First of all, this review is written after a re-watch. I‘m also up to date with the manga so I may be harsher on the anime that I should. I will also review this season based on how good it is on its own so I won’t cut it some slag because of the necessity in the greater story and after all is said and done I still recommend Nanatsu no Taisai to anyone who is looking for a good action series.
This season follows the story of Elizabeth, the third princess of Britannia and Meliodas, the leader of the infamous Seven Deadly Sins, who areaccused of having planed to gain control of the kingdom 10 years ago. After unexpectedly meeting each other in the first episode they team up to search for the remaining members of the Seven Deady Sins and to stop the rebellion of the Holy Knights.


The anime does a good job in establishing a relaxing atmosphere, while sometimes letting us see through the cracks and hinting at the idea that not all is as relaxing as it first seams, giving the anime a nice dark undertone. Ignoring these moments however it is hard not to relax while watching this anime because from the color palette to the actions of the characters, everything is creating this nice relaxing atmosphere. This however also means that there is no tension for the majority of the show, only the last conflict has any tension because for the first time it seems like the Sins are being pushed to their limits.

Turning the eye to the characters, it is easy to identified them as stereotypes. Later down in the story however it becomes apparent that they have more going on then one can see on the surface. This is mostly hinted at in flashbacks to tragic moments in their life but the don’t get to much information regarding the past of the Sins. All members of the Seven Deadly Sins also have tragedies or sins corresponding to their title, Wrath (Meliodas), Greed (Ban), Sloth (King), Lust (Gowther), Gluttony(Merlin), Envy (Diane) and Pride (Unknown).

The story structure is rather easy, the first half focuses on the gathering of the Sins and follows the easy sequence of somehow getting information that a Sin is rumored to bin in x location, then making their way to check if its true or not and either on the way or after reuniting with a Sin getting dragged in a conflict or attack. The second half is mostly fighting after responding to a kidnapping so there isn’t much of a story. The only story progression is the revelation of the enemy mastermind and his motivation and I have to say, it’s questionable at best.


Even if this review sounds quite negative, I still recommend Nanatsu no Taisai because most of the problem I have with this season get addressed late on in the story. I view this season as I view the first season of HeroAca, bad in comparison of the rest of the story but it needed to do what it did because this is the foundation on which the rest of the story lies.

Seven Deadly Sins is a story about the princess of the land, searching for the notorious outlaws to help put an end to an oppressive rule. It's a funny, epic, goofy story.
Story: The story is very interesting in itself, with lots how they will take the land back, although at times it feels inconsistent different quirks that are sometimes just dropped out of nowhere. Its nothing to take seriously, and is overall enjoyable, but nothing to scream about.
Art: The art is bubbly and colourful, which goes hand in hand with the show's tone. The art style is definitely present. It's charming and interesting to lookat.\n\n
Characters: The characters are all ridiculous in their own ways. Over exaggerated and fun. Although some are a little underdeveloped, it doesn't take away from the shows overall enjoyment.\n\n
Enjoyment: This show is not meant to be a mindblowing experience. It's more something to watch as you wind down. Just something funny and ridiculous that will make have you laughing. If that's what you're into, I definitely recommend this show.

In the midst of a boring ass night of scrolling through awful Netflix anime, I happened to fall upon this show. I've heard it pop in and around of a few shounen discussions so I figured I should give it a shot since I've been a huge fan of shounen anime since I was young. And even though I've experienced all the shounen cliche's and linear story lines, something about Nanatsu no Taizai feels genuinely offensive to me in how it manages to surpass even the worst of shounen anime in terms of being uninspired and linear.
Story: 2/10 Honestly, the concept of a princess's journeyto find an exiled group of knights to take back her kingdom sounds like it could be really good on paper, however any and all potential is immediately squashed as most of it is used for shitty fights and nonsensical and awkward fanservice. Elizabeth and Meliodas have 0 chemistry and the only times they do are when she's just randomly okay with him molesting the shit out of her on every journey. The story hits you with cliche after cliche and none of them are done in a tasteful to get enjoyment out of. The fanservice is awful and surprisingly sexist, the characters always border on useless or way too overpowered, the plot is linear, etc. You'll get 0 surprises from this anime and if you're like me, you'll probably just get irritated from the shit this anime tries to feed you.


Art: 4/10 Apart from character design, the animation is pretty decent. Nothing really to see here. 


Characters: 1/10 Definitely the worst quality of this anime. Majority of the characters and people in it are very uninteresting and horribly designed. Meliodas is overpowered, Elizabeth just cries and is there for nothing but being groped on screen. Other characters are about as one-dimensional as the protagonists, just not as annoying cause they don't get nearly as much screen time as these two morons.


Sound: 4/10 All of the sounds from the OST to the openings are just serviceable. Nothing that really stands out and enhances the scenes but at the same time I don't really hate any of the music they have.


Enjoyment: 1/10 This anime is really mind-numbing. I generally have never outright hated an anime but this one really takes the cake. Everything about it feels offensive to my soul and I can barely find any good things to say about it. I feel like this anime sends out a bad message about how bare-minimum and untasteful you can make a series and still have it praised as a good shounen. Everything Nanatsu does has been done before but a thousand times better. 


Overall: 1/10 You're probably just better off finding another shounen series if you want something entertaining with characters duking it out. This anime is awful.

PSA Warning:
Out of concern for your eyes, if you are allergic to stupidity do not read my review. This is my first ever review and is therefore bound to suck. I have never been much of a writer either. However if you still wish to continue you have my condolences.
SPOILER FREE REVIEW
Nanatsu no taizai is an action adventure oriented anime with a lot of light-hearted humor to kind of gloss over the serious tones that the show throws at us every now and then. The show is good for a fun watch as it doesn't provide much in terms of character development, with such amassive cast of characters though, that is to be expected. This doesn't however take away from the fact that a lot of the characters are indeed very fun and interesting. The show will give backstories to many of the characters, and even mess around with our emotions regarding some of them. However that's all fine and dandy, but the main character, Meliodas, gets little to no development aside from his superficial change that he experience thanks to Elizabeth near the end of the show. Now this would be okay if the story were told from the perspective of a character who has no impact on the world being viewed, however he is not only the main character of the show, but also one of the most influential and renowned person in their world. So while there is little that could have been done to rectify this problem of lack of development among all the characters (other than create a 100 episode long show), it is one of the bigger problems I have with the show.\n
Characters: 8\n
Character Development: 7\n
Moving on to the plot and pacing of the show, there is little that I can really poke ate. Now that isn't to say that the story is an amazing piece of work that has never been done before; in fact its is the complete opposite. This show follows your usual adventure action type of story-line in that its predictable and rather simple. It doesn't do anything complex regarding its topic of "betrayed by your own now corrupt kingdom" (for that check out Ubel Blatt an amazing manga) which is an always fun theme but is extremely hard to do well. All this comes down to the fact that I didn't go into this show expecting some amazing story telling and complex and head turning plot twists. No I expected the usual below average shounen that get produced by the hundreds, and was instead pleasantly surprised with a better than okay story. However that doesn't forgive its many flaws in pacing. I like to compare this shows pacing to Attack on Titan since everyone knows that show, the show starts off at a breakneck pace and doesn't slow down for a good amount of time, but suddenly you will find that the story comes to an abrupt halt, and slows to a snails crawl. Now I'm not saying that the originally fast paced plot is good, in fact it can also be very badly done, as seen at the end of the show as it seemingly speeds everything up in order to just barely fit in the ending, the ending which that they pulled out of one of their intern's ass and just slapped on with bunch of Elmer's glue and staples.\n
Plot: 8\n
Pacing: 6\n
Nothing special to say about the art and music really, do love both openings of the show dearly, and I always find myself singing along to them, much to the dismay of my roommate. Otherwise the rest of the soundtrack I found to be rather dismissible, and the art while not bad was by no means anything special, it had the usual A-1 Pictures feel that a lot of their animation has, in that its really nice and you can literally see the money flowing out of your screen (too bad you can’t take some of it though), but it didn’t manage to leave an impression on me.\n
Art: 7\n
Music: 8\n
Finally the most important part, the enjoyment category (I should try and put this as my first category next time). This show like I said earlier is a fun watch, its upbeat and happy, and has a feel similar to that of one piece, one of my childhood shows that I still watch to this day. It is for that reason that I most likely enjoyed it. I while I do love to get down and dirty watching some super-duper serious shows that only the “elites” can understand, I like to go back to my roots and enjoy a fun laugh with a light hearted show such as this. And it is for that reason that the highest rating any of the sections gets is in this one. I managed to make time out of my busy college and work life to watch the whole show in three days, all with little to no fast forwarding. Taking that into account this show definitely deserves a good score for managing to hold my terrible attention.\n
Enjoyment: 9\n
Overall it was rather enjoyable to watch this show and I even started reading the manga because of it, and it is for that reason that I award this show with an:\n
8/10\n
Hope you all enjoyed reading my review, feel free to check out my poopy list of anime and manga, and feel free to shoot me any questions, comments, or friend requests. I plan to continue writing these reviews as often as I can as its actually pretty fun. And also to those thinking about writing a review just do it. You won’t regret it, the first step is starting and that is always the hardest part.\n

I didn't think I was gonna be a fan of Nanatsu when I watched the first episode, cus the art was a bit not my style and the fanservice seemed to be in your face and obnoxious. Then I watched the 2nd episode for kicks. Then the third. Then the fourth. You get the idea. Soon I was obsessed.
Story: 10
Story was, as MAL describes it, outstanding. It didn't really seem all that stereotypical at first (though I saw Meliodas being a sin coming from a mile away... thought he was gonna be lust though lol) and as the plot developed, I found myself waiting forthe next episode with bated breath. The way it captures you with each episode is unique and can only be credited back to excellent writing and a LOT of developmental work. So much love and care is put into each episode and that's what makes it worth watching, if not anything else.\n
Art: 8\n
The art, like I said, did not capture me at first. Too cutesy and the anatomy was ridiculous (what skinny female has boobs that big???????), but it most certainly grew on me. It suits the show really well and the background art was so amazingly detailed and beautiful. Though A-1 Pictures is generally known for the abominations of Aldnoah 2, Magi, and SAO, they honestly transferred manga-to-anime art so smoothly that I didn't even know it was A-1 until I looked on MAL. The animation is stunning, but A-1 has always been pretty good with animation so that wasn't too shocking. What brought this rating down was the amount of effort I put in before I liked the art. What saved it was its evolution and the gradual look of aging and maturity you can see in the characters.\n
Sound: 10\n
I could listen to the NnT OST all day. The openings and endings are so great that I can't pick a favorite, and the BGM suits each scene really well. Not really much to say here, good job A-1.\n
Character: 9\n
A-1 is known for its plot-annihilating adaptions. It loves to reduce characters down to their stereotypes and rip up plots like a dog rips up newspaper.  I haven't read the manga of NnT, but the characters and plot were very well put together in my opinion. A manga reader may say otherwise, but this is just my own input. The characters develop so well and the backstories are tragic yet beautiful. One complaint I have is the obsession with Elaine, a minor character who was only there to advance Ban's character, and yet she continues to be brought back again and again and treated like an actual major character. This show's inability to separate protagonists from tritagonists brought its rating down.\n
Enjoyment: 9\n
If the fanservice was less boobs-and-ass-in-your-face-all-the-time, it'd have gotten a 10 from me. I guess that's just my own take on it, as I'm pretty sick of fanservice, so take that in stride. Still, its ability to smoothly transition from comedy to angst to action to ecchi was spectacular, and I stopped minding the fanservice after a few episodes. It really made me interested in the manga, and I have no regrets watching this series. It made my week so interesting, thinking about each episode for days afterwards. Nanatsu no Taizai is memorable, to say the very least. It has a sort of charm to it that makes it unusual for its type, and I recommend it to anyone who wants an excellent plot, a few good tear-jerking moments, and cute and powerful girls.

Right now, as of writing this review, the number-one review for this show is 5 lines long. Look, I understand that being concise is nice, but I think few shows deserve that kind of treatment. 
Obviously not every show is for everyone. Not only that, but people are often looking for different shows at different times. For instance, I'm usually into really dark thematic shit like Utena and Madoka, but I recently moved across the country to teach highschool in a culture I know nothing about, and I found that at the end of each insanely stressful day the last thing I wanted was toget home and overload my brain with symbolism and essays. Once I adjusted I returned to my usual ways of course, but for that first week I just wanted something that would entertain me and lift my mood. So, in spite of myself, I actually had the audacity to hit "play" on the first episode of The Seven Deadly Sins, a show I had heard was pretty much complete garbage. And guess what? I ate up every single episode, OVAs included, and if season two were to go out right now I would pour myself a drink and binge it straight through the night.


Why?


Do I think the show is actually good?


Well, that's actually kind of tricky. Let's start off with the reasons you shouldn't watch this show. 


1. If you literally cannot stand cliche plots, you should not bother with this show. The plot is as cliche as you can get. There are essentially no serious surprises, and the show doesn't attempt to base itself around any sort of novel premise. It's pretty much just standard fantasy, with good guys versus bad guys and a few in-between guys. Don't overthink it.


2. If you hate bad writing, don't bother. There's a ton of extremely unnatural dialogue in this show. Every episode has blatant dismissals of the 'show-don't-tell' rule, and no one talks about anything that actually matters, ever. Go read a book instead.


3. If you're turned away by fanservice, put on something else. There's not all too much of it, but the smattering of fanservice in this show is some of the most egregious shit I've seen. Basically, the main character likes to grope the other main character seemingly against her will every couple of episodes and it's supposed to be a joke. That's kind of fucked up, and if you are incapable of just kinda zoning out for those scenes (which makes total sense) then get out of here right now. 


Wow, that makes this show sound absolutely terrible. I guess it kind of is? And yet, Here I am, advocating for this pile of stereotypical tropey garbage. Why? Well, I enjoyed it. I enjoyed it a lot. I mean, I really don't binge shows anymore. I don't have that kind of stamina. But I watched like 5 episode of this thing a day, I firmly believe there's a reason to its addicting nature.


First of all, and this is a grossly overlooked quality-- The Seven Deadly Sins is consistent. It literally only takes one or two off-beat episodes for me to drop a show like this, meaning that I drop most of them. However, this particular one never made a significant misstep. From the beginning it promised action, humor, cuteness, adventure, and plot development every episode, and it delivered straight through. It never stopped building its core story, providing enough hooks to pull you to the next episode, but it also never stopped spending heartwarming quality time with its main cast. This is  actually a pretty tough accomplishment to pull off over 24 episodes, and I fully commend the highly-qualified production team for their success here. The show doesn't let up, with a finely-tuned pacing that expertly holds the viewer's attention span without feeling excessively rushed at any point.


Second, the music. Look, music can carry an entire show if it's used right. And I don't just mean that the music is good: I mean that it's placed well and not abused. The music is done by Hiroyuki Sawano, so the tracks are obviously great already, but many a great soundtrack has been squandered by abusing its signature songs and bombarding early episodes with the full numbers. The Seven Deadly Sins holds back: it's got the song Perfect Time under its belt, which is likely one of the hypest soundtracks of all time, and yet instead of drowning all the action scenes with this particular piece until you become numb to it, it saves the full version with lyrics until THE VERY LAST EPISODE. Before that, it uses only instrumental versions of the song, leaning instead on a myriad of other pieces to carry the bulk of the excitement. On top of this, the second opening is one of the best openings ever made, going a long way towards pushing investment without playing the show's trump cards. This is smart and conservative show-making, guys. I was impressed.


Third, the plot. Look, it's literally a stitched-together corpse of tropes, as I've already mentioned. However, it's stitched together in a different way then shows before it. This might seem like I'm grasping for straws, but it makes a huge difference. There are very few moments in this show where you won't say "I've seen this before", but by stapling together a wide range of cliches it keeps the overall story from being too predictable while also preventing you from being entirely sure how a scenario will play out. It's the sense of guessing that keeps stuff interesting, and The Seven Deadly Sins does a fairly good job of keeping you guessing through all of the cliches.


Finally, and this is easily the most important--The Seven Deadly Sins is [i]uplifting.[/i] Seriously, this makes the biggest difference in the world. I enjoyed watching this show way more than Fullmetal Alchemist:B, even though that show is much better by traditional metrics. Tone pulls WEIGHT like NOTHING ELSE, and if you go down the route of committing to being serious and intense you had better be able to back it up with execution or else your show will quickly become trying and boring no matter how big your plot is. The Seven Deadly Sins never pretends to be anything other than a raunchy, loud, feel-good adventure tale, focusing on the fun rather than the drama and keeping its characters rather free of the 'tragic backstory' trap, slipping in moments of substance but never de-railing to go chase some idiotic piece of prehistoric drama that no one cares about. Everything in the show works towards the atmosphere: the bright, crisp, cartoony art, the upbeat music, the generally positive character interactions, the morally simplistic plot; this is a concerted effort to craft something wholly positive, and by Jove does it pay off. This thing is a blast to watch.


Overall? Overall, if you're looking for a smart, thoughtful story, run for the hills. However, if you're at the place we all reach eventually where you just want something to entertain you and make your mood improve, give this thing a whirl. It's got a team of geniuses behind it: no really, you've got key members of the teams of everything from Evangelion to Steins;Gate to Oregairu and the Eccentric Family, and all they're trying to do is make you feel good. They're pretty good at it. Just don't go in expecting a masterpiece and you should be alright.

A fairly immature anime centered around friendship and adventure. It has an almost "fairytail" like feel to it, where no one important actually dies and they make friends with their rivals/enemies but to an even worse degree. The action is fairly strong in this anime but i can't really ignore the numerous anime cliche's, character tropes and the fairly bad/fast pacing. Most of the cliche's and tropes are forgiven overtime through story progression and character development but you can still feel the traces of it lingering on. (elizabeth = princess trope, diane = the over obsessed #1 meliodas fan, king = the nosebleed shy boy,ban = the aloof keep to himself cool guy whom drinks the most because of his problematic past, this also isn't short from the cliches of excessive groping, friendship is power, no one can die, hidden main character abilities and how the main character is always smiling etc.)\n\n
Other than that they did execute the plotline fairly well and in a concise matter which was enjoyable. The action was fun, the story was paced well, and even with the tropes you did find the characters intriguing in some sort of way. I think how they executed the backstories was it's best suit.

Nanatsu no Taizai/七つの大罪/The Seven Deadly Sins Review
Story (6/10) Fine
Nanatsu No Taizai's story I thought was fine, I started this anime series (as an anime only watcher) back in October of 2014 when episode 1 first aired. And back then I thought it was ok. It had a couple of interesting things going on and but a few similarities to Fairy Tail (And I hate Fairy Tail... but it's probably only because A-1 Pictures is adapting this series which is probably why the art style and atmosphere and resemble that of Fairy Tail). Either way since we are on the topic of what this anime remindsme of from A-1 Pictures another on that comes to mind is Magi. And the only reason Magi comes to mind is because when it comes to adaptation quality and pacing of Nanatsu No Tazai (as far as I heard) this was a series (just like Magi) that A-1 Pictures decided to speed run adapt 24 episodes within the contents of around 100 chapters. If you know how much content is within 100 chapters of a manga then you should already know that when it comes to adaptation quality things are definitely going to be left out. Now as an anime only watcher I've only heard of certain key elements that were left out and I heard they were quite important to the arcs presented in this 24 episode season and future arcs in seasons to come. And as I watched about majority of this anime of Nanatsu No Taizai it definitely felt like certain areas were rushed or didn't make entirely too much sense because it wasn't really focus on as much or just flat out MIA. And those were the issues I felt lead to me feeling not as interesting in the overall story as I should have been had certain missing plots were present. Either way it didn't make the overall story bad it, I should can't see myself giving the story anything higher than a 6 know I was fed a arguably half-assed version of the manga's original story because A-1 wanted to speed run adapt apparently a manga that has a good story.



Art and Animation (7/10) Good 

More Specifically (7.50/10) Good+


The Art when done right in certain scenes can look very good, same thing goes for animation on certain scenes animation can look very good also but the art style during these very good animation scenes always seems to take an immense drop in art quality to the point were it annoyed me. Now the same thing happened in Magi but not as much as this series. The choreography for the fight scenes probably looked amazing in the manga and when the choreography was adapted here the actual choreography was great and the animation that went with those scenes were very good but the art style could not hold up 90% of the time which makes me definitely look at A-1 Pictures in a different light, before Magi, Fairy Tail and this I thought A-1 was around and a little bit behind Madhouse (only going off of SOA Season 1). Now I would say there are just a little bit above like Toei and Studio Perriot on their off days.



Sound (9/10) Great


If there's anything A-1 or any studio really can't fuck up now these days is the sound. Nanatsu No Taizai has great sound. OST is great, voice acting (at least for the JP VA) are great, but I can't say the same thing for the english dub for a couple of the voices in particular Meliodas I couldn't stand his english dub it was horrible to me. 



Characters (7/10) Good


I thought the characters in Nanatsu No Taizai are good. Some good backstory on the ones they gave us like King, Diane and Bon. Like I heard certain important things were missing from this anime adaptation but oh well.



Enjoyment (7/10) Good


My enjoyment for this season of Nanatsu No Taizai overall is a 7. It could have been higher if it could have kept my interest around the beginning which to me felt a little bit lack luster, uninteresting and generic quite honestly. And it's probably what led me to put it on hold around episode 13 because I just felt it wasn't something worth getting excited over weekly to watch only one episode of. There are a few anime that get me hyped every week a new episode dropped and this wasn't one of them. Now that I've binge watched it, I can tell you I honestly didn't start to really enjoy it until the last arc of this season which I heard before I even started that it that it is probably the best arc in Nanatsu No Taizai right now and I can see why it was a good arc or at least good enough for the enjoyment section of this review to not be anything lower than a 7 that is because without that arc enjoyment would have probably been at a 5. 



Overall (7/10) Good 

More Specifically (7.30/10)


Nanatsu No Taizai is a good anime... it's good... that's it. That's all I can give it, I know I shouldn't compare this Magi or any other anime in this review but I just have to say since A-1 Pictures treated this and Magi with the same "let's adapt 100+ chapter of your manga into a 25 some odd anime series" I just have to compare the two and with that being said I like Magi a whole lot more. But Nanatsu No Taizai was still enjoyable enough for me not to drop it and it was good enough for me to give the next season which is apparently starting in 2016 a shot. I'll try to stay caught up weekly with that one because this one couldn't do it for me.

Disclaimer: This review will also be including season 2, becuase I'd rather not make two seperate reviews for the same series. There might also be a few spoilers included in this review just so I can fully prove how bad this anime is.
First things first, do not watch this anime if you are above the age of 16. This is one of the most childish anime I've ever watched in my life. I honestly felt as if I was watching some type of Disney cartoon. That's how fucking childish this anime was. This is one of the most generic, predictable, and childish anime I've everwatched in my life. 


The story is about our main characters (Meliodas and Elizabeth) travelling together to gather the rest of the Seven Deadly Sins. Their goal is to take back the kingdom of Britania. This is one of the most cliche stories I've seen in a shounen. So right from the start this anime is already uninteresting with its generic ass story. The plot is also terrible. It's literally just the typical pokemon type of plot structure. Another reason why the story is shit, there's no worldbuilding whatsoever. We don't know shit about the world they're living in, besides a couple of towns. Without worldbuilding, I didn't give a shit about the story for this anime at all.


When it comes to characters, there isn't a single good character in this series. There's three words that best describe the characters: generic, underdeveloped, and boring. Firstly we have Meliodas, a main character that hasn't gotten an ounce of character development for 50 episodes. His laidback personality is cool and all, but there's no reason to be interested in this character. He lacks any element that makes a character great. The rest of the cast is trash aswell. Next we have Elizabeth, the cliche damsel in distress character. Once again, there's no reason to like this character. 


Do I even need to bring up character development? There isn't even a single character that gets character development, so I won't even bother bringing that up anymore. They're all one dimensional characters and overall just aren't interesting. Escanor has to be one of the most overrated characters I've seen in a Shounen. I find it werid how Shounen fanboys like characters simply because of the fact that they're overpowered. Like these fanboys don't care if a character has depth/development, they literally just like characters because they're strong. That's the most stupid reason for liking a character. 


The rest of the sins are complete trash aswell. When it comes to villains, there isn't even one good villain in this series. Gilthunder was cool at first until he got thrown away by the writers. After season 1, he's always in the background and is pretty much an irrelevant character. So yeah...sorry to the Gilthunder fans that recently started watching this...Hendrickson is the typical shounen villain aswell. 


The best character in this series is Hawk btw


The villains for the second season are even worse than the first one! It's crazy how so many people were hyping the 10 Commandments up, yet they turned out to be complete garbage and a massive disappointment. As usual, they're the typical villains you see in shounen that are just evil for the sake of being evil. Their motivations weren't interesting in the slightest. All of them are one dimensional charactes, even Zeldris which is apparently one of the more important ones of the 10 Commandments. In conclusion, the 10 Commandments are the worst group of villains I've seen in a battle shounen. 


Now lets talk about the second season. This will go down as the worst second season I've ever seen in an anime EVER. The story/plot for the second season is even worse. The second seasons story is about the Demon Clan. They finally have awakened (thanks to Hendrickson). So this whole season they're pretty much just fighting off the 10 Commandments. Here are all the problems I found in this season.


 Firstly, the plot is just fucking horrible. The writer clearly had no idea what he wanted to do. The plot was just all over the place! One second everything is peaceful, next second they're fighting a Commandment that just came out of nowhere. One second they're training, next they're fighting a commandment again. It's all over the damn place. Another problem I had with this season is the other garbage ass plot points, especially the one about Diane. That has to be one of the most boring things I've ever watched.  There's a bunch of stupid plot points that were introduced in this season it just became ridiculous.


There was a lot of deus ex machina being used in this season. One of the biggest examples of this is when Ban was 1v2ing two of the Commandments. He was losing the fight until he just found a random cave where Escanor just happened to be running a bar. After that he was saved by Escanor. If you cant see how stupid that shit is then I don't know what to tell you. In general there are a lot of asspull powers that just come out of nowhere. I wont make this part too long though. It's a battle shounen so it isn't that surprising that there is bad writing like this.


Lets talk about the fights now. The fights in season 1 were all pretty decent in terms of choreography. Well, the only actual good fight scenes were when Meliodas fought Hendrickson. Everything else was just average at best. The second season on the other hand, had AWFUL fights. As someone that read the manga, it was just a massive disappointment to see some of these fights animated. The animation was just straight up garbage in season 2. A-1 just dropped the ball on this one.


This anime has hands down some of the ugliest art I've seen in a shounen. All of the characters just look so goofy and ugly it's insane. Like seriously, they all have fucked up noses and shit it just looks ridiculous. The art overall just looks like childish nonsense. The mangaka was trying to be unique, but no it just looks like shit.


So here are my scores for each category



Story/Plot: 1/10

Characters: 1/10

Enjoyment: 2/10

Art: 4/10

Animation: 5/10

It was disappointing. This show has a lot of potential but fails to reach it.
Story :5 
The story started out interesting which made me wanting to continue watch it, how the Seven deadly sins were a bunch of traitors this and that. But progressing through  the story it started to become cliche. Cliches are fine but it was not executed well. The hero had to save the damsel in distressed and some plot twist that didn't really made sense ? The writers just gave some pathetic excuse and i was left "oh thats it?" Ultimately the last few episodes really dragged the score down
Art:7


I actually like the style but you can tell that they only put in effort in fights scenes that the main hero is in. It doesn't give much impact for the rest of the characters.


Sound:7


Im not that good at music so who am I to accurately judge this. It was enjoyable to me and i loved the openings and endings.


Character: 6


The score would have been much lower if it were not for the supporting cast. The two main characters were something i could not bring myself to enjoy.


Meliodas was such a boring character. His personality was like a wooden block. He is usually happy and is perverted. Thats all i got from the 24 episodes. He gets angry when elizabeth is hurt an what not thats all. There is no depth in his character other that his mysterious past which im not remotely interested in. Furthermore he is overpowered. I get that he is supposed to be but he keeps pulling deus ex machina bullshit powers out of his ass whenever convenient. 


Elizabeth was nothing but a nice crybaby. There is nothing else to her personality. Also deus ex machina powers again. She is also useless, always getting her self in trouble like you cannot fight just stay out of battle. Then she just screams for meliodas to save her. Additionally her portrayal pf a sensitive girl is quite ironic. She cried when a pig died and whenever meliodas is hurt but not rarely for the other sins ????????  


Jesus they are the only two characters that i have problems with which sullen this anime experience.


What would have been better is giving depth to meliodas character and just remove elizabeth from the story, i really did not see her use other that uniting the sins (which they could have done themelves) and her blood for some ritual. Or they should have made her a supporting character.


I really liked characters like diane and king as they display many qualities like their insecurity and other WIDE RANGE OF EMOTIONS.


Ban and gowther were fun to watch, villians were interesting if they were given more time and not defeated in one fight.(goddamit overpowered mc)


Enjoyment: 7


 regardless of the many mistakes I still enjoyed the show but overall it was meh.

Is this the next big Shōnen hit? Better yet, is it good? These questions rose quickly when this series got an anime adaptation. And I'm here to answer them.
__________________________________________________________________________
STORY: 7/10
The story of most Shōnen is usually where their fans come from. Nanatsu no Taizai has a very unique story, but it isn't flawless like that of other Shōnen. The basic explanation of it is that the captain of the Seven Deadly Sins decides to regather up the other sins with his new traveling companion, a girl who needs their strength to save her kingdom. The story is full of plotholes and missing information, and inthe end feels very rushed. However it is very lighthearted and even hilarious at times, but serious when necessary, and overall is good.

__________________________________________________________________________

ART: 5/10


The worst part of this show is definitely it's art. NO, THAT DOES NOT MEAN THE ANIMATION, THE ANIMATION IS OF VERY HIGH QUALITY AND DESERVES A MUCH HIGHER SCORE. However the art...well it's unique, to say the least. However, it is very...circular, I guess would be the best way to describe it. It makes character's eyes look very weird, which is the second most defining feature other than hair. Something about it just...bothered me.

__________________________________________________________________________

SOUND: 9/10


This is one of Sawano's better works. AND THEY WERE ALREADY GODLY! His epicness combined with the fairy tail type soundtrack proved to be an incredible combination. However, in the end, the soundtrack couldn't be perfect unless Sawano is working with flat out serious anime, but he still did a great job with this!

__________________________________________________________________________

CHARACTER: 10/10


The greatest aspect of nanatsu no taizai is it's character arsenal. I have nothing to say about this. They're all unique, funny, and awesome in there own way, even the villains.

__________________________________________________________________________

OVERALL: 8/10


Overall, this is my favorite anime ever. However that is proabably because of my personal preference towards the story. Besides, even blinded by that I can tell it's not perfect. But it is good. Very Good.

Story: 8/10  The story is nothing SUPER special. The main female protagonist, Elizabeth goes about seeking the Seven Deadly Sins to try and stop the uprising of the main villainous force (The Holy Knights). She runs into Meliodas who just so happens to one of the Seven Deadly Sins. From there they come to a mutual agreement to search for the remaining Seven Deadly Sins to take down the threat of the Holy Knights. Antics are plentiful along their adventures so you can expect some light hearted comedy along the way. Some twists and turns happen as well to keep you on your toesa bit. 


Art: 9/10  The art style is very vivid. One thing that sometimes determines what I watch is the art, and for me, this one hits the nail on the head. It's not the most amazing art in the world, but it's anything but bad. You can tell by seeing the landscapes and such that you will be traversing through a very fantasy-esque adventure. The characters are all different and are very colorful as well.


Sound: 8/10  The soundtrack for this anime is pretty good. It has a medieval sound to them and all of the soundtracks fit very well with the scenes. If you want to include the intro and outros, all of them are great and I find myself watching them instead of skipping them. More so the first outro and the second intro. Finally let's cover the voices. All of the voices fit for all of the characters and they all just feel natural.


Characters: 10/10  This is where the anime truly shines. Every character is likeable in some way. They all have distinct personalities and have some pros and cons going for them. Even the villains have amazing personalities, so much that you may find yourself actually liking them instead of hating them. The characters alone made this show for me and I hope you enjoy them just as much as I did.


Enjoyment: 10/10  Everything about this anime just felt right to me. It's one of if not my all time favorite anime. The pacing feels right, the humor to serious ratio seems just right, the characters and how they interact with each other are all great as well. It's just one of those anime that I enjoyed from episode one to finish.


Overall: 9/10  Personally I want to give this a 10/10, but I know everyone has their own opinions and I'm trying not to be biased. I know the anime has it's flaws, but maybe I'm just blinded by my personal feelings towards it because I find it painful to give it anything lower than an 8.5/10 (I rounded up because it's more of a 9 than an 8). However, if you're looking for an anime with some nice fight scenes, a likeable story, some good humor, a lovable cast, and a bright world full of adventure. I think you should give this a try.

“No matter how much you bleed and even if your tears run dry, you stick to it. That’s what a knight stands for.”
Elizabeth Liones, the third princess of the Liones Kingdom, sets out to find the “Seven Deadly Sins,” an ill-reputed group of former knights, with the hopes of taking back her once-peaceful land from the corrupt Holy Knights who have taken over. The show is, unsurprisingly, packed to the brim with the larger-than-life fights, adventurous spirit and charismatic characters that one would expect from a battle shounen.
Nanatsu no Taizai‘s artwork is vivid and lively, with lush, emerald hillsides, rustic cottages and eye-popping shades ofblue sky depicting the show’s English countryside-inspired setting to great effect. In addition, character designs are unique and memorable, doing a good job of conveying personality and ensuring the viewer is able to distinguish between the individuals of quite a large cast.


In terms of animation, Nanatsu has its weak moments, especially during more static scenes that center around a conversation or something to that effect. For the most part though, the show’s animation works greatly to its advantage. Fast-paced action and movement scenes look dynamic and visceral, to the point where if you blink at the wrong moment, you might miss something important.


All in all, the color palette is full of life and spectacularly pretty, while the animation is quite strong, especially during the show’s high-octane fight scenes. Amongst A-1’s works, Nanatsu no Taizai stands near the top visually.


Adhering to the status quo as far as battle shounens go, Nanatsu‘s overarching story doesn’t really stand out as anything spectacular or refreshing. “Princess recruits ragtag outlaws to save kingdom from new corrupt leaders” doesn’t really stand on its own as a strong, mind-blowing narrative. On the way to resolving this main arc, the show takes us through an assortment of mini side arcs, which introduce the viewer to new team recruits and flesh them out, mainly via backstory. Again, this should be pretty standard fare for anybody accustomed to battle shounens, and though some may view it as repetitive, tired even, Nanatsu does its best at making it work. And for the most part, it does. And that’s because of the…


Characters – one of the major things this show has going for it. The cast involved are charming, likeable and memorable, each with their own stories and special abilities. As one of the “Seven Deadly Sins,” each of these characters has a past shrouded in mystery and regret, and it’s a lot of fun as a viewer learning more about them, and seeing how they overcome their past struggles in the present. For this type of story, it’s essential that we as viewers are presented with a group of fleshed-out protagonists whom we want to root for, and Nanatsu no Taizai does a great job of this, making up for the barebones nature of its overarching narrative.


Ban, King and Meliodas stand out as fantastic additions to the cast, and even characters that come across somewhat one-dimensional and annoying when they are introduced, like Diane and Gowther, grow on you by the end of the show. Hawk functions more as a sort of mascot for the show, but provides some welcome comedic relief at select moments throughout. The main gripe, character-wise, is Elizabeth, the main heroine, who reverts to being a passive damsel-in-distress whenever the events of the story call for it. After all, the show does have a tendency to fall back on shounen tropes now and then, so this doesn’t come as much of a surprise. Even the main antagonist comes off a bit cliché and probably would’ve been more effective had they been written to be more charismatic and/or interesting.


At the end of Episode 24, I realized that I didn’t want these characters’ adventure to end, and couldn’t wait for a second season (which is thankfully coming in a month). Looking past the sometimes tropey writing, Nanatsu no Taizai is at its core, a fun, light-hearted adventure, complete with the fights, plot twists and hints of romance that we have come to expect from the genre. It’s more akin to something like Boku no Hero Academia in its tendency to stick to genre conventions while still telling an enjoyable, highly effective story, than it is to Hunter x Hunter, which redefines the battle shounen entirely.


One element which may be a turn-off to some people is the ecchi present throughout. Though it occurs only a handful of times in the span of the show, instances of Meliodas groping Elizabeth or peeking under her skirt are quite jarring and seem unnecessary to the overall narrative. Elizabeth’s general passivity in these situations only serves to make things worse. Perhaps it is an attempt to paint Meliodas as a less-than-honourable figure or more likely a pandering to the target demographic, but it still feels like the show could have gone without it.


The fact that Nanatsu is so easily digestible (coming in at only 24 episodes), especially compared to longer shounen series plagued by filler and 5-episode long flashbacks, makes it an easy show to recommend. Unless you are vehemently opposed to shounen tropes being thrown in here and there, there is little reason not to watch and appreciate this show for what it is: a fun, colorful adventure and strong entry in the shounen lineup. Though it likely won’t end up becoming one of your all-time favourite anime, and you may not even remember much of it a few years down the road, Nanatsu has plenty of heart and charm to keep you entertained for the time being.


If you’re hot off the heels of watching a whole bunch of battle shounen anime (Naruto, Bleach, Hero Academia, etc.) and are now desperately seeking something new to fill the void, Nanatsu no Taizai is a fantastic choice. It plays off a good deal of the genre’s tropes, and while it doesn’t do anything ground-breaking with them, it still manages to be a highly enjoyable experience. Pleasing visuals, dynamic fights, a vast and memorable cast, and a satisfying array of romance, comedy, adventure, fantasy and plot twists all make for an exciting and fulfilling ride.

A lot of the negative reviews here are from people watching season 1 and saying there isn't much story or growth. Well, yeah, season 1 is meant to introduce you to 5 of the 7 deadly sins and get to know why some of them hate each other, love each other, support one another, and get to know their personalities. This sets the stage for the major growth personally as well as improvements in their abilities and fight scenes to come. 
Instant gratification is not on everyone's list of requirements for an excellent anime. Instead, we are introduced to several subtleties that I didn't evenrealize until reading the manga. It was rewarding to rewatch having caught up with the manga as of 10/30/18.


There are several things in season 1, and even season 2, that you don't even know you don't know, because you haven't questioned it yet. The anime follows the manga quite well, and the subtle romantic, friendship growth, or childhood cut aways give depth and meaning to the lives of the characters besides simply being strong adventurers traveling together. Thankfully, there are no needless cutaways, rather they're actually enjoyable. 


Please stop writing negative reviews of anime's after 1 season unless you completed the manga to date anime's use the first season to set up the show as a whole. Based on the manga, season 3 is going to be absolutely epic.

The number seven is always a thing that comes up in anime. It’s always used as way to give characters diverse tropes or is a number to represent objects a hero must smash to save the world. Seven Deadly Sins or SDS is your generic action series about a group of interesting characters uniting to fight a large scale foe. If you like stuff such as the "Legend of Arslan" and "Yona of the Dawn" you might like this show as the story is similar to a degree.
Like Yona and Arslan SDS includes a young future ruler Elizabeth seeking out a group of powerful warriorsto take back her kingdom from tyranny. The warriors are the Sins who are these very powerful magic wielding knights who are wanted for trying to take over the kingdom ten years before. Each episode has our heroes fight new foes continuously who are at different levels of strength so it’s pretty generic but is still interesting.


 There was a point in the story where I felt there was a cop out to make things less serious then they were at that point. Despite its looks this show can be very dark at points. The cop out was that they had this one opportunity in later episodes where they can make the show more intense but they did not go through with it likely out of fear of how the fans would react. 


The Art of this series is very bright and colorful which at first makes you kind of feel you are watching something meant for kids. Later on however when you see stuff like people get torn in halve and stabbed a lot, you come to think "oh I underestimated this show in the R Rating". Character designs are another reason I thought this series seemed very childish at first. All characters are dressed in very colorful clothing  thus not looking like the battle hardened knights of legend they are known to be.  Our main hero who is the strongest does not look like a force to be reckoned with while characters such as Ban who look bad but are the probably the most nicest of the bunch in terms of what they stand for.


The characters in SDS are a peculiar bunch of interesting faces Meliodas being our main character is a very powerful bada$$ full of mystery. He has a bit of a tragic backstory that had not been fully fleshed out. Ban who was one of the characters I liked the most is the a$$hole of the group but you come to really love him when you learn his true goal in his current affairs. I also liked the character Gowther who was more a comic relief character during his role in the show. I got to like the other characters such as King and Diane. Elizabeth I only saw as the girl who needed to be saved however and thus her character was the one I paid less attention to.


SDS was pretty good in terms of an action series. It has its high moments and thus it will be memorable.
