Hey there ! Before explaining my score, I wanna tell that it's my first review, and I'd like to apologise if my english isn't perfect too.
So what do we have ? A shonen. To be honest, I don't like shonens. A friend really wanted me to watch it, soooo I gave it a try.. What can I say ? TOTALLY WORTH IT.
Let's start !
¤ Story : 9/10
The plot, at first glance, is kinda basic, but after bunch of episodes, you'll discover that the thing is way deeper you imagined, of course I won't spoil so I can't really tell more about it. 
Though, I can'tput a 10 because sometimes, it seems like the story is quite rushed, and there are some plot holes that can be frustrating as hell. 


¤ Art : 8/10


At first, I didn't really like the art of this anime. When I saw Meliodas' face for the first time, I was like "Meh..".  But I really got used to like it, especially when they introduced characters like Ban, and some random knights because the way they look is kinda unusual, but in the good way. 

However, the animation during the battles and stuff is pretty good, I can't really say more about it D:


¤ Sound : 10/10


Nothing much to say. The voices (like Ban, Hawk) are just perfect, so what can I say?

OH YES, THE SONGS OF THIS ANIME ARE FREAKING AWESOME ! Hiroyuki Sawano and Takafumi Wada really did a wonderful job, these OST bring us in the wonderful world of Nanatsu no Taizai.


¤ Character : 11/10


Here we go, it's the thing I enjoyed the most about Nanatsu no Taizai (tho it's 10, m'kay) ! 

I mean, when I finished the anime, I figured out that I liked almost each character in this show. They're all awesome in their way. Plus, the sins all have a very interesting backstory, which make them much deeper and lovable. 


- The sins, especially Meliodas, Ban and King, have, as you could guess, a very dark and touching backstory, and you feel it everytime they appear, by the way they interact with other characters, and that, THAT IS GOLD GUYS.

- The other guys, like knighs, like Gilthunder and stuff, also have a great development, which make a lot of characters enjoyable. Of course, there will be some guys you won't even give a fuck about, but it's all about your tastes !

- Hawk. Do I need to say more ? I really don't like that kind of characters usually, but seriously, this pig made me laugh way, way too many times.  We don't even know what the hell he is doing there, but who cares?


¤ Enjoyment : 10/10


Yep, still a good mark. The thing is, I got hyped, I laughed hard, I felt bad, I nearly have tears at some part.. So yeah, this is one of the anime I enjoyed the most. This may be not a masterpiece or so, this may be not the best anime, with the best animation and the best story. But this is definitely a thing with a incredible universe and it has a lot to offer.

I rushed it in two nights, which is a thing I rarely do, but this f*cking anime really likes to put some enormous cliffhangers at the end of each episode so you want to see the next one.


¤ Overall : 9,4/10


I think I've said all I had to say. As you probably guess, I highly recommand you guys to watch this piece of treasure.

I really hope they will do a good job with the season 2 incoming next year, and I hope as well that they're going to follow the manga so it doesn't end like Tokyo Ghoul : masterpiece manga to piece of shit anime.


PS1 : Oh, don't be afraid about overpowered characters. In fact, all characters in this show are OP anyway.


PS2 : NEVER forget to watch the episodes until the end. It's kinda stupid but a lot of very important scenes were put.. after endings. Yeah, that's annoying if you're not used to watch endings.


KOTOKOTOKOTOKOTO

I honestly hadn't heard anything about this anime. I saw it as a recommendation to one of my favorite animes and decided to give it a try. I was not disappointed. I really enjoy action/adventure/fantasy/comedy and I think Nanatsu no Taizai did a good job balancing those elements. You won't find anything revolutionary from this anime but it will be a fun ride. Some of the characters are really interesting while others are very stereotypical. I am hoping for a second season.

Nanatsu no Taizai is what Fairy Tail should have been (but isn't).  It is an enjoyable series for people who loves medieval times and Arthurian legends.
For people who are wondering about the plot, then allow me to give out some details in the beginning of the episode:
The story is about seven notorious criminals who got exiled from the Kingdom of Liones after killing the Great Holy Knight Zaratras. The seven criminals disbanded and hid all over Britannia. Ten years later, the princess of Liones left the kingdom to find the seven criminals in order to seek for some help, and "that" moment all startedin a bar called the Boar's Hat...


I have said enough. The rest is up to you. ;D


Anyways, allow me to give the pros and cons of this series:


Pros:

*A lot of likable characters. Trust me, once you start watching more episodes, you'll be interested in a handful of characters.

*Plot is solid. The only major difference I can say between the Manga and the Anime is the Armor Giant Arc, and both of the versions are still great regardless.

*Amazing soundtracks. It's well done and fitting for the anime.


Cons:

*Quality of the show was poorly animated. This one isn't the show's fault, but A-1.

*Fight scenes are sub-par compared to the manga.

*MAJOR difference between the Manga and the Anime is the ending. What happened in the anime never happened in the manga. So I personally would read the manga instead.


There are some other flaws I would say about this show, but most of them are either not relevant or not appeared in the anime. Either way, this is a show I personally would recommend.

The Seven Deadly Sins follows a girl named Elizabeth the third princess of Britannia, after her father gets taken by the holy knights she is out to
find the seven deadly sins to help her save her father and save the kingdom. She meets a weird young man who owns his own tavern later she finds out he is Meliodas the Dragon Sin of Wrath the leader of the Seven Deadly Sins. She tells him what she is doing why she is trying to find the seven deadly 
sins and he agrees to go look for them. Throughout this journey they meet many hardships along theway including countless battles. As you go further\n
through the series the holy knights plan starts to become more clear as they are planning to take over the kingdom and start a holy war. They are secretly trying to bring back demons into this world to start on a new holy war. So together the sins must take down the holy knights and bring them to justice while everyone still thinks they are traitors for the events of the past but they must prevail and show that all of this was a lie. I thought this series was very well made love the concept behind it and I thought it was very well executed. With a mix of action, adventure, and fantasy this series was right up the ally of things I enjoy to watch besides Romance. The art style was very pleasing and the story line was very strong after the first few slow episodes it really picked up.

Seven Deadly Sins could have been a great anime, but there's just something...off...about it. I feel like, more than anything, the show lacks cohesion. It's one of those annoying shows that just constantly resorts to flashbacks to attempt to explain what is currently happening, and these flashbacks often happen right before the event they pertain to. I know this is very typical in anime, but here it just gives me the sense that the story is writing itself as it goes along.
It just breaks my suspension of disbelief, because it makes me painfully aware that this is a universe created out of a manga, andthe manga author kept his world as fluid as possible so that he would have no trouble cranking them out. No need to actually foreshadow anything...we'll just do it right before it happens. Why are we doing this? Well it's because of something that happened 100 years ago...let me tell you about it! Ugh. 


Also the "big reveals" on this show don't feel like big reveals, because they were NEVER foreshadowed at all. Instead of being like "WHOA, of course! that makes sense!" I just think..."huh? What? Uh, sure I guess."


Then there are the fights. It's the kind of anime where everyone is ridiculously OP and it makes for some awesome fights. From an animation standpoint they are really impressive, which is why I gave the art a 10, but while they are fun to watch, they often make zero sense. Again, it's like the author never wanted to be nailed down. There are no real ground rules or limits on any of the main character's strength, and their abilities feel random.


For instance the Grizzly Sin of Sloth, named King, has the most random powers. He can petrify people, he controls a magical spear that flies around, he has a magical pillow that can transform into different stuff, oh, and he can summon these giant vines. Alright, fine, I got it, but just when you think you understand what his capabilities are he summons a MAGICAL SHIELD out of NOWHERE. Which was clearly just because he REALLY NEEDED that shield. The fighting lost all sense of suspense and danger because it become clear very quickly that whenever one of the Sins has their back against the wall, they're just going to pull out some bullshit ability and win the day.


Then, of course, they have their "special abilities" that they call out by name. Some of them, like Full Counter, repeat often, but the majority of them don't. They're always pulling out a new trick. Like I said, there's no consistency. I always thought the point of naming an ability is so the audience could latch on to it and recognize it in the future, but if  you're never going to do it again, why bother? They should just scream out "COOL THING I'M PULLING OUT OF MY ASS" because that would be the most accurate way to describe it.


I also just can't stand Meliodas' personality. You want it summed up in a single phrase? Happy-go-lucky. That's it. That's all. He's just too one-note and it grates on me. I know there's a good story reason why he doesn't allow himself to lose his cool, but he could really use a broader range of emotions. It's kind of bad thing when the main character has the most wooden and thin personality of everyone in his gang.


In conclusion...this could have been a great anime if everything didn't feel so random and off the cuff. It's so clear that so many things where just made up on the spot that it really knocks me out of the moment and stops me from enjoying the show. If I could somehow ignore the glaring plotholes and deus ex machina I would probably really enjoy this anime, but I just can't do that. So I'm going to have to give this a 6 for now.

The first time I heard of such thing as "Netflix original anime," I could not hold back a snort. Although a fan of most original content Netflix offers, I could not combine three words together. While there are plenty of great series made in Europe, such as my personal all-time favourite Oban Star Racers, I had no faith Netflix could do a good job. To save myself time and disappointment, I decided not to bother.
A while ago, I noticed the USB cable no longer connects my phone to a computer, thus I can no longer transfer myself new episodes of anime. I have sheepishly convincedmyself I will find something online via my phone during a lunch break at work. It appeared to be more difficult than expected, and scrolling through ad-filled listings was unpleasant. Annoyed by the obvious virus sites constantly popping out as I tried to find a title of the series I had on MyAnimeList, I eventually decided to settle on something that sounded relatively familiar—Seven Deadly Sins. I was not sure if it was on my list, but the name rang a bell and so I went for it.


The beginning did not impress me a slightest bit. "Generic" was the only word that echoed through my head, as I watched endless and absolutely unnecessary ecchi scenes and had been introduced to the world's most boring characters. Apart from Hawk, of course.


Dropping the series sounded like the only solution, but my mom did not raise a quitter—instead, she brought up an OCD otaku, who must finish every damned series she starts. With a deep sigh, I carried on watching. After all, I have condemned myself to much worse shows before.


With appearance of other characters, the series was finally starting to draw me in. Although unimpressed at first, I found myself growing more and more eager to learn what the next episode had to offer. In fact, soon I even stopped noticing the irritating sexual scenes at all as my concentration was set on the story. That was when I have realized my soul had been stolen by the show I was quick to dismiss as cliché.


In my opinion, the strongest aspect of the series is its flow. The mistake most animes make is that the very first battles or small introduction stories (both are present in SDS) are forgotten as the show progresses and the original plot starts evolving. I was pleasantly surprised how Seven Deadly Sins actually included very minor characters to the main story, giving them extra screen time and somewhat of a development long after the viewer had forgotten them. What made me purr like a big fat cat was that it wasn't a one-time wonder, but has been continuously carried out throughout the series.


Another thing I give my praises to is character development. Probably not so much on the main characters who, in my opinion, had very little growth at all. I find it very interesting how creators of the anime put a much bigger emphasis on the side characters and their evolution rather than the main cast. The said evolution also resulted in great and unexpected plot twists that made me clap hands. Although far from a rookie when it comes to anime, I must admit it's the first time I've seen such approach. Normally, I would not expect it to work and the idea alone sounds mad. However, in Seven Deadly Sins it was executed so well it left me speechless.


The anime that started light and silly, filled with every cliché joke and element you could think of, was quick to start getting dark. I found myself deeply impressed how smooth this transition was, as myself I could not pinpoint it and yet it was happening. I like to believe the more serious themes started appearing around the time I found myself growing fond of the series, but again, it's just my ego demanding a few strokes.


Moving to the cons, I will once again mention character development. Although I welcome and cherish the idea of focusing on different kinds of characters, leaving the mains with close to no development should still not be a thing. Especially if, which is a serious case in Seven Deadly Sins, there is a hella annoying female character. Elizabeth is seriously everything I hate in a female antagonist and although there were brief attempts to make it seem as if she grows, till the very end she remains a damsel in distress with an overly squeaky voice. I guess being able to grope her was the only thing that made Meliodas tolerate her talking.


Few stories that are viewed as complete, especially regarding back story of the main characters, in my opinion are too rushed. With Ban and Elaine, who live through a tragic love story, I failed to suffer the pain that was meant to be inflicted on my feels. No, it did not happen because I am insensitive—in fact, I'm a notorious anime-cryer, but it was just not presented the way it should be to evoke one's feelings. It was short and clearly rushed, giving the viewer no time to actually get drawn into. At no moment I could feel the pain of the characters, it was only my common sense suggesting the story is actually very sad.


The part I have most complaints on is the end. I have spent days and days trying to figure out how I felt about it. The episode before the last was when emotions filled me so badly I was physically weeping, and I was, in fact, stressed to see how it all ends. Most series I was so into were forever ruined to me due to a stupid, ridiculous ending (I'm looking at you, Occultic;Nine), and goodness how I wished not to be disappointed. To this day, I can't tell if I am or not. It is difficult to put it in words without any spoilers, but let's just say I would be devastated if it ended the way I wanted to end, thus I am happy it ended the way it did. On the other hand, I would probably be devastated but satisfied, while now I am happy, yet rather annoyed.


Despite the cons, I still genuinely enjoyed the series, and once I've finished them I did not wait to start looking for a new season. That's when I came across Wikipedia article on Seven Deadly Sins, and for some reason decided to skim through it.


No words could describe my amazement when I saw the same three words I refused to put together: "Netflix original anime." I stared blank at the screen for nearly a minute, letting the idea to sink in. The series I liked more than the most (and I've seen a lot) were actually the ones I rejected before even giving it a try.


Lesson has been learned. The mind has been opened. All that is left now is to wait for a new season.

It's a great story for it turns out that the supposed protagonist has turned out to be the antagonist and the antagonist turns out to be the protagonist. Amazing right? The supposedly evil appears to be good and the characters with the holy name appear to be wicked. Now on it's the second season, it'll gonna be a holy war and I'm so thrilled if where will they be able to find Escanor. How will be the story end? Will it be a one-sided love for Elizabeth to the Captain ? or for Diane to the Captain? Will the seven deadly sins could match upthe power of the Commandments after they power up?\n\n

Ladies and gentlemen, we live in a world where subversion of tropes is no longer unique. I have seen and dropped many many animes that do this. Sometimes I just want to stop thinking about the flaws of a series and just enjoy it- Nanatsu no Taizai is that series. 
This season of the series mainly focuses on regrouping the Seven Deadly Sins, all of whom having their own unqiue superpowers and personalities, to beat down the Holy Knights (basically the government of this world). This premise is simple and clear, and that's good enough. This is all okay because the series focuses and excelsat enjoyment.


Take the characters for example. The characters are definitely NOT complex (well maybe exempt one), but they just make you root for them. For example, the pig Hawk's main purpose is to be the comedic relief, which I usually despise, but I am charmed by his reactions and suggestions to the way more powerful pack that is the Seven Deadly Sins. 


The original sound track, openings, and endings are just fun too. They all set up this as a tale, an adventure.


I did watch this in order to watch the second season, and I am just going to say that if you are on the borderline of watching Nanatsu no Taizai then just watch the opening of season 2.

I feel like 7 Deadly Sins is here to stay! It's an anime that has a great story from the get-go and leaves a mystery that you want desperatly answered. 
Your first opinion on the characters will be most likely false and that adds a great component of surprise and excitement.
There are many plot twists in just 24 episodes and the cut of the episodes is the one you need in order to press the button "Next Episode" (Not Dr. Dre's Song) easily.
You will love most of the characters (both good and evil) and you will shread a tear in some episodes.
The only reason Iam not giving 10 to the series is because sometimes it confuses me with the balance of power that is shown in fights. At the same time it is good cause you don't know the true limit of everyone's power, but since it confused me a bit, I gave it a 9.\n\n
Worth watching and I hope Season 2 to be as great as the first one.

Warning possible Spoilers
Since the proper second season of The Seven Deadly Sins has now started, I thought it was time to rewatch the first series to refresh my brain about it. The first time it ended up being pretty fun to watch, yet the second time it ended up being even better.
Story (9/10)
Set in early medieval Britannia, it follows a princess called Elizabeth, who is looking for the Seven Deadly Sins to help her stop the Holy Knights. Luckily she happens to accidentally encounter the Sins Captain, Meliodas.
It actually has a fairly simple story, the first half mainly has Meliodas, Elizabeth and Hawk finding theother sins, while also battling with the Holy Knights on some occasions.

But it keeps the story entertaining by concentrating a lot on the characters while also having them fight a bunch of battles, which was entertaining and fun to watch because the show gives the characters very quick development where you just like them instantly and a lot of the stuff that happens between the sins can be either hilarious or emotional because these guys have such good chemistry together in battle or having nice beer.

The second half of the story does continue with finding the sins, but once Gowther was acquired, the story really takes a shift in tone as it becomes more serious and gives us more information on the Holy War and The Holy Knights. A lot of these episodes actually focus on the big climatic battle for this series and boy is the action non-stop fun, but it also has a break from the action at points to give us some more background on the sins, It also tries to go for a Akame ga Kill vibe where the Holy Knight characters get a lot more focus and we see they aren't as connected as we first thought and they suddenly see through the lies they've been fed over the years.

The final battle also introduces on of my favourite aspects of the show and why I love it's setting, because it is set during the time of King Arthur and I really like how they have brought this myth into play.

The series also ended on a good note, the bad guy is defeated and the heroes continue on their journey, which really did open for a season 2, but it just got me hyped for the eventual second season which has finally arrived.


Characters (9/10)


Seven Deadly Sins has a huge range of characters, but it manages to balance them out very well especially the sins themselves.


Meliodas is the Captain of the Seven Deadly Sins and is the sin of Wrath, however he is probably the most laid back and chill Captain I have ever seen. However that doesn't mean you should underestimate him, because he is probably one of the most OP characters I have ever seen, but in a good way since the enemies are pretty powerful too. He's also a big pervert and tends to mess around with Elizabeth from time to time, but he also cares for his team and any civilians he comes across making him willing to sacrifice his own life to protect them.

Elizabeth is the third princess of Liones, after watching this the second time I can see why Elizabeth isn't as popular compared to the other characters, to me she isn't a bad character by far, her reasons for trying to fight and not run away are commendable, but it just becomes a drag for her character and makes her a little annoying sometimes. However in the end I still liked her character and hopefully her new powers can help develop these faults.

Diane is the sin of Envy, she is the giant of the team, no seriously and she actually ends up being the best female character of the series, because it amazes me how they make a giant girl adorable yet badass at the same time, her relationship with King also helps too as their both developed quite a lot during this season. Despite being a badass fighter, her unrequited love for Meliodas makes her a big Tsundere sometimes especially when he clings to Elizabeth which is probably her only negative, but it does work sometimes as a comedic device.

Ban is the sin of Greed, Ban is arguably the best character of the series even though I like each and every one of the sins, but Ban just kicks ass. He's that very likeable douchebag character who plays jokes and doesn't take the situation too seriously, but he is also a tormented character who has been cursed with Immortality and yearns to bring back the one he loves making him a very well rounded character, his relationship with Meliodas, King and Hawk made him such a funny character until the moment got very serious which definitely happened between him and Meliodas as the situation got a little drastic.

King is the sin of Sloth, He's actually the fairy king and is probably the most powerful member of the sins thus far just from magical power, although he's painfully the weakest when it comes to physical fights, his feelings towards Diane and the bumpy relationship he has with Ban made him a fun and relatable character even if he was a bit smug sometimes, it was also funny seeing him pop between his normal and bigger forms which always made great timing.

Gowther is the sin of lust, despite only joining the crew just after the halfway point, Gowther manages to become an instant likeable character, by being the clueless guy who doesn't really know the meanings of what the other characters say very well and his unintended jokes just end up being absolutely hilarious, he can also be a pretty creepy character especially with the power he has which mainly focuses on peoples minds.

Hawk is the sin of Scraps disposal as he likes to be called, Hawk is pretty much the talking animal character of this show, people might think Hawk is pretty annoying, but rewatching this made me realise that Hawk actually makes a lot of good points to the characters and is secretly badass at times, proving to be a bit of an underrated character, but I feel like the whole talking pig thing is leading up to something big.

Merlin the sin of Gluttony, she shows up towards the very end which does suck a little because the screentime she got, made her out to be a ruthless Mage especially considering none of the sins even dare pull a joke on her showing how feared she is.

The Holy Knights consisted of a lot of characters, but they were all memorable in  some way, well apart from a few who were just there because of how ridiculous they looked. I did like how they weren't entirely the bad guys apart from Hendrickson and Dreyfus who are the ones pulling the strings all along and tricking everyone else.


Art (9/10)


What I really liked about the artstyle in this show, has got to be the variety in the character design, because each of the sins looked awesome and different so it was pretty cool how each of them are a different race as well. The same can be said for the Holy Knights, each of their armour felt unique and really colourful albeit a few that just looked stupid.

Some of the locations looked pretty damn good too like the Fairy forest kingdom and the land of the dead looked very cool too, instead of feeling like death and misery it felt very mystic. However most of the other places just felt like they lacking, the whole countryside just doesn't feel great to look at, maybe it's because the setting is Britain and I'm British.


Sound (9/10)


Both of the ops in this anime were well done and fitted the style of the Seven Deadly Sins, the first op had the adventurous feel while the second op had the more serious vibe going as we entered the final battle.

It also provided one of my favourite ed's during the first half, which made me feel like this should've been the op because it was so catchy and fitted really well with how the characters are portrayed in the show. However the second ed just didn't do well for me and felt very lackluster after the first one.

The soundtrack is also pretty damn good, it always had the right beat when the moment felt comedic or when there was a battle going on and the main theme Perfect Time was definitely the best choice for a show like this.


Extras: 


I really enjoyed the action, it just kept getting more and more intense each time something happened and I felt like they didn't hold back either, especially when we got to the final episodes when everything is unleashed upon us, the only thing action wise or even character wise is, the show really doesn't have much of a backbone for killing off characters. With the sins it made sense, but I'm surprised how only two characters that actually made an impact died, also the names of the magic spells weren't very amazing to hear they just didn't feel like they had any omph to them and felt very simple.

This show actually has a lot of comedy and it works really well on so many levels, mainly due to the chemistry between the sins which has made them a very likeable bunch compared to other anime's who try to create a group of characters.

Now despite having Ecchi in there, it isn't too bad from what I remembered, just a bunch of groping, pantie shots and a few jiggle effects, so the usual really, but it doesn't overstay it's welcome and never becomes a big distraction. I think what kinda hurts the story a little is the amount of romance subplots, the one between Meliodas and Elizabeth just doesn't stick with me and I see them more as friends than lovers. On the other hand the ship between King and Diane is definitely one I can get behind and made them much better characters by the end, because they work so well together and every moment between them felt so cute.


Enjoyment (9/10)


Overall (9/10)


Overall this is a very entertaining fantasy, adventure anime, sure it has slight problems, but they don't impact the anime that much and I can't wait to see how season 2 ups the enjoyment factor.

Taizai greatness! This is the second time I’ve watched the show this year: once subbed and once dubbed into Spanish (thanks Netflix). I enjoyed it from the very beginning, and now that there’s a new season (or maybe a remake) coming in 2016, I just can’t wait for more of my favorite shounen. The problem is, however, how this first season ends. While the anime was almost faithful to the manga (some details all along the series were taken off during the adaptation, but it wasn’t terrible), the problem comes at the last 5 minutes, something that is indeed bad, and can put in problemsthe development our characters (especially Gowther) get in the following 20 chapters. But first, I’ll talk briefly about the anime.


(Skip to the next paragraph if you just want to read my thoughts on the ending and the new Taizai series)


Taizai the anime is a well done adaptation that can leave anyone with satisfaction once they’ve finished. If you're looking for some fun without caring about missing information and some deus ex machina plot twists, then this is the show for you.  The animation is average for A-1 pictures standards, and if you’re picky, you’re going to watch lots of off-model characters. But is nothing that will ruin the experience for you. The music is good enough to make the action scenes more compelling, and the OPs EDs are pleasant enough to watch them every time at the beginning and end of the show.


It isn’t a good stand-alone show, though, as it leave major plot holes opened by the time it ends. It’s not a problem of the writers, nor of the original creator, Nakaba Suzuki. The problem was how quick A-1 got the rights to adapt the manga. Adapting 102 episodes and finish at a point where nothing is resolved and without the certainty of a second season is dangerous for the quality if the show, and it is worst when it’s finished with an anime original conclusion.


The problem is that, as I said before, it leaves a possible 2nd season (not confirmed as of today) in a very difficult point, mostly because of the anime original ending. Major development for Gowther and very good details for the story, like the Balor’s eye or the introduction of the Pleiades knights, come right after the end of the Hendrickson arc. So the scriptwriters are in for a very good challenge if a 2nd season is indeed confirmed. In order to connect the ending of the 1st season with how the story goes in the manga without losing such important information, the most logical thing would be remake the second part of the last episode.


Although it is less likely, a remake of the complete show is another possibility, but it would be a lost of time and money in something that was, for the most time, well done and without any major flaw. And frankly, watching everything again would be boring for a lot of people as it hasn't passed much time since this anime ended.


To sum up, Taizai the anime is a great show for people who just want to have some mindless fun and don’t want to analyze every single detail of it. For or those who don’t plan to read the manga and don’t like plot holes and deux ex machinas, the show may be a lost of time. But for manga readers like me, the ending might be underwhelming and might put in danger information presented right after the last animated arc of the manga if a second season is confirmed.


So the recommendation of this show will totally depend on the tolerance of the possible viewer. To me, this show was a treat from beginning to end, and I can’t wait to see how the writers would manage to solve this big problem.

Yes, I realize that my individual scores are actually higher than my overall score, but there's a reason for this.  Seven Deadly Sins starts off great...the writing is excellent, the characters are likable, and the story is great.  Especially this last element.  This show throws you into the story without explaining whether the characters have actually done the horrible things they're rumored to have done (killing dozens of knights and attempting to overthrow the kingdom, to name the main accusations).  For a time, the viewer is allowed to judge whether or not the Seven Deadly Sins (as well as some ofthe supporting cast) are who they appear to be, and to try to figure out what their true motivations are.  I found this to be a fascinating element of the show.  I really enjoyed this show...for a while, anyway. \n\n
But there's no rating on this site for consistency, which is what this show lacks.  It has no follow-through.  The first dozen plus episodes are great, but around maybe 18 episodes in, this anime kind of takes a nose dive.  I'm making it sound like it gets awful, which it does by no means, but quality takes a major hit.  While there are some great moments towards the end of season one, the show basically becomes obsessed with the final battle between the main characters and the antagonist, and keeps building it up.  This buildup to this final fight and the fight itself must take up like 8 episodes, which is ridiculous, since that takes up a full third of season 1.  Seven Deadly Sins works really well on one to three episode arcs.  I can't really remember there being more than that before this final battle, so to have this kind of format all of a sudden really throws off the pacing of the show, and honestly, makes it boring.  I really wish a lot of animes weren't so obsessed with having this epic final battle kind of thing.  I see it so frequently, and while it can work really well sometimes, it just drags this show down to the point of boredom.  I recognize the need for some kind of major climax to the season, but again, this could have been another 3 episode arc, and it would have been great.  I would still recommend this show, but just realize that you might not find it as satisfying towards the end of the season.

Nanatsu no Taizai, what can I say?
First off, I went into this show highly skeptical considering I was of the impression that this would be retarded and a waste of my time. I believed that it would be another happy disney show about saving the princess and wahhh wahh wahh boo hoo kids flick for the romantically petrified and foreveralone mundane.
Boy was I epicly wrong. This show right here people, is one of the best in the last 10 years. I havent been this hyped watching a show since I saw Lord Lelouch is code geass from the first episode. Ill talk about every sectionlater on but if you are only reading up to this point, ill say this, do not be quick to judge lest be judged,


Now for the sectional review:


Story: 10/10


- This show is about a group of people that are dragonballz level assassins, coming together through time to try and save a kingdom under siege by an evil "group" known as the Holy Knights. The main two characters or love com, are that of the Great captain of the assassin group known as the "seven deadly sins" called Meliodas, who has a carefare personality that will either grip you at the beginning or at some point and the wonderful bonified fairy tail piece or so I thought, Elizabeth, the third princess of the empire under siege.

- As Elizabeth runs away from home, she came across this wonderful bad ass mother of all ages bonified beast Meliodas, their journey to find the rest of the assassin group comes into play and a large sequence of events occur. 

-I will not spoil the overall anime as I really wish for you to see it but I will say this, the story has no fillers, every episode has a large amount of action, and comedy and will have you rooting for at least one character from the beginning to the end. This show is what I wanted other so called "top brass" anime to be like. It will not in anyway bore you and It certainly is not a Disney flick for kids of all ages. This show is for a mature mind, meaning if you believe an adolescent is smart enough to understand the events of the show then they may watch it as there is blood and gore in this show so dont permit children under 12 to watch this thank you.


-Art


Regarding the art, it has a similar feel to that of fairy tail before 2014 thank you very much. The design of the world is marvelous and truly makes you feel as if you are a citizen of the kingdom and fellow lands and engulfs your mind into a fantasy like no other. The last anime that had me batcrap crazy like this was sword art online first season thank you very much. Anyways yeah, there is modern day art that would hurt your eyes to watch and the comparison of fairy tail design should give you a decent perspective as to what this anime's art is all about.


Character


- Regarding the characters, I believe the anime team and the author definitely got this section on track as one of the best anime to ever have such a proper level of character development. Truly, I was in awe when I found out about each Sinners story and in the words of one of them:" A sin is only something that you cannot ever erase." I was brought to tears by every single one of their pasts and it is so immense as to how a human being can endure their pain and have so much life to live for. The show makes you truly think as you watch as to what "sin" really is? Who can truly judge sin? And as you watch you will understand that only the one who made you can as there are some religious perspectives in this so it tests your beliefs as well. Oh my god, the feels ugh. Definitely good character development. Anyone who watches this with an open mind will be able to find at least one character to feel that they are similar to as it is that vast. Damn.


-Enjoyment


As you can obviously see if you are still reading this review, you can tell how much I loved this anime. Ive watched a lot of anime in my time and this definitely is at the top of my list. So damn good, they packed so much genre in here it had me mind messed. If there is anything that I am disappointed with regarding this anime, it is that it might not have another season. This is Code Geass level people. Beautiful. I hope yall enjoyed my review and peace. Love yall. 


Final verdict:


9.3/10

*** Spoiler Alert,  but not really,  but in case someone is a stickler***          
           As my inputs on the 5 point rating system go,  The Seven Deadly Sins score an 8.8 that I will most definitely round up to a nine.  The power of maths compels me,  the power of maths....  you get it.
            The summary provided by MAL, and every other anime site,kind of points you in the right direction for the story; but its so vague you don't really quite know what you are signing up for.  The show itself goes way beyond the summary and you really don't get a proper taste of the vast world contained by the anime.  Seven Deadly Sins is full of growing plots  and very well placed insights to character backstories that all pair together for a wonderful 24 episode adventure.  This particular anime is down right littered with cliffhangers,  so praise the gods its already a completed series.   I personally would have absolutely died not being able to watch one episode after the other.  So my heart goes out to all who endured the struggle during its release.   With a variety of landscapes and scenarios, and the constant character development; this show will easily steal your consciousness and demand a binge.  You have been warned.  I give this fable a [9/10] for story.



     The animation is a little above average at best.   However, it was also consistent for 24 episodes.  No matter the characters introduced or the changes in landscape, there was never a dip in animation quality, earning it an [7/10] for art. 


    The first 12 episodes had an amazing OP and ED.  Like damn those were some tasty jams.  The second cour not so much.  Even with the final 12 episodes failing in the soundtrack department,  I am happy to still give the sound a 9.  Cause the dub work on this anime was more than satisfactory, and good dubs is hard to find. If you are a dub only anime fan,  don't forget to add the seven deadly sins to your watch list. 



    Characters:  Well being dubbed the seven deadly sins does kind of give the viewer a misleading introduction.   You expect these vile beings,  just to discover the Sins are very similar to the call signs of fighter pilots.  Maverick and Goose?  Nay,  Wrath and Greed bitches.  Welcome to the danger zone.  While each having their own tropes and archetypes,  the diversity of the people in Nanatsu no Taizai will lead you to a believable concept that they are in a big wide world with a vast history.  I found myself personally not hating any of the characters in this show,  villains included.   So that's a top gunned [9/10] in the character department.



  Did I enjoy this anime?...   well did I?     I binge watched it in a single day.  Ass glued to the sofa and eyes dried by my intense reception of this animated pleasure.  Personal Enjoyment [10/10] 



            As always your anime pal Grizzziff Kingsbeard coaches moderation in all things.   Do as I say and not as I do; but if you find yourself wanting to kill some free time, whether a few hours at a time or a whole day at once,  then The Seven Deadly Sins isn't a bad way to go about it.   Highly recommend in either the sub or Dub formant, cant go wrong either way.

The Seven Deadly Sins is a show I'd tell people I like, but to be honest, I'm a bit conflicted about it. My first time watching through it, I considered it really enjoyable and exciting! But rewatchng some of it, I see quite a bit of flaws and things I kind of glossed over the first time around.
Story-7
*contains light spoilers*
The story starts of on a very exciting note. On episode 1, we open up on a kingdom in ruins, immediately creating a sense of tension and curiosity. Then we get to a tavern, where we are introduced to some quirky characters like Melodias and Hawk,and hear rumors and chatter about the titular Seven Deadly Sins, when a silent armored figure enters. This person is revealed to be Elizabeth, the princess of the Liones kingdom. After seeing Elizabeth's unflattering clothes from under the armor, Melodias gives her the rather promiscuous, Boar Hat female uniform. Then, holy nights come looking for Melodias. Melodias slays them all with his interesting broken sword. Melodias the reveals himself to Elizabeth as the captain of the Seven Deadly Sins. The subsequent episode manages to keep up the excitement from the first and establishes what seems to be a main antagonist. Episode 3 and 4 start to drag a lot though, and are mostly to set up more characters and future events. The pace of the story does start to pick up though as more sins are re-recruited, until we get to the first major arc, The Necropolis arc. Which, believe it or not was my favorite part of the show. Characters like Ban and King have a lot of time to develop during this arc, which is a pretty good thing. Up until this arc, it's easy to see Ban as just a jerk and selfish. But through flashbacks and events that take place in this arc, you realize that not everything is black and white with him. He always had some level of selfishness to him, but there are people like Elaine and places like the Fairy Forrest that he genuinely cares for and tries to protect.He even is willing to sacrifice his life for the sins. And as the story goes on, Ban's existence seems painful...and this could just be his way of taking it out. King also kicks ass and proves to be valuable to the team. However, the best arc of the show is quickly followed up with the worst arc, the Vaizel Fighting Festival. I was actually pretty excited for this arc of the show because tournament arcs can sometimes have the potential to be one of, if not, the best arcs of the show. Heck, just look at the Dark Tournament arc from YuYu Hakusho, and a lot of people get hooked on Naruto after the Chunin Exam arc. They have the potential to have amazing fights, putting an end to rivalries, and overall, just proving who's the best. However, instead of doing most of this, The Seven Deadly Sins just uses this arc as a platform to introduce a TON of new major characters, story elements, backstories, ect. to the audience. Now, I wouldn't have a problem with this if they were able to do all of that and have good fights, but that's not what happens. Most of the fights are literally happen just to show us gags (Diane vs. Griamore, King vs. Cain) or flashbacks (Melodias vs. Cain, and Melodias vs Ban to some extent). Speaking of Melodias vs. Ban, that was definitely the most disappointing fight. In forms of fight choreography, what they do with it is fine. There are a couple cool sequences, like when Melodias and Ban start flipping each other, and when Melodias and Ban punch each other's fists, and Melodias' fist makes Ban's fist curl back which lets him hit Ban's gut, however, you have two characters fighting who are established to be...practically immortal! We've seen King drill a giant hole into Ban's upper torso with his Chastiefol, and have had Ban come out perfectly fine, but they don't even go that far in this fight. I was expecting Melodias and Ban really tearing into each other! Instead it just ends with powers and abilities that haven't been previously set up in the series and more foreshadowing.There's not even any tension going on during the tournament. Except for Griamore, who Diane defeats in the first round, there's no one who poses a threat! Instead, most of the tension comes within running the risk that the holy nights could find out that the Seven Deadly Sins are back together and out in the open. Although, after Melodias and Ban's fight, which almost splits the battlefield in half, you start to wonder if their even trying to hide it anymore. Thankfully, the last two arcs do the series justice. The Armored Giant arc has a nice heartwarming ending and prepares all the characters for the final arc. And the last arc, The Kingdom Infiltration arc, is in my opinion, a great way to end the show. Everything ties together very nicely and we're actually explained some things that have remained pretty elusive throughout the whole show like why Melodias' broken sword is so important to the government, why King was absent from the Fairy Forrest when Ban was, Diane's backstory,and who Elizabeth really is. There are also some pretty good fights and I really enjoyed the ending. It kind of reminds me of the ending of Dragonball Z, where all of the characters use their power all at once to defeat the villian.


One thing I didn't really like about The Seven Deadly Sin's story though is that they kind of steal a bunch of plot points or aspects from other shonen series and try to retool them to get them to work into their story. You can obviously tell from the visuals that TSO takes more than a little influence from Fairy Tail but they also take a little more than that as well. Just like in Fairy Tail, there's a hot teenage girl who wants to be independent and a part of the team, like Lucy. There's demon blood, a quick and easy resource to turn failed knights into the strongest of holy knights referred to as a new generation, just like the wizards in Fairy Tail who were implanted with dragon lacrimas to become a new generation of dragon slayers. There's also this confusing magical circle where a bunch of holy knights stand around and trade powers with each other, which gives the respective hero of that holy knight that specific power to temporary use in battle (The show doesn't explain it that well but it makes sense when you see it) but the point is, looks exactly like the magical council meetings from Fairy Tail!!! Not only that, but they also take a surprising amount of influence from One Piece as well! From Melodias and Ban having a tradition of arm wrestling, to the last scene of the show resembling the end of the Alabasta arc a little too closely (Except in this show, the princess gets what she wants) it's a little blatant. Thankfully, they do try to retool these concepts enough so it doesn't feel tired, and they're pretty spread out across the show.


Characters-6


The characters are a bit of a mixed bag, but I find about half of them to be generally enjoyable


Melodias= Melodias is the captain of the sins and represents the dragon sin, wraith. However, that doesn't really fit his personality at all. In fact, wikipedia even says "despite being called the sin of wraith, Melodias acts more like a mellow trickster who is often seen fondling over Elizabeth one way or another". In fact, at the start of the series, I thought he would probably represent the goat sin, lust, as he dresses Elizabeth in skimpy clothes and gropes her for the sake of comedy. Throughout most of the show, he is pretty laid back. Which is pretty rare for most shonen protagonist and certainly sets him apart. However, Melodias' laid back attitude kind of pisses me off sometimes. It can sometimes come off as him not really caring about what's going and kill tension in a scene. Later on in the show when we learn about his past, his personality starts to make a little more sense. Maybe he's just bored cuz he's been through so much that this adventure isn't as exciting as it is to Elizabeth, or the writers may be trying to subvert our expectations. Y'know, him being the representation of wrath but really acting mellow. And that is an interesting idea to try to subvert. There are a lot of other anime like Fullmetal Alchemist or Trinity Seven that create personifications out of the seven deadly sins, however it's all in the execution. And I don't think they exactly accomplished what they were going for. I love this kid's character design though. The saggy looking vest and tie just look perfect for the protagonist of an adventure series.


Elizabeth= Elizabeth is a character I loved the first time watching The Seven Deadly Sins. But now that I've really analyzed the show, I don't think she's really as great as I remembered. Elizabeth is a princess from the Liones kingdom, who ran away from home to find the Seven Deadly Sins so they can resolve turmoil going on in the kingdom. Elizabeth is kinda just the character that tags around while the sins do all the heroic work. However, she does try and make herself useful, which is what brought me to start to like her character. She always puts herself in harms way if it means helping the sins and she actually saves them all at the end of the series. However, she still does come off as weak even after saving the sins. She still lets Melodias grope her and she never actually fights along side the sins. To me, she's kind of like a poor man's Lucy Heartfilia. A teenage girl who stands by and tries to help a team of powerful heroes, while also gaining independence from her father while still looking really good. However, I consider Lucy a more dynamic and likable character because she worked hard with her friends to become stronger, and eventually could hold her own just like the others in Natsu's team, and she didn't aspire for anything less than that. She had confidence to rise above her father and his obsession of money and trivial things, and carved out her own identity by becoming a member of Fairy Tail. When Elizabeth tries to help the sins, it feels like she's just kinda half-assing it, or doesn't want to risk actually fighting. She is against violent conflict, but she doesn't make an attempt to get around having to hurt people or stop the sins from doing it. In the end, she's alright.


Ban- Ban represents the fox sin, greed. He's a pretty cool character and a fan favorite for most. And I can certainly see why. Ban is probably the most vicious looking of the sins, with his fangs, scars, and bloody eyes. He can also be incredibly ruthless, willing to kill his own teammates. But he also has somewhat of a sweet side, I won't spoil it. His red coat and pants with spikes also kind of reminds of late 80's and early 90's rock fashion which is pretty interesting. The only thing I don't really like about him is that, like Melodias, I don't think he really represents his sins well. When Ban is first introduced in the series, I thought he was going to represent lust because of his interesting fashion sense. I know I've said that twice but I'm seriously not kidding XD And yeah, his powers do have to do with greed, but aside from in flashbacks, nothing about his personality screams "greed!". He's not even like Melodias where they may be trying to subvert the audience's expectations. For what he's though, I think Ban is a pretty good character.


Diane- Wow! A character who actually has characteristics and a personality that their sin represents!? I can't tell if this was intentional or they weren't trying to be subversive but they actually did it! Diane, the serpent sin, envy. Diane is pretty different compared to a lot of the characters as well, in the way that she is a giant. She's fierce, strong, and can also turn her body into iron. However, being a giant comes with it's drawbacks.Diane constantly feels lonely because humans discriminate against her, and also, she has a crush on Melodias. But do to her size, she's not often able to comfort him while he's inside of buildings or hospitals. So she comes to envy the humans. Diane can be pretty interesting on occasion. But most of the time, it's just her gawking over the captain. I find Diane to be annoying most of the time and she certainly isn't my favorite of the sins. 


King- King, the grizzly sin, laziness. King, surprisingly, is another character who actually represents his sin quite well. Actually even better than Diane. Unlike Diane, who's personality was only designed around envy, King's entire character design definitely had laziness in mind. He wears a hoodie and sits on a floating pillow. Nice to see you guys go all the way for one character. King is often pretty laid back, although he can occasionally butt heads with Ban. He also is in love with Diane which creates a love triangle. King's a pretty serviceable character. That's all I got.


Gowther- The goat sin, lust. Well after I already through two characters in this series were lust, this one must really stand out right? Not really. Next to King, she's probably wearing the most clothes of the sins. She's also very plain and most of her powers involve controlling minds, which isn't as interesting as it sounds. Maybe she was supposed to be subversive too. Either way, she's still my least favorite of the sins. 


Other Characters: I actually found myself liking a lot of the side villains. There's a lot of conflict within the Kingdom of Liones which leads to some interesting debates between the holy knights. And the holy nights aren't portrayed as being evil and irredeemable. There are some knights that are just doing this for the sake of their families. This is something I haven't seen in a shonen in a long time and I was glad to see this incorporated here.


Animation-8


Not going to touch on this much since I mostly focused on Story and Characters, but the animation is pretty nice. It's got that overly glossy look we've come to expect from A-1 Picture's shows, which I generally don't like. However in the Seven Deadly Sins, I think it actually works. I'm not really sure how to explain why, but it just does. Also, I like the attention to detail, like the strands of Elizabeth's hair. Nothing really more for me to comment on.


Enjoyment-9


Extremely enjoyable!! Well paced and great for binge watching!


Overall-6


I think a 6 is a pretty appropriate rating for the Seven Deadly. It's a wildly enjoyable series that I always love watching!! I feel really attached to characters like Elizabeth, Ban, King and way more. However, objectively, I'd say it's just above average. It has some good ideas, but trouble executing them. It can also be moving too fast or too slow. And the Fighting Festival will always suck. I would seriously recommend this if you love shonen, specifically ones that take place in Celtic settings and want a quick watch. If not, I think it's okay to skip this one. I'm seriously interested to see what happens in season 2 coming this January!

When watching this show, I found I missed (for some reason) the "let's make the protagonist the most powerful person ever" shtick found in shows like Sword Art Online. However, The Seven Deadly Sins manage this nothing like they do with Kirito in SAO. They seem to make *every* main character (both villain and hero) super overpowered so it all kinda balances out. This makes it surprisingly more enjoyable than you may think, as the fight scenes become quite spectacular - especially near the end. 
I'm giving this show an 8 because, although it is quite an extraordinary show, the repetitive "sexual references" (as Netflixput it) definitely don't help its case. The excessive boob and ass gropes from the main male protagonist (redacting name for spoiler reasons) are annoying and unnecessary, but are too low frequency for it to put me off watching the show.

In a medieval world of magic, the Holy Knights are the tyrannical rulers of the Kingdom of Liones. Their rule is now threatened by their former allies whom they betrayed known as the Seven Deadly Sins, who are beginning to reappear throughout the land. 
Seven Deadly Sins is a solid shonen battle anime. It has what you would expect with many cool powers, fights, colorful characters, and a balance of funny and serious moments. This anime is a little too swayed in the direction of humor for my taste, though I am sure many others would enjoy this. 
The anime itself is decent is mostregards. Decent plot, decent worldbuilding, decent actions. Some aspects were even bad in my opinion, with the comedy not landing well with its atmosphere or being very funny and the animation being average. The characters at first felt decent at best, though I will admit I was surprised with the characterization and character development we see with each of our characters throughout the story. These characters are fun and entertaining, but also have deep backstories behind them. The characters arent amazing, but they are I would say they are good. \n\n
The story itself isnt very intersting up until the last 8 episodes of the 25 episodes which were great and my favorite part of the series. I hope this series continues with the serious tension and atmosphere in season 2, at least for the important arcs. \n\n
Overall, I would recommend Seven Deadly Sins if you enjoy shonen battle series and are looking for a recent one to watch. This anime isnt anything great or groudbreaking, but it might be a better alternative to some of the other shonen battle series airing recently. I have a feeling fans of One Piece and Fairy Tail would enjoy this since they will be able to get past the goofiness.

Inconsistent, sometimes the characters feel invincible, other times they seem unreasonably weak. Too much sexual harassment toward the women in this series, the story would not have suffered at all if they took all of it out. No boob-squeezing, no panty-stealing, and I'd have liked this series all that much more. Sometimes I fell out of the loop, confused by where the story was going. Decisions seem to be made without thought, fairly randomly. Like, ask "How did that happen?" and the show answers back "Don't worry about it, just accept this nonsense and keep watching."
Despite that, I've enjoyed watching the show, it's pretty good.

Oh my christ I can't believe some comments and actual reviews of people being amazed by the plot , the music , interactions and characters. Im going to just throw all thoughts out so this will definitely be more for a rant than a review. *Contains spoilers*
Where do I begin?
Uninspired basic-level dialogue and typical cliches throughout 24 episodes? Check.
Lack of any memorable music? Check.
Lack of understanding on how to pace the animation and story well? Check.
Random backstories of characters we have seen for literally 5 total minutes, that "die" (whether its true death or they just come back later because "happy ending") that main charactersget emotional about, for 3 good minutes until they stop crying and then give inspirational speeches with happy faces? F*CKING CHECK! (?????)


Plot of backstories? Absolutely generic , ZERO exceptions. CHECK


Main plot? No matter how good of a story you might have on paper, if you're not good at presenting it it will definitely go to waste, while i still believe its mostly uninspired , as in its not innovative at all, and at various parts doesn't make a lot of sense. I still believe they could've done a better job at it:


They tried countless times to make you give a shit about characters no one should ever give a fuck with how little they were presented or how basic their backstories were and how fast it flew by giving zero time for it to sink in. Bad guys that have zero reason to help eachother yet they still do it regardless. For no good reason 9.9 out of 10 "Holy knights" apparently are corrupt to the bone not giving a shit about anyone and cant for a single second see the evil around them, this is  thrown in your face for 23 episodes until on the last one everyone is "very sorry , we strayed away from our path" and all is forgiven because now all these guys are going to rebuild the kingdom , hooray.


Main characters? Well there's a few that can be likeable honestly , what they mostly have going for them is cheap-vague mysteriousness that the more they dive in their past the more they prove how vague they are. The main female protagonist that motivates the group to reuinite has a bad case of orihime-chan multiplied by 10. The main protagonist , meliodas, can't be bothered to give a shit up until his close ones are in true trouble , typically gets beat up over and over and over again in the midst to come back either healed or determined to win ZZZzzzz.. As in for their main mascot "hawk" a talking pig they have around with them has to be one of the most pointless and annoying characters of them all that they also expect you to give a shit near the end where it supposedly dies by tanking a huge attack that would've "finished off" the good guys and next episodes gets revived because of , literal explanation by the pig "its a mystery". Yeah what a surprise , vague as ever.


Enemies? Throughout the entire anime nobody ever poses them an actual threat till the very end where you know they'll win to conclude the story. The few times they try to throw someone supposedly strong its blatant as hell they were never a threat.


Fights? "You stand no chance against me! Seven deadly sin member!" -> "How can someone be this strong?" -> "So this is the true power of the deadly sins, wouldn't expect less"  -> "Loses or ends up siding with them later on" or "Guy 1: I bet you didnt expect that attack" , "Guy 2: I did , i bet you didnt expect this attack" , "Guy 1 gasps in surprise and gets hit". Seriously, fuck you.


So what the actual fuck does this anime do right? Beats me, I guess cliches do their work and the fact that they approach things in such a vague way i guess makes people try to think deep into it as they theorize in their minds to justify enjoying this rollercoaster of nonsense. Maybe its the harem scenes/jokes they throw every 1-2 episodes or so. What a great accomplishment. I SHIT YOU NOT , THE ONLY THING THIS ANIME GETS CONSISTENTLY RIGHT WHICH IS THE FUNNIEST THING , IS MAKING ABSOLUTELY SURE THAT WHENEVER A FEMALE CHARACTER'S CLOTHES GETS TORN,THAT UNTIL THEY CAN GET THEIR HANDS ON NEW CLOTHES, IN EVERY UPCOMING SCENE , WHETHER THEY ARE TEMPORARILY DEFEATED , OR IN THE BACKGROUND , OR DURING VICTORY MOMENTS , THAT THEY NEVER MESS UP THAT DETAIL DOWN TO THE PIXEL. LOL WELL DONE ON THAT FOLKS! PUTTING ATTENTION WHERE ITS WORTH WHILE EVERYTHING ELSE IS FALLING APART


Well, jokes aside (Even  though that really actually happens in disturbingly funny detail), the popularity probably mostly comes from the flashiness of the fights. While the pacing and generic reactions of characters makes the fights less enjoyable , combined with the fact that most of the attacks seem more random than memorable with few exceptions. You have your typical shonen fast paced attacks and your large scale powerful ones so I can see how it can grab attention in that department , while the pacing is as i've said numerous times is bad , the animation is pretty alright for 2014 standards. Anything other good than that  i would probably say its the background art. If you're into medieval fantasy worlds i would say its pretty pleasing.


Conclussion:


If your argument is going to be: "Well its a shounen , what do you expect?". This isn't an argument. 


While even classics or popular shounens can have what you would typically expect from this genre they make sure to deliver it right and in some department stand out from the rest in a unique way. Seven deadly sins so far severely lacks that. It feels like a mass of ambiguous ideas grabbed from right and left put together with little effort to be original, innovative or smart and for that i'll be giving it a generous 4.


If you want to approach this in the most enjoyable way despite all my personal opinions , go into this anime with the very least expectations, expect things to sort of be generic and take it lightly for what it is. Otherwise something should definitely tick you off episode by episode, well atleast assuming you have any standards at all and you can see things in a larger scope. Atleast that's my subjective opinion. Apologises for the long rant , thanks for listening.

Nanatsu no Taizai, Seven Deadly Sins in English, is a shounen anime that should have been seinen. It suffers greatly because of its aimed demographics, and brings about a lot of head scratches along the way. It's unfortunate mainly because its foundations are quite superb, only to be dwindled down by the constraints of its own "genre". 
TL;DR - pros/cons 
+ Amazing production values
+ Huge cast of diverse characters
+ Interesting main cast (for the most part)
+ Well set-up world
+ Diversity in powers gives space for huge opportunities 
+ A whole lot of space to expand (other Kingdoms, worlds etc.)
- Very badly executed story
- Ending isterrible 

- Main villain is neither interesting nor intimidating 

- Fuckton of asspulls 

- Most of the side characters are pointless and go nowhere 

- Very little is know about majority of main cast 

- More than a few dull moments before the final arc



Story in NnT follows Princess Elizabeth on her quest to reunite Seven Deadly Sins, Kingdom's strongest Holy Knights who are believed to have betrayed the Kingdom ten years ago. Initial setup works well, as it presents clear goal and a path of adventure. Its initial characters spark up the charm, and the mystery behind each of the Seven keeps you going. Unfortunately, somewhere along the line, it turns into a ... mess. You know, that generic plotline of "dude wishes for power so he combines with gods or whatever". That can work if executed well, but here, however, it was executed quite poorly. Story suffers massively from its own incapability to cope with its rules within universe, and relies upon random asspulls to salvage the concurrent plot. The vision is there, and is clearly present at the start, yet it is lost somewhere along the way. 


I'll explain my first sentence in a little bit of a detail here, as the story suffers the most from it (possible minor spoilers ahead, so read at your own risk): the author seemed to think that by making it shounen, he couldn't pull out actual heartbreaking moments and instead gives us unsatisfying endings all over the place, overdrawn subplots that end abruptly, and a whole fuckton of asspulls, especially towards the end. If you want an example, think of a climax of Berserk's Golden Age Arc, but instead of playing out as it did, imagine if nobody died - that's NnT in a nutshell. Forming deep bonds that are tempered by death is nigh impossible here because you know no one within the main cast will die. 


Another bad point of the story is the final arc - which in itself drew my initial score of the anime from 7 to 6. It's absurd on so many levels I don't know where to being. As I previously said, aside from the generic villain plotline, a bunch of new random shit is introduced out of nowhere without any prior mention, and even things that were mentioned previously were mentioned maybe 1 episode before that very thing miraculously spawned within the world. Ultimately, what this anime turns into towards the end is literally asspull galore, as a bunch of new and random powers and connections are introduced out of nowhere, numbing down my enjoyment greatly. I can't go into detail because I don't want to spoil it, but it gets cringe-worthy by the last episode, and that's not a feeling your story should invoke. 


Ultimately, though, I stand by my initial statement: that the anime was ruined simply because of the demographic it was aimed at. It would have served it far better if it held deep and mature story with realistic stakes, fleshed out rules of the world, removing its pointless asspulls completely. I feel that most of the things that were actually resolved via asspulls could have been handled so much better, and that's only using things that were already present in the story. 


On the other hand, anime looks and sounds gorgeous. It's colorful and there's rarely a dull moment in colors. Action varies from good to amazing, and there's enough diversity within the powers of Holy Knights to always showcase something new and amazing. Movements feel fluid and natural, and I was particularly impressed by fist fights in this anime, as they really were able to get my adrenaline going. The designs of the characters, creatures as well as the world are exceptional. They're varied enough for you not to get bored, but you'll still find yourself finding similarities between them. The whole anime is colorful and it never really dulls its own color pallet for the sake of "artistry", and that's something I appreciate. 


It's been awhile since I've heard some good soundtrack in anime - surprisingly. The score of NnT is amazing, and definitely one of the high points of the whole thing. Openings and endings were done well, especially the first one, and the whole ambiance within each different zone really captures the feel. When it comes to voice acting, it can be a hit or miss, but for the most part it holds itself up. Another impressive feat here is the array of special effects for each special and not-so-special attack, as they really do vary it up. Sadly, production really is the peak of this anime, so props to A-1 on this one. 


With the huge cast of characters that NnT boasts, it's obvious there's going to be good ones, bad ones and ... well, ugly ones. Elizabeth is your everyday cookie-cutter sheltered princess who goes on a journey and develops "strength" to fight for her friends. She seems more like a fodder than an actual character, as very little is actually done with her. In a nutshell, she's your lovely airhead princess with big boobs. 


Out of the Seven Deadly Sins (well, Six), I actually enjoyed majority of them - some more than others, Ban probably being the highlight. Unfortunately, aside from Ban, King, Diane and, to a very small extent, Mel, we know very little of who the hell are these people. This is what holds the characters back immensely and it's mainly because the anime focuses far too much on its generic villain subplot and overall theme of "Holy Knights are actually evil, kyaaaah!" rather than developing its characters properly. My least favorite of Six is probably Mel, followed closely by Diane. Although Mel really is a badass character when it comes to fighting, he's your masked shounen lead. Sure, he has his moments, but there were far too many times I've wanted to punch him in the head for those moments to overshadow it. 


Aside from them, there's, as I said, a whole fuckton of side characters, most of which you really don't care for. Quite a large number of them are used mainly as drama fodder and plot devices, so you shouldn't really get your hopes up. 


Villain of the series is bad - not as he's bad in the sense of evil, he's just boring. Up until the very end, you have no idea what his motives are - yeah, there are hints "the start of the Holy War, release this, I gotta drink it to match them etc.", but they're just boring excuses. He's not charming, he's not interesting, he's even dull looking, and, quite frankly, he's not even badass as the ultimate enemy. His mega move is making some purple shit snow and then gathering it in one spot for like 30 seconds while everyone else around him sits and drools in awe. Good job ye Holy Knights. 


I'd lie if I said I didn't enjoy Nanatsu no Taizai. However, I'd also lie if I said I was never bothered by its lackluster story and overabundance of pointless characters that go nowhere. If you exclude last 3-4 episodes, this show would definitely get 7, even bordering 8, however its ending is really, really good example of why you need to have an idea of your ending before you write it, because you can't use asspulls to save your story over and over again. 


It's a fun watch, and if you're not a nitpicker like me, you'll probably get far more out of NnT than I did - and even I got plenty.

Nanatsu No Taizai (Seven Deadly Sins) is a great example of how an anime with basically no original material can still be enjoyable. 
The story in itself is your average 'girl on a quest' routine. You can see subtle and not so subtle glimpses of elements borrowed from animes like Full Metal Alchemist, Fushigi Yugi, Naruto, the list goes on. However, what makes this show so much more enjoyable is the characterization of the Seven Sins. Each one of them is unique in demeanor and even species and while there are your quintessential team idiosyncracies, it never gets too repetitive or too dumb. 
The highlightof the show is, of course, the action. The sequences are not too long, nor too short and the balance between exposition and fighting is great. On the whole, this is the kind of limited series anime that you can binge watch over a weekend, and while you know you haven't seen anything truly spectacular you'll not feel it was a waste of your time either.

I did not plan on watching this anime at all. After discovering the show on Netflix, I decided to watch the first episode because of how bored I was and my brother was annoying the hell out of me so I needed something to watch. Now that I have finished watching the show...... 
(There will be SPOILERS in my review)
[Story]: (7/10) (SPOILERS)
Based on the best-selling manga series of the same name, Nanatsu no Taizai follows the adventures of Elizabeth, the third princess of the Kingdom of Liones, and her search for the Seven Deadly Sins. With their help, she endeavors to not only take backher kingdom from the Holy Knights, but to also seek justice in an unjust world.


I don't watch a lot of Shounen shows because it's purely fighting scenes and lacks dialogue scenes. It seems to appeal to brain dead viewers out there, hence the reason why the big 3 animes are all Shounen. I don't hate the genre, I just don't love it as much as the other genres out there like mystery or psychological animes or whatever. However, there are some Shounen genres out there that I love but I won't mention the show's name. "The Seven Deadly Sins" is now one of the Shounen animes that I love and I personally think it's better than most Shounen shows out there. 


In my opinion, "The Seven Deadly Sin's" story is....not the greatest. It's fairly generic, to say the least. The first half is just them searching for the members of the Seven Deadly Sins and the second half is "princess gets kidnapped and she must be saved". You don't need to be a smart-ass to figure out the story. 


What you do need is an above-average working brain or maybe an average working brain will do. By the time you reach the second half of the show, you will experience a lot of plot twists. Most of this plot twists are downright ridiculous because to me, it looks like the twists were pulled right out of their ass. From Meliodas being part of the Demon Race to Gilthunder who turns out he was being manipulated by some Holy Knight (forgot her name) and he was actually a good guy all along. There are a lot of plot twists and you need to prepare your brain when that happens. 


The show also contains an insane amount of plot holes. While I was watching the show, I noticed the show's plot holes were piling up but I ignored them because I thought they were all going to get answered by the 2nd half of the show or at the end. Some of them were answered but most of them weren't. For example, Meliodas' "OverPowered Demon Mode" which occurs when he's at a disadvantage. This really bothered me because it kept happening to him when he was about to die and I really really wanted to know why this was happening to him in the first place. When a character goes all OP mode, I want to know why it's happening to that character or else it's all just pure bullshit to me. Luckily, the show is going to get a second season next year so I'm willing to forgive the first season's plot holes as long as they answer them in the upcoming second season. 


The show's pacing is somewhat rushed. I mean, this shouldn't be a surprised if you've seen over 2 or 3 A-1 Pictures anime. If you didn't know, A-1 Pictures likes to rush their anime for whatever reason. This is why when I see an A-1 Pictures anime, I think long and hard whether to watch the show or not. Thank God the anime is not rushed, to the point where it will be hard to understand what's going on. 


Two more things that I want to talk about. First, the show's fanservice. What in the bloody f*cking hell is up with A-1 Pictures, along with the author and the fanservice?
