The protagonist of the show constantly touches, gropes and harasses (not rape) the princess and the princess constantly forgives him like it's nothing. It'd be ok if it was a minor fanservice scene but it's not. It kept happening every episode. It turned from a humour fanservice scene to a distracting fanservice scene. My mom even asked me why I was watching a goddamn kid rape a young adult lady. *sigh* The explanations that I have to come up with just so she can leave me alone.  Anyways. You will notice that the fanservice is almost non-existant in the second half of the show as it switches from light-hearted story to dark and serious tone. 


Last thing that I want to talk about will answer the question that you have right now. If you're going to ask me why I rated the show a 8 even though I just mentioned all the flaws then here are my reasons. Firstly, the glorious fight scenes which I will talk about in the "Animation" category. Secondly, unlike most shounen shows out there which contains a lot of goddamn fucking fillers, The Seven Deadly Sins contains little to no fillers. When the arc is done, the show moves on to another arc. This prevented me from getting bored at the show. Third and lastly, the characters are surprisingly better than the story itself. I'll talk more about the characters in the "Characters" category. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Art/Animation]: (9.3/10)

If you have seen an A-1 Pictures anime before then you should be familiar with the animation. It's very similar in terms of visual and character designs. However, there is one difference when comparing this show's animation to other A-1 Pictures show's animation. I'm talking about the fight scenes. I'm very surprised at how smooth the fight scenes are and this is coming from the studio who also created Fairy Tail and Sword Art Online. If you have seen those two shows before then you should know that the fight/action scenes in both of those shows weren't that smooth. They were, for the most part, choppy and there were some still animation. In the Seven Deadly Sins, the choppiness is almost non-existent and the still animation barely exists. It's probably because of the year gap but whatever, that doesn't matter.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Sound]: (9/10)

The show did not disappoint in the "Sound" department. The OST's are f*cking awesome to listen to and the battle themes are glorious. It perfectly fits with the action scenes. I'm now moving on to the OP and ED theme songs because the majority of the score for sound comes from the OP and ED theme. 


The OP theme songs are "Netsujou no Spectrum" by Ikimono-gakari and "Seven Deadly Sins" by MAN WITH A MISSION. I'm the probably the only person here who did not like the 1st OP theme song. The singer's voice is annoying as hell. However, I.freaking.LOVE! the 2nd OP theme song. When I first heard the song, I didn't even know the guy was singing mostly in English. The singer's accent is so heavy. After 2 episodes, I fell in love with the 2nd OP theme song. It sounds amazing and the transition from English to Japanese gives me goosebumps. I really really hate Engrish songs *ahem Mirai Nikki OP 2 ahem* but this is one of those Engrish songs that I love. 

The ED theme songs are "7 -seven-" by FLOW x GRANRODEO and "Season" by Alisa Takigawa. I didn't really like the 1st ED theme song. Maybe because it just didn't fit my taste. The 2nd ED theme song was decent. I don't hate it but I don't love it either. 


I watched the show in English Dub so I'll be reviewing the English VA. Most of them sounds great except I have 2 complaints. 1st is Meliodas' voice actor. It's Bryce..f*cking...Papenbrook. Why do companies love to hire this guy? I mean, his voice acting ain't that bad but I'm getting tired of hearing the same voice actor over and over. His role also includes Kirito from SAO, Eren from AOT, Shirou from UBW, Rin from Ao No Exorcist and many more. If you notice, all of the characters he voiced are protagonists from famous shows. That's why he's well known and that's why I'm tired of hearing the same voice. 2nd is the Princess' voice actress. She's not bad but she honestly got annoying after a few episodes with her squeaks and constant moaning (by moaning, I don't mean her sex voice). 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Characters] (9.5/10)

The following reasons why I gave this show a 8 despite the generic story is because of the characters. "The Seven Deadly Sins" contains one of the best characters for a shounen show. 


Each main characters contains one of the best personalities I have ever seen. Their personalities are funny as hell and the interactions between the characters are not something that should be missed. What I also love about the characters is the fact that they don't get ignored once a new arc happens. They're still important and relevant to the story. 


Every main character also receives character development. They all get their own flashbacks so you can understand them better. Even if the character's arc has passed by, they still get some flashbacks in order to explain their current actions. The flashbacks aren't as boring as I thought it would be and they're all very important to watch. 


I just want to point out one minor issue and that's Meliodas. To me, he's a Gary Sue. If they bothered explaining how he got the Demon powers and why he has those powers in the first place then I wouldn't even be calling him a Gary Sue right now. It's ridiculous that he's getting out of those inescapable situations every single time. Why do you think this is a minor issue only? Because the show ended inconclusively so it's obvious that there's going to be a second season and I'm very positive that it's going to be answered on the next season. If the show ended right on the 24th episode without explaining the Demon crap then I would have rated this show a lot lower. 


I'm not going to bother introducing the characters because this review is intended for viewers who have already seen the show. Not for people deciding whether they want to watch the show or not. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Enjoyment]: (9/10)

Despite the generic storyline, I truly enjoyed this anime. The fighting scenes are eye candy, the characters are hilarious and once they get serious, that's where the characters really shines. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[VERDICT]

"The Seven Deadly Sins" is a great shounen anime to watch because of its wonderful and smooth fighting scenes, great soundtrack and great and hilarious characters. It does have its weak points like having a generic storyline, excessive fanservice at the first half of the show and tons of plot holes that is likely going to get filled in the next season. 

P.S The show has a generic storyline but in my opinion, it's not that crap like some fans claim. At the end of the day, the show having a crap storyline is for you to decide. 


[OVERALL]: (8.5/10)



Pros:

+Decent Story

+Great Visuals and Animation

+Smooth Fighting scenes

+Great OST and Battle themes

+Awesome 2nd OP theme song

+Great and Developed Characters

+Tons of Funny Moments in the first half


Cons:

-Generic Storyline

-Excessive Fanservice

-Tons of Plot Holes

-Inconclusive Ending

-Pacing Issues

Before reading this review, take note that I have not read the Nanatsu no Taizai manga. In summary, the anime basically shows great character development with an interesting story. The art and animation is fluid and good for most of the parts but the sound/music is okay, nothing too memorable. However, I felt the opening and ending of the series has always been on point. Moving to the negatives of the anime, Nanantsu no Taizai seems to have a lot of plot holes when watched at first but it mostly addresses the issues somewhere later in the series. Overall, if you like a fast-paced animefilled with action-packed fighting scenes, this anime is a must. Nanantsu no Taiza or The Seven Deadly Sins is the type of anime that will leave you spamming the next episode button and begging for more.

Story: 10 -  While classic in nature, with its princesses, knights, and kingdom takeovers, it's also unique in its own special way. Interesting powers, situations, and creatures. Even though the general plot is actually quite dark, when it's not a moment for heavy emotions, the anime is actually fairly light hearted and comedic. The twists and backstabs are pretty good, if although sometimes predictable, however I was never not entertained.
Art: 9 - I've read around online that many people apparently didn't like this art style, however I actually really enjoyed it. Although I do think it could have been a little bit more polishedin some spots, for the most part, it does its job very well, actions, scenery, and emotions, are all easily conveyed, with appropriate emphasis and impact.


Sound: 9 -  It's usually pretty rare for me to like a full cast of any anime, but I actually really liked all the voices in this show, and the sound effects were pretty good too. Everything suited its purpose, and nothing really felt out of place.


Characters: 10 - The characters I think I enjoyed the most. This is very much a character driven anime, and although not everyone gets a backstory, I hope they continue this trend if the anime is granted a sequel. Each unique character has their own intensely personal and fleshed out personality, and it's so refreshing to not see blatant copy-paste stereotypes for everyone. I really enjoyed all the quirky behaviours and the motivations for each individual regardless of what side of the fight they were on. There is real emotional damage and insecurities for everyone involved, and it all make sense with regard to each characters personality and behaviours, which makes for a very well rounded cast.


Overall: 10 -  Every moment of the show was a joy to watch, and that's what I love about it. A tell-tale sign of a great anime, is it being able to captivate you at every episode, and once I started watching this show, it was agony waiting and wanting to know what would happen next (even if you already thought you knew where it was going). As well as its emotional impact, I think a good anime also has to hold some kind of weight. If it doesn't mean anything to you, then why should you watch it? I think when an anime has pulled at your heart strings, or your intellectual curiosity, it has done something right.

Firstly story is good for an adventure genre. But i find it disgusting with 'Ecchi' scenes (fan service). If these were not in the anime series i might have rated it 9. Thus it would be better to add 'Ecchi' in the genre description.
The male protaganist's strength was exaggerated a lot. But i liked his friends. The background history of MC's is not clear. Every time they refer to the incident that occurred 10 years back.
I enjoyed it purely for the adventure they had and even in the opponent team there are good guys. It is different from the shounen anime i have seen sofar only in this context. What i I found in this anime as refreshing is the main concept that when two parties involved in a war doen't mean that they are bad guys; in reality they are  are obliged to fight for their country and are not bad, which  is shown in this anime well.

Nanatsu no Taizai, The Seven Deadly Sins, a shounen action adventure fantasy anime with some comedy. As for the shounen part, it satisfies it completely. Action? There's a lot of it and really awesome fights too. Fantasy and adventure? Yup, you got it. A kingdom with good guys and bad guys. Comedy? Don't even get me started. Loads of laughs in each episode. Characters? All are amazing with unique abilities and personalities.
It's a really good anime, and it's so enjoyable that I didn't even realize how quickly it ended.
Story 9/10:
The series follows a single storyline: to gather all the Seven Deadly Sins (SDS) and takeback the kingdom from the Holy Knights (HK). The first half of the anime is dedicated to finding and recruiting all the SDS. The next half of the story is a war between the SDS and HK. The SDS are legendary knights while the HK are not as strong as the SDS but are still in the top ranks of knights of the kingdom, each having their own power.

Along the story, you get some history lessons of most of the characters, be they a member of the SDS or HK.

The story progression is really nice. It's not a slow pace and not too fast as to skip some parts. It just goes along nicely and you enjoy it to the full.


Art 10/10:

While some people may disagree, I personally believe this anime perfectly captures the essence of a fantasy land and a shounen anime. Too serious an animation would not give the anime it's comedy and lighthearted feel that it has sometimes. And too bad an animation would make the characters unappealing.

The character designs are really amazing. In all the anime I've seen, this one has quite a different art style and it's really nice and soothing.

As for the fights and special powers, they are also well animated. No censorship, which again is a plus point.


Sound 8/10:

There are 2 openings and 2 endings. They aren't anything special and not so bad as to regret not skipping them. Though my favorite is the 2nd ending "Seasons". 


Character 9/10:

The characters truly are amazing. Each member of the SDS has his/her own backstory, personality and power. Though some characters didn't get a backstory but that's also fine, since it doesn't affect the understanding of the story. Aside from the SDS and HK, other characters include the Kingdom's princesses, the King and some village folk.


Some episodes are dedicated to specific characters in order to make the story clear. Histories can be sad and the fights may have feels but that makes them all the better. As for the superpowers, they are out of this world. At first, they all may seem like normal people but once their power starts flowing, it's epic.


The characters are somewhat like you won't hate them all. Even if they are on the bad side, they are pretty cool. And since this is a fantasy anime, some inhuman things are sure to come. Those include Fairies, demons and some other demons human stuff.


Enjoyment 10/10:

I really really enjoyed this anime. So much, that I can watch it again and won't get bored. I started this series when it had completed 15 or something episodes and I watched those 15 episodes in a single run. I was completely glued to the screen once I started the anime. It's really fun to watch. You got some really funny comedy and some pervy stuff too (though not the ecchi pervy kind). But it's really fun to watch. 


The story is complete and it doesn't leave any cliffhangers. But it does hint the start of a new story and therefore the possibility of a sequel. And this anime truly deserves a sequel.

This is my first review so try to judge it with kindness XD 
To the main dish now, Seven Deadly Sins as it’s the alternative name is an addictive anime which it moved from manga to anime some time before. Lacking the experience to comment manga’s plot since I haven’t read it yet, I can’t judge the differences between these two. So, the story is a bit linear at start (as always) but with every episode you discover more and more about different stories and histories, to the point that many of them  come together to one point and I don’t believe it reachedits climax at  the end of the anime. It was just a bite of a great cake.  I believe story wise this anime has much more to offer in the near future(I hope). Now as far as the art is concerned they did a great job making some great scenes, the fights are really good having intensity in almost each attack, focusing to the surroundings not to standing there as dull objects but as parts of the fight. Sound is not the strong aspect of this anime. Do not expect to meet great songs or intensity created by songs and sound alone. Giving a quick thought now I don’t remember a song played in entire anime. Let’s go the strongest hand in this anime. If sound was one pair, characters are full house at least. Every char is unique some of them have a common story, and one of them is just epic.. No I’m not referring the main char but all my credits go to Hawk. When you see the anime you will remember my words.  I really really enjoyed this anime to the point watching it in 2 days and enjoying every single second that passed watching SDS. \n
So as an overall score, i say 9 since for me sounds are the drawback in this anime.\n

An anime created by one of the greatest manga of all time. This anime started off very good and seemed like it would've been one of the anime that would stay true to it's source material.
I was a little disappointed when I realized the route it took.
After episode 3: rushed pacing, cut scenes, story changing. The Nanatsu no Taizai anime blitzed through over 100 manga chapters and crunched them into only 24 episodes. From a manga, that has a deep story line such as One Piece, which has amazing foreshadowing and and gives just about all of the content shown with it a purpose, nomatter how small. 


Though this anime had great animation, art , and overall, caught the essence of the series, it very much disappointed a fan that read the manga before the anime even began. 


Gowther's story was changed, it cut out Dreyfus' fight that he had with Hendricksen along with his son and skipped an entire two chapters that was characterization of Elizabeth's sister. 


Anyways, as an anime, yeah, this was a fucking awesome ride, but as an adaption, it was tragic. 


Basically, what I'm trying to say by this review is to those of you that haven't read the manga and watched the anime first, read the manga because the anime skipped on a lot of important details that the anime left off on and sped through this decently paced masterpiece. 


I give it a 9 as an anime.

But a 5 or 6 as an adaption.

I was actually looking forward to watching this anime; I heard a lot of people talk about it and it actually sounded pretty cool. I can tell you that it's pretty garbage. I dropped this after 5 episodes because I just couldn't take it.
As soon as I started to watch this anime, on the first episode, I was able to predict what was going to happen. The characters were predictable and way too cliche (in the bad way) for me. Sure, most animes usually take the first three to five episodes to properly start (they have to introduce us to the world first) but gettingthrough the first five episodes was hard. I sighed loudly, rolled my eyes and cringed almost every minute. 


If you are one of those people who enjoy the same old kind-of-love-triangles and fan-service and way-too-OP male protagonists, and you can just shut your brain off for hours, then sure, watch this anime. 


I wouldn't say I hate this, I just didn't enjoy this at all and don't recommend this.

Though the first 2 episodes left me hyped for the rest of the series, by chapter 8 I can't stand the idea of binging this.
The MC apparently can't be touched by the strongest Sacred Knight, and then effortlessly beats another 2-3, but 5 episodes later he's struggling to deal with another random one, even though he's fighting 3v1 against her.
Endless ability names. Obvious things unnecessarily over-explained. Sudden, dull romances. Disposable villains. Lazy motives. And sooo many cliché-filled, underdeveloped and bland story arcs just make this series another one in the pile of shonen average stuff.
That said, I HAVE NOT WATCHED PAST EPISODE 9. So thisreview might change at a later moment, but I doubt so.\n\n
There is something to it, nonetheless. I plan to finish it after all. But compared to HunterXHunter, Boku no Hero Academia, or even a "non-fighting" shonen like Shokugeki no Souma, Nanatsu no Taizai is just an underwhelming series overall. So, it gets a 6/10. It does not deserve anything higher. But, that being said, it doesn't deserve anything less either.\n\n
P.S.: The Pork is the best thing about this show. So good.

I watched this anime on Netflix, where it is called the seven deadly sins. I must admit I was VERY skeptical about this anime series since it was being advertised as a Netflix original. I didn't expect a "Netflix original" anime to be any good. However, I was beyond surprised. The start of the first episode was a bit iffy. It came off as a very perverted, sexual based kind of show, but towards the end of the episode, I realized I couldn't wait to watch episode two. I really grew to love this series. The characters were so lovable and epic, the storyline wasso interesting and I was always on the edge of my seat. The pervertedness continued, but I strangely grew to love this interaction between the princess and the dragon sin. It was always a good laugh, that's for sure. I would highly recommend this series to anyone who loves action, romance, and comedy. I truly loved it, and am praying for a season 2!

Ok, so I actually really liked this series, despite alot of my rating being low. 
First of all, my big thing about this series is that I really dont go into it because of the plot. Its the pure awesomeness of the characters that I just want more and more of. Meliodas is everything a character aspires to be, and Ban is his darker counterpart. King is incredibly powerful, yet struggles with internal issues of relationships and Diane, Merlin and Escanor are pretty flat tho. We dont really come to see em. Escanor is awesome, buts also relativly flat.
People watching this only care about Meliodas,Ban, King and maybe Diane because their pure prowess and internal struggles are so captivating. 


This is the only show I have ever watched subbed (I cant stand watching things subbed. Why would I want to read, when I could hear,) because I simply couldnt wait for the dubbed version. The scale of the plot is epic, with the wars and betrayals beating me up so bad! Is was AWESOME.


The story is dope, but is only AWESOME when combined with characters. The Art was fine, nothing to scoff at, and the sound as well. The characters were ok, half of them being great, the other half useless, but not bad.


Personally I love an epic journey of powerful beings reclaiming the world from evil, and so I enjoyed this as one of my fav animes of all time. But overall, it does lack in character and plot at some point.

In this anime, the main characters are likeable. However, some of the characters appeared a little too late. I found myself wishing that I could’ve known them more. Some of the scenes were dragged on and I found it annoying. There are also scenes where I found myself wondering… How the hell did that happened? What’s worse, some of them weren’t explained. But don’t go away. This show is awesome. 
One word is all it takes to make any anime worthy to be watched: interesting. It’s simple. If you think it’s interesting, then watch. If not, then don’t. It all boils down in asking yourself:Is it interesting enough to make me watch it? 


So? What makes it interesting? 


A princess goes on a journey by herself in search for people who might save the kingdom.   A simple plot isn’t it? But what if those people are fugitives? Now that makes this simple plot interesting. I believe this is the strong point of this anime. Seek help from criminals? Are you kidding? From there, the story grows and becomes more complex. 


The “heroes’’ she sought… Just the simple thought of their identities makes you anticipate who they are and what kind of people they are. Though, it’s a shame since my favourite character (Gowther) wasn’t focused compared to the others. 


Was it a worthy-watch?


Of course. I had so much fun watching it.

I am new to this site, but I have watched a wide variety anime over the years, and this is the first time that I have seen an anime with so many plot holes and such a frenetic ending receive so much undeserved appeal and 10 out of 10s (since SAO). What I write does not come from a hipster-like desire to stand against popular opinion, but from my own notes taken while watching the show.
Story -- 
The story has an interesting premise that drew me in at first. This idea that there is this guild of renegade, all powerful knights who were first exiled,but are now needed to combat a greater evil is an idea that I happen to be quite fond of. However, this story gets confused among all the side stories, flashbacks and plot twists used to manufacture tension and build characters during their fights with their rivals. There is one point toward the endgame, where the protagonist spots a plot aspect from what seems like thin air before destroying it, saving "the girl" and appeasing his rival (I was befuddled until I watched 3 more times). Another, where a character spawns from nowhere simply for the purpose of interluding to set up the second season. Events like these, for the astute viewer, serve only to muddle the main conflict. However, I will give some credit to this shonen for bothering to show the backstory for characters like King and Guila (although, this makes it more apparent when characters like Jericho don't receive proper background). 

The interweaving of characters is rather interesting, as all characters seem to be connected to others in some way.

ALSO, might I add, that there are four instances in which characters escape the inescapable or breech the unbreechable. These frustrate me to no end as it means that tension is truly manufactured in some instances.


Characters -- 

The characters tend to frustrate me, since, although they are Knights of an esteemed order, they seem to lack chemistry in battle until the last battle, behave like pouting teenagers despite all being adults (except for Goat Sin), and they never wear armor in combat, eroding any semblance of their being these legendary knights, especially when compared to other knights in the show. There is little tension in combat, since at least two of the sins are absolutely unkillable and at least three have no clear limit established for their abilities, meaning that they could be even more powerful then they demonstrate when the PLOT needs them to be. Other characters tend to hide their power, some times to a grave fault, as many of the characters have OP abilities that they don't use in some battles, for some reason.

Personally, Hawk the Pig and Elizabeth are my least favorite characters, as the Pig is trying VERY hard to be funny and Elizabeth is practically a Fairy Tale character with all the crying, name-shouting and power-of-friendship-ing that she does. 

There are some funny characters like Goat Sin and Dragon Sin (early on) that serve to keep the anime light-hearted in spite of all the edgy themes.

There is some fan service, but it is rare.


Art and Sound -- 

This is an A-1 pictures production, so both are bog standard. Not amazing, but not terrible. The first OP and the last credits theme are pretty good, not much else sticks out.


Overall -- 

For a shonen, its mostly predictable, with the least developed and most annoying characters(Elizabeth, Hawk, etc.) taking up more time than the more developed and most interesting ones(Gil, Gowther and Jericho). Character designs are erratic (some seem as though they are from entirely different animes, or at least in the wrong time period) and major plot elements are predictable (except for one RIDICULOUS one).

If you like shonen, you may like it, otherwise I wouldn't recommend it except for a laugh at how ludicrous its final episodes get.

Please don't believe the hype.

Nanatsu no Taizai ( The Seven Deadly Sins) is a story of recruiting individuals who were commonly thought out as the bad guys into a team (again) into completing the  contradictory ( to what people think they do) objective of saving the kingdom. The story is set in lands of the middle ages where the runaway princess recruits members of a disbanded group of the kingdom's traitors to go and help avoid a crisis brewing in the kingdom's upper echelons. 
 The anime was well planned with fairly developed characters, coupled with pretty good 
animation, and sound, presenting usa an enjoyable journey with the characters. What failed the anime though is how predictable the events where, though the setting was good, it wasn't unique and failed to set it apart from other anime that carry the same style. The story wasn't emotionally intensive and failed to attach me to any of the characters as although the characters are developed, they are too common within anime of this genre. \n\n
   Overall I find this anime to be good but not more or less as it lacks depth of emotion and character distinctions. Serving well as mindless entertainment, which may just be good enough for the average consumer.\n

Sins is an incredible anime.
The cast of characters is so unique and refreshing! Don't expect to find your basic cotton candy bitch here. Every time you think you knew what a character is capable of they show you more of their power, but it isn't rushed or too slow. The acceleration of abilities in this anime is just right, which is rare. I still can't get over how unique these characters are and the MC is great! The MC really carries this anime through his confidence. It's really nice to see an MC who is no joke and will beat your ass. The music andaudio is excellent, but there's not many tunes to get attached to or inspired by. The art doesn't particularly stand out either. There are other series that produce a lot more effort but that doesn't mean sins doesn't have its own style. Other than the uninteresting music score and unspectacular art, sins is simply amazing. All in all, sins is a rush of refreshing characters and adventure! Watch this and you will not regret it.

I just finished this anime with a friend of mine. We were watching all the episodes in one go which kinda indicates how hooked we were.
The tension builds up nicely and one reveal is more spectacular than the other. Of course this anime has it's downsides but let's take a closer look at every aspect.
Story: 
While the first half of the anime feels like a light shonen anime, it smoothely progresses up to the very big showdown. 
The creators of this show understood one thing so many hollywood studios tend to forget. An epic and spectacular fight scene is somewhat useless when it does nothelp to develop a character. Nanatsu no Taizai does everything right here. During the fight you learn a lot about the people who fight, why they fight and how they feel. Prepare for awesome plot twists and revealed secrets.

Sometimes a bit cheesy though.


Art: Looks nice. A bit too much bubble-gum atmosphere for my personal taste but still good and leaves nothing to bitch about.


Sound: Some flaws here. Sometimes the music doesn't fit too well to the scene. Still some nice folk-music in it.


Character:

The character development especially during the fights is great. 

I didn't like that they introduced the 6th Deadly Sin so late in the series and told the viewer nothing about her while we got to see a lot from the other characters. Maybe that will change in Season 2.


Enjoyment:

Couldn't stop watching.

A few plot-holes here and there but luckily the show manages to make up for that with it's brilliant character development.

Short summary: I'm not going to hold back! *Everybody then proceeds to hold back*
I heard about this by seeing it recommended enough times. I am a biy disappointed to find another shounen where the next boss is actually more powerful, and the main character unlocks a whole new level. The typical, trash someone would write if they only planned out the beginning and ending, and fills the story with coincidences so the plot holes are as blaring, but I'm sure most of us can distinguish.
It would be unfair to say I didn't enjoy this, cause I did, but only the parts where I didn't rollmy eyes. I don't mind copy and paste character tropes, and these characters were unique enough where watching them interact warrants a 20 minute episode, and for once the mascot is likeable from the start.


There were times when the soundtrack far exceeded what this anime could have ever been, and I was ignorantly excited for what was to come.


The story itself is pretty good, and I never really felt like any major storylines from any character was forced. It somehow felt very natural for everyone to end up together. But besides that, there are many, many moments where the coincidences are really too obvious.


So, all in all: mediocre at best, and watch it if you're in the mood for shounen.

The male gaze is strong with this one and very much lacks female gaze. If you have problems with non-consensual sexual stuff going on, this is one of the things I can't suggest.
The story is basic "hide and seek" platform. Characters set off on a quest to find other people to do a thing! It's pretty trope-y and cliche, but that's some of what's good about it. The way the story plays out had me on the edge of my seat a few times. What I didn't understand were the main male character's lack of facial expressions. It seemed like a problem that got fixedas time went on but when it first started he was groping the main female character's body with a straight-face. She also didn't do anything about. I prefer when the characters react to stuff like that, too. Or maybe it's a "if I pretend that it didn't happen he'll stop." But, it doesn't.


There were some things that were more inopportune, and out of place. A lot of things with the main male character didn't get explained. More into that, there's no explanation on where all but one character came from. The writing also lacked at some moments, but nothing too hurtful.


Sub or dub? Dub.

Nanatsu no Taizai is a fun anime and a must recommend to anyone who likes or loves fantasy and/or adventure anime. From its core, like most other adventure anime, The Seven Deadly Sins is about getting from 1 location to the next, implementing enjoyment into the journey and not one that keeps you guessing for the fate of the ending.
The characters each have their own personalities as  they all come from different backgrounds and even races, they interact with each other especially well as they have been absent from one another's company for many years, this something I really enjoyed and a big plusfor this anime.\n
The music was nothing special, it was nothing memorable or something that stood out above anything else, It served its purpose whilst watching but nothing else.\n
The Story is Good (for an adventure anime at least) but nothing that really made me emotionally connected to the world.\n
One of the biggest downfalls with Nanatsu no Taizai is one of the main characters Elizabeth, who for the most part did nothing of value and only served as a fan service prop just so it could receive the stamp of Ecchi on its front cover and a cheap tool for the other main character, Meliodas to play with as a love interest.\n
While the Story, Art and Sound was nothing special, the character diversity was enough to get me griped into watching this to the end and my personal love of Adventure Fantasy anime made this extremely enjoyable for me.\n
I give this anime a 7 outa 10, Above Average and the title of a Good anime.\n
(Note that my scores are based upon the idea that a 5 out of 10 anime are considered "Average" animes)

This action-packed anime has become one of my top 10 favorites within just a few episodes. Let me tell you why you should be watching Nanatsu no Taizai. 
Story 9/10- This story is about a group of people that supposedly "betrayed" their homeland. The main girl character, Elizabeth, is one of the princess of Liones. She sets out to seek help from the notorious legendary knights to protect her homeland from the Holy Knights. From the first episode to the last episode, there is nonstop action. So if you don't like action stuff then I don't even know what you're doing here.
Art 10/10- From theever famous studio A-1 pictures, the art sure is glorious. I've seen most of the A-1 pictures animes and I think this one is by far the best. I like how they drew Meliodas, instead of portraying him as a [spoiler]3,000 year old male[/spoiler], they portrayed him as a kid. And a perverted one at that too. 


Sound 10/10- The music is epic!! I can't stop listening to it after I finished watching the whole thing. I just replayed everything over and over. It is beautiful, as expected of Hiroyuki Sawano. I also liked the opening song. I just didn't like the second one. 


Character 8/10- Meliodas is a great leader, and he is OP as well. Ban is [spoiler]immortal[/spoiler], I didn't really like him that much at first but he's pretty cool with his killing intent. Him and King don't really get along that much though. King, or King Harlequin, he cares deeply for his friends and his sister. Diane, well, she was jealous of Elizabeth at first because of all the attention Meliodas was giving to her, learned to like and befriend Elizabeth. Gowther was kind of useless tbh, and Merlin didn't show up until towards the end. Merlin was pretty cool though, didn't expect Merlin to be girl. Gilthunder is also pretty cool. And who can forget about the talking pig?? He was so cute and loyal!!!


Enjoyment 10/10- I enjoyed this anime a lot, I am so hyped for a season 2!!! I need to see Escanor. 


Overall 9/10- This is a really good anime. If you liked Akame ga Kill! or Akatuski no Yona (haven't seen that one but heard it was like Nanatus no Taizai) then you should definitely watch this. Except imo this was so much better than Akame ga Kill.

Rank at time of review: 88th.
Main genres: Adventure, Shounen, Action, Fantasy & Ecchi.
Anime summary - This show was incredibly hard to rate but also very easy to rate and that in some respects actually highlights the strengths and weaknesses in and of itself. Nanatsu no Taizai (The seven deadly sins) is a show that tries to do a little bit of everything and succeeds marvelously whilst also failing to pinpoint any specific emotion from me. I will expand on this concept throughout my review.
Story [7] - The story begins as many others do, a young, beautiful princess with a great big heart and even biggermission. She is looking for the most hated villians in all the land, the seven deadly sins. This shy, loving princess shows up out of nowhere requiring a knight in shining armour to come to her rescue when all of a sudden an incredibly strong (almost invincibly so) young lad shows up and wins her heart over with his undying kindness and spunk. This young lad also turns out to be one of "the seven deadly sins" which the princess left her home to find. And here begins their journey, the innocent princess and the young perverted knight go in search of the remaining deadly sins with their companions, a talking cute pink pig and a massive green pig carrying a house. Also, this show is ecchi which explains why the hero of this story is a pervert (I think thats the only reason) Also, its got some pretty hilarious sexual harrassment, so thats a thing. The story is dark, bittersweet, full of tears, love, romance and a lot of action. 


Art [7] - The art is a tough one to rate. I can't help but draw a comparison with Soul Eater and Hunter X Hunter. All 3 of these shows are somewhat dark with pretty child-friendly art that grows on you and has genuinely scary moments. They are all extremely unique art-styles and all compliment the shows perfectly. When you get used to the artwork it can take your breath away at times. The one critique I would make of it is sometimes the blood (and trust me, there is plenty of it, this show hasn't been cencored to any large degree) can look fake and lack impact due to it. But this is a minor problem that doesn't take anything away from the show as a whole.


Sound [7] - The OP and EP's were pretty mediocre, they didn't really fit the 'vibe' of the show as much as they should have. There were some heart-breaking moments that felt ruined and lacked emotion because the ending song didn't represent the emotions being portrayed by the characters. As for the music actually in the show, I can't complain about any of it. The music created tension before a fight, drew in suspense during it, and broke your heart when something bad happened. You could close your eyes throughout the show and understand what was happening by the tone of the music (if you ignore the OP and EP)


Characters [9] = This is probably a highlight of the show. I wasn't sure about the cast in the first few episodes, it seemed like a pretty fun show with some cliche characters and I was genuinely confused about how it was ranked so high.. But after around episode 8 I found myself wanting to know more and more about these wonderful new companions. 


A big positive was the fact that the characters personalities were in no way linear. They actually developed throughout, big events actually change their personalities and the way they behaved. We see why they are who they are through both heart-breaking and tender monologues about their past and that pain they feel is evident in the way they behave as well. If someone is reading this review who hasn't seen the show and I could get only one point across to them, it is don't give this show up after just a few episodes. Don't ignore it because everything seems too cliche. This show grows. It plants a seed within you in the beginning and that seed slowely grows into your heart until you simply understand why this show is so good.


Enjoyment [9] - This show is undoubtedly one of the more enjoyable watches in anime. It may not be the most sophisticated anime in the world but it does everything very well. Comedy, action, ecchi, more action, it literally has everything that you could want and combines them really, really well. Like I said, its not a masterpeice and there aren't going to be many people rate this a 10. But there won't be many rate it below a 7 either.



Overall [8] - The seven deadly sins is an anime which is very hard to not enjoy and thats the reason for its rating (88). Not because it blows you away, but because it will suck you in and force you to at least enjoy it a little. This might not seem like a compliment, but it is. Its impossible to impress everyone.. But this show comes dang close and thats incredibly impressive.

The anime is great and I like pretty much everything about it. But don't get me wrong, I'm not some fanboy that thinks every anime I like has no flaws. Because it does. Not just the talking pig (doesn't really affect me but still.) The wait for it... FAN SERVICE! The fact that Meliodas touches Elizabeth on her breasts, arse or w/e really annoys me, same as the fact that every woman is practically naked,  and simply because it's not there for the plot, it's there for the guys that sit at home jerking off to this. I mean I'm not judging haha butthe fact that it's so much fan service just really bothers me. Could've been a great anime. Just wish they would've keep the fan service to a minimum and I probably would've given this anime a 10/10. There's some incredible fights tho. If you're okay with fan service I recommend this if you're into adventure/fighting animes with a great story.\n\n
//limpan

This story blew my mind as far as top notch art, an outstanding take on the seven deadliest sins known within the christian faith, and most of all the acknowledgement of all characters. Generally, in shonen anime one to three characters get the lime-light per-say, but in this anime every single sin with exception of gluttony and pride (because one hasn't been around long and the other has yet to appear), has all had plenty of screen time level full of epicness. They even found time for the useless female that follows the main character and the mascot to make epic moves. However, if you'reanything like me you'll see then ending as a bit of a cop out, but the anime will hopefully continue as the manga has. The cop-out brought my enjoyment to a 9, but every other category remains 10/10.\n

I highly, highly recommend this anime/manga for anyone who has the slightest bit of interest in the fantasy genre. 
The anime actually follows along with the manga with very few minor details changed, which is great. Of course it starts out with the generic cliches of characters but after the first impression you realize that these are not your normal cliches that are over used and annoying to watch. Whether it's good or bad events that happen to the characters, they develop onward damn near instantly and are in now way stunted. 
The bad guys are not just the good guys, the good guys arenot just the bad guys in disguise. The entire world, it's history, the monsters/races are tastefully used and it cultivates mystic that makes you wonder just what else is roaming in the world. \n\n
There's no beating around the bush with story or character development. Instead they start you off with what you think is the classic cliche personality and immediately they take off and plow through all of the annoying malarky that's commonly used and dragged out throughout the series. They don't over dramatize the characters or their relationships which makes for a far more 'realist' feel on the world, the character's reactions and and the events that take place which shape the characters.

So I watched this show after knowing that the manga was the best-selling manga for the first-half of 2015 dethroning the big ones like One Piece and Attack on Titan. I picked up this show to know on what the hype was all about. 
"The Seven Deadly Sins" - hearing this makes me think that the main characters are villains, but they aren't. I mean, I am pretty sure The Seven Deadly Sins of FMA (One of my favorite anime out there) were villains, but this anime doesn't portray them as villains. Apparently, The Seven Deadly Sins have been set up by someone on thekingdom that they're going to overthrow the kingdom. The truth is, they aren't. One girl named Elizabeth, is on a journey to find the Seven Deadly Sins to take back her kingdom. This... is actually nothing new, but I do feel like the story was executed very well. It was written creatively. The story is on-point and it doesn't rumble. Not to mention, it's properly paced. The ending wasn't really that bitter. It was rather the best way to leave the show hanging and wait for Season 2. Though, it does give us a teaser on what's next in the future.


When it comes to A-1 Pictures in terms of animations in action-packed anime, I don't expect a lot. I do feel like they're very inconsistent. Take a look at Fairy Tail. It's choreography when it comes to fight scenes are mostly poor. Well, if long-running anime isn't the case, take a look at SAO. The anime had it's moments in animation, but it doesn't keep up. So what did I think of the animation in Nanatsu no Taizai? Well, it's actually good. Though, there are so many moments on this show where it could have been animated better; where it could have been choreographed better. 


The sound of Nanatsu no Taizai reminds me of Fairy Tail. Though for me, IN TERMS OF SOUNDTRACK (Not the whole anime), it's soundtrack is not on par with FT. FT's soundtrack is better. The soundtrack totally feels like you're in the Middle Age of Europe. For the openings, well, OP 2 is better than OP 1 and I think most can agree. OP 1 is pretty light, though, I wasn't really feeling the song. She sang one of the best Naruto Shippuuden OPs (Blue Bird and Hotaru no Hikari), but this one just seem a little off. OP 2 was like, REALLY GOOD. MAN WITH A MISSION is really a great band. For the EDs, both ED 1 and ED 2 was good. I cannot pick.


The characters of Nanatsu no Taizai are good. They're very entertaining at times. However, the characterization and the portrayal somewhat confuses me at times. These are the Seven Deadly Sins, yet they don't really portray their sins a lot. Sure, Diane showcased her envy side; Meliodas showcased his wrath side, but it's not like they show it all the time. Characters like Elizabeth seems to be your ordinary girl main character of a Shonen anime. You know, where they're so weak, but then shines at the later part, then you came to realize that she's actually a badass (Sakura from Naruto, Lucy from FT). Though, Elizabeth seems to be at the "shines at the later part". I don't think she's a "badass" (yet). I am not hating alright. So far, they're enjoyable.


Speaking of enjoyable, I did enjoy the show a lot, but what puts me off is the humor it offers. There are some humor of this show that doesn't make me laugh at all especially Hawk's humor and Meliodas touching boobies - it doesn't make me laugh, but I don't hate the show for it. What made this show great is simply the storyline. I thought it was epic and it really gave me a ride.


Score: 7.6/10

If you can look past all its flaws, the Seven Deadly Sins is very enjoyable show. 
Many people criticize the show for its dues ex machina plot. I would agree to a certain extent. Many of these devices are used near the very the end of the show, specifically the last two episodes. Fortunately there is a little backup for each d.e.m. used so it doesn't feel completely ridiculous. See the story loves to put these little hints throughout the entirety of the story to explain the ending. Then, they show all these "hints" in a quick flash to make you feel like itsjustified. Most of the time there is no explanation. It just is and you have to accept it.


On the other hand, the show excels at showcasing vibrant characters. This is by far the best part of the show. There is such an uniqueness found in each and every one of the characters. You fall in love with all of the personalities as they clash and bond. The show will have you laughing at just how ridiculous each person is.  This is the height of the show. Many times you will question their decisions but you will never question their person. 


The art, like the characters, is very vibrant. Flashy and colorful, it catches the eye. The animation felt very similar to Magi. It's no wonder the show was made by the same studio. 


The sound is decent. Good themes come in at the right time and I get my excitement going but it definitely doesn't blow me away.


Honestly, this show has a identity crisis. It is constantly not taking itself seriously with slapstick humor but it tries to be serious with demons, murder, and pure evil. Its very good at the humor but not so good at the evil. The middle of the show is the creme of the crop while the beginning and end leave something to be desired. By the end, I think you won't think this show is very good, but you will have enjoyed the hell out of it along the way.

One of the best series I've ever watched. This is one of those series where since episode 5 you're checking which episode you're on, hoping there's plenty more to go.
Story -Despite being an anime, the depth of the plot and background is comparable to Tolkien. The meticulous unravelling of past events and ancient lore is nothing short of a masterpiece. Prepare to get sucked into a world that leaves you yearning for more after each episode.
Art/sound - Art perfectly suits the series' fantasy setting along with its brilliant aptitude for adding the right amount of humor in every episode.
Character - This is where the seriesshines. You'd expect the characters to run dull after hearing of 7 (yes, SEVEN) main characters along with a horde of side characters. However, every character brings a perfect balance of individuality and uniqueness without hogging precious screen time. The characters are also introduced in a spectacular fashion; where you know its coming, but you're just waiting to see how it unravels. \n\n
Enjoyment - Although there are some plot holes and inconsistencies with the strength of characters, lore, reasoning, the show was incredibly enjoyable to watch.

I suggest you watch this anime on Netflix with the HD turned ON. 
The story is a typical shounen format... you have your main cast, a princess who finds this pervy kid (who's actually really old, really powerful former knight who has a bounty on his head for treason), and they go on this journey to find their friends to help them fight and save the kingdom. Nothing new, uses a bunch of things we have seen before in other stories (7 sins, short main character with blonde hair, magical weapons that harness their users powers, fairies, demons, etc etc), but it sure is entertainingwhen you get to watching it. However, I do feel like 25 episodes is a bit short and there was barely any story development since the series seemed to focus more on telling the stories of the characters. If you like legends of medieval England, you'll probably like this anime because of the similarity in the setting, magical element, and characters. 


The art is awesome. The colors are very bright, almost felt like I was watching Hunter X Hunter (2011) and the quality is excellent. The background music will make you feel like you are taking a trip to Stonehenge and watching a jousting match in Camelot. 


The characters I think are the best part of this anime. The seven deadly sins themselves are interesting to try to analyze and watch as the story develops. They are also quite interesting and are not what you would expect given their titles and their roles as knights. You have Meliodas, who although is "Wrath" is actually a pretty pleasant, friendly, and caring guy who rarely gets mad. You start to have all these questions for the other "sins" throughout the story and try to figure out why they got those titles. Elizabeth, who initially I initially disliked since she seemed like she was the epitomy of "useless, pretty, female character in a shonen who only works as a love interest" tries throughout the whole series to make something of herself, for her friends and the kingdom she cares about.  The side characters get a lot of screentime as well and you get to know them and their motives. There is also a talking pig. You HAVE to watch it for the talking pig. 


Overall, although the story is not AMAZING (I mean...what can you really do for an ongoing shonen series in 24 episodes?), the characters themselves drive the series make it truly enjoyable to watch despite its flaws. Give it a try and don't forget to watch it in HD!

I saw this anime being rated as one of the popular anime's a few seasons ago, and saw the second season of it in the #1 spot in some anime website.
I had high hopes for this anime, and was expecting some really cool concepts with the actual seven deadly sins while figuring out if today's shonen anime can compete with older anime shows. Unfortunately, I was disappointed.
This anime has is very generic and bland, the tone of the story was very confusing because of the blank expression Meliodas would usually express during dramatic events and whenever I made many predictions, which I won't spoil, butall of them came true.


The characters have almost no development, the exposition is mostly through dialogue, and the characters and their titles of one of the seven deadly sins, have almost no relation.


The main character, Meliodas is a complete Mary Sue, and most of the episodes wank him to no end.


The anime also has alot of pedophilia and sexual harassment going on through out the story, which made watching is somewhat uncomfortable.


The few things I can applaud this anime for is the art is very nice and very colourful, the voice actors do a good job, and some of the fight scenes were entertaining.

The Seven Deadly Sins (TSDS to save space from here on) is a work created by the studio A-1 Pictures, a studio known for their lackluster shows, and unfortunately, TSDS is no different.
Story
The story is as basic as it gets, kingdom gets taken over by evil corrupt organization and group of adventurers team up to save the day. Nothing special, but nothing terrible in the setup. How said setup is executed is where the problem lies. Since one of the main characters we primarily see the story unfold around brings nothing to the table and has nothing to do with the story other than beingobvious waifu-bait there’s a large disconnect with the actual heroes’ perspective and her own, we often just see her crying over everything when that time could be better allocated to fleshing out better fight scenes or developing the actual characters who matter. What we get for this trade-off is a stunning lack of establishing shot for villains, explanations for whatever ass-pull the heroes just used, or time to enhance the fights. Villains often just show up out of the blue with no indication they were even in the area of our heroes, they do something mean, fight the heroes and show how weak the heroes are in comparison, and then the heroes decide to actually start trying and wipe the floor with them. Heroes and Villians often just bring out the super-ultra-hidden technique that they’ve been saving for just his moment that we had no idea that they could use to instantly win or be completely shrugged off by their opponent's super-ultra-hidden technique.  There’s never any tension that the heroes are ever in any danger so you just become null to all the explosions and vicious stabbing they are being dealt because you can be sure they start walking it off in no time because the plot never has the timetable to sit still and have a break because we have to have one of our characters cry all the time. At some point, the story decides it needs to start wrapping this up so a character just teleports to a location they had no idea the heroes were and kidnaps one of them so the team has a reason to head over to capital to defeat the big baddie and save the kingdom. It feels like the plot had little planning.


Magic System

This being a fantasy show set in a world where anyone can use magic an explanation to how the magic works in this world is needed, sadly the show never gives us one and this results in characters being able to do whatever they please when the plot demands it and having certain characters being leagues stronger than others because of their immense power, but it’s never explained what this power is and we can never get a gauge of how strong certain characters are in relation to others before a fight. How strong is Meliodas in comparison to random villain #3? You never know, especially since our characters are often just messing around and not even trying until someone much weaker gets hurt because they refuse to try. What determines characters abilities is never explained either they just start using abilities we didn’t have privy to beforehand and it’s never clear why they can’t use other abilities they’ve seen before. What multiplies this problem later on in the series is that there are characters that specialize in magic called mages, but what is the extent of their abilities? You guessed it, you never know, and the explanation used for anything that can’t be explained is“It’s magic.” Lazy storytelling 101


Fights

The fights are brief and riddled with power levels you are never sure of. All the characters are capable of destroying mountains if they wanted to and able to take hits that could do so regularly and keep fighting. There’s never clear indication if the damage the characters are taking matters. There are characters who are actually immortal, but it’s clear early on that none of the characters are ever in any real danger and as such, there’s never any tension in any of the fights, and a fight without tension is a fight that is boring. A fun fight needs two things, mechanics, and narrative. The mechanics of a fight is the fight itself, fight choreography, the various fighting styles, the weapons used, physical skill, etc. This is essential to keep the audience engaged in the action, and battle shounen should have a solid foundation established in the first few episodes, preferably the first one, however, TSDS fails in this respect because the characters are so ridiculously overpowered that there is never a moment of understanding of what makes these characters so strong since if they just decide to win, they do. The mechanics of a fight is nothing without the underlying context of the narrative behind it. There is a simple narrative in the fights of TSDS, but it never goes far enough for the audience to care for the battles themselves. You’re never sure of who the underdog in each fight is, if the opponents are equal, or if the fight is with a true villain or someone being manipulated by someone else. The heroes often just see the fights as bothersome and severely underestimate their opponents, giving them the upper hand, only to immediately get destroyed when the heroes get angry. The fights in this battle show are pretty lackluster, fast, and add little value to the overall narrative.


Art

This being an A-1 Pictures show you can expect them to shell out the budget needed to make TSDS feel consistent in theme and tone. Nothing ever feels out of place and the fights, while short, never looked like they were running out of money to animate. It’s a solid look for the show that they’re trying to create.


Sound

Another category A-1 Pictures often delivers is in the soundtrack that we hear throughout the story. I’m happy to report that they do so in this show as well and when the drama needs a tear-jerker or we need the epicness to crank up to eleven the soundtrack can turn a bland scene into a memorable one. By itself the soundtrack is great and it feels appropriate for the show. The opening and ending themes are worthy of the praise they get and can definitely be added among the greats.


Characters

The characters are how we see the story presented and as I mentioned before in the story section there is a major problem with one of them in particular, Elizabeth, chief among them is that she has no purpose. If you took her out of the story not only would you save a large amount of time that could be used to improve the overall show you wouldn’t lose much in the plot. Just have Meliodas journey around looking for TSDS from the start while working and gradually feel as though he has to do something about The Holy Knights and their cruelty would be natural and flow better with the story. She’s just there so people can project her as their princess in distress. Meliodas, captain of TSDS has his flaws, and two of them really hurt the experience, one is he’s a sexual assaulter, I’m not even making it up, he does it regularly for what I assume is supposed to be humor for the show but in reality is just kinda scary, at one point when a consenting girl ask him why he doesn’t do it to her, he responds “It’s no fun if you want it.” Another problem is his inability to take his opponents seriously, since he knows he’s ridiculously overpowered he often destroys the mood the show is trying to established by pointing out that he’s not even concerned that the villains are there with a nonchalant one-liner, and he does this all the time, many times in a single fight usually. The other characters all have their problems too, but nothing on the same magnitude of the main two. We often get flashbacks of our characters so we can know their backstory and motivations, and most of these flashbacks are done well enough, but nothing in the present is ever as tense as the moment in the past and this is because there is actual loss or risk of loss in the flashbacks. The characters are just so badass that the only way that they can be in any danger is if they are doing something stupid on purpose.


Enjoyment

Getting through this show was a real chore. The biggest problem is it’s just boring I think I have hammered home that the show has zero tension and because of this, it lacks any weight. I know the show is rather popular and I tried to understand the appeal while watching it, but the only value is as a time waster to have in the background. I’d give the show an overall score of 2/10. It’s not worth watching for anyone.

This is the most bland anime that still manages to make me want to watch the next episode immediately. Not sure if that says something about the show or that says something about me haha. I think this is the kind of show that I would have loved as a kid but now with a more jaded view on things I see a lot of flaws that I wouldn't have before. I should probably also note that I'm a big medieval/fantasy fan so there is some genre bias here. Let's first start with the..
Story (7/10) - slight spoilers!
I grapple with this one quite a bit.This show is one step away from being predictable at every turn. The "twists" are all fairly common. However, I'm still interested in the big pictures. I also like the attention to detail (such as the red-eye raven following Gilthunder around paying off later in the show). I also enjoy the sprinkling of flashbacks that we get about the characters past (Diane and King's time together, events ten years prior) that explains their motivation. Overall the story-telling is not bad and this is one of the main reasons why I will be watching the next season.


Character (6/10) 

While the story itself is pretty engaging for me, the characters are meh. All the characters are fairly boring except for Ban (a sentiment echoed by many here). Character progression was non-existent in the current timeline. As mentioned before though I did like how all of the characters had their motives at least somewhat explained. This isn't true for everyone but true for enough members of the main casts that I felt like it deserved a shout-out. 


Sound (5/10)

Average, not memorable. I liked the second ending but that's about it.


Art (7/10)

Some of the abilities were pretty cool. I really enjoyed the animation for Chastiefol (sp?) as well as some of the Holy Knights abilities (Howzer, Gilthunder). The fight scenes were good. The fanservice was good (sorry I'm easy). I wish they tried harder with some of the effects though (Hendrickson in Grey Demon mode shot these shoddy looking black balls that didn't do anything for me, perhaps just a result of the color choices)


Enjoyment and Closing Remarks (7/10)

I don't know how to rate this category so this ended up being the same rating as my overall score for the show. Overall I recognize that this isn't the best show out there but there are enough elements of action/story to keep me interested. Looking forward to the next season!

When I first saw The Seven Deadly Sins, I downloaded as a quick crappy shonen anime to watch while I multitasked on the side. I was pleasantly surprised.
Its no Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood, but it doesn't have to be. It's fun and entertaining to the point that I was watching it full window, freaking shocked on how it was actually, GOOD.
Story: 
The plot is maybe one of the weakest aspects of the show, but it still is strong enough to be entertaining. Though the lore of the land is never explained, I enjoy when they don't go out of their way to over explain, because ittakes away from the flow of the story and seems forced when there are lengthy explanations of boring backstory. It was cliche and sort of silly, but it was enjoyable. Not all anime need a FMA level of backstory.


Art:

I found the art very pleasing to look at, and didn't see any big errors on my first run through. All the characters seemed to move in different ways and were very expressive. This anime does have a case of the "Everyone is pretty or hot expect bad guys or old people" but the designs were very varied so I didn't have any problem with it.


Sound:

I enjoyed the opening theme enough to sit through it and the ED was good enough. The soundtrack was pretty generic but I didn't really notice a lot of obvious repeats so I was fine with it.


Character:

Elizabeth is a pile of useless shit, but, while being sort of obnoxious, it is amusing to see her get groped by Meliodas with no repercussions (And I'm a anime boy loving girl.) Elizabeth is a classic useless anime girl, but she doesn't annoy me by being all tsundere so points to that.


Meliodas is a OP, edgy protagonist but he somehow is his own character. Kaji Yuki as is VA does a great job being sort of carefree but a tad bit edgy. There isn't much to his character, but he is amusing and not the worst MC to follow (Fucking Charlotte and all it's shittyness) 


Ban, Diane and King are all good and serve their purpose. Ban's VA also voiced Makato in Free! which amuses me to no end. 


Nothing magical, but there all pretty good characters (expect Hawk, fuck Hawk)


Enjoyment:


I enjoyed the blatant ecchi aspect of the show and the action was engaging, I would say I liked it and will be looking out for the next season.


Overall:


If you like classic anime action, some tits, and cute boys (Yeah, you got me, I was here for Meliodas' character design. He's a shota MC, you don't see that a lot.) Your going to like this anime.


It's harmless for the most part and kept me interested (Something a lot of anime seem to not be able to do. I'm looking at you Blue Exorcist/Charlotte/SAO)  


Give it a watch~

[MILD SPOILERS]
Nanatsu No Taizai Season 1 is solely dedicated to explaining the backstory of each of the characters, including the ones that turn bad.
It however still provides alot of action and comedy, being a funny Shonen.
Story 9/10
The story talks about 7 beings whom were the strongest and cruelest order of Holy Knights in the Kingdom of Liones. They were formed by seven brutal criminals, who had all been convicted for grievous crimes and had carved the symbols of seven beasts onto their bodies. After having been framed for murdering the Great Holy Knight, they were indefinitely disbanded, as well as branded as traitors and villains.They are the main protagonists of the series.


The captain, Meliodas the Sin of Wrath is not your average captain in Shonen anime.


He is extremely overpowered and can probably one shot any holy knight but... He has a limit to his ability and when faced with a tough opponent like his teammate Ban the Sin of greed, can still take alot of damage.


In season 1, the story goes about explaining Ban's backstory in detail.


However, what I found interesting was that the members of the Sins somehow had interlinked backstories and the writer used Ban's story to link up to another character, so on and so forth.


Each of the character are extremely powerful but not to the Saitama extent, the writer draws a clear boundary between the weak and the strong.


What I enjoyed very much was the comedy in this anime and not to mention the well developed backstories and of course the fight scenes.


The story provides an action filled plot and not one episode goes by without an awesome fight scene.


The story shows Meliodas and a girl, Princess Elizabeth gathering up the old Sins to fight against the Great Holy Knights whom were said to be the strongest knights in Britiana.


The show then slowly reveals snippets of Meliodas's backstory, although not entirely but enough to last us through season 1.


Meliodas slowly gathered up MOST OF the members with some left out, most likely to be included in season 2.


The story overall was pretty well developed and well done. It thoroughly went through with most of the main character's backstory and not to mention the OVAs being made to further emphasize on certain backstories and give us a better understanding on why some characters hate each other etc.


Art 10/10


Being an A-1 film, I have no complaints with the artstyle.


Sound 9/10


I really do enjoy the music used in the anime, it fits the theme correctly.


Overall 9/10


I highly recommend this anime

Sometimes hype is justifiable, sometimes not. Nanatsu no Taizai (or Seven Deadly Sins in the west) is one of the cases of the second group. And I will explain why
Story - 3/10
Although the history keeps the spectator curious to know who are the terrible Seven Deadly Sins (with desapointing results) what they've really done and why are people blaming than to the catastophre that happened in the past, the anime doesn't show us nothing new. Is a terrible oldfashined poor screenwriting, with loads of deus ex machina, overpowerd characters that you know will always win, predictable action blended with comedy and a childish plot. Alsoit has terrible sexist ecchi scenes between Meliodas and Elizabeth that are revolting and unnecessary. 


Characters- 1/10


By far the worst part of the show. All characters are ridicoulously bad developed, have the most idiotic aspirations and do not change from the begining to the end. The one most ridicoulous, in fact, is Elizabeth, one of the most despicable representations of a woman on screen. It was not good just show her as the danzel in distress, she is a totaly dumbass in distress, something rooted on the old american movies and series, not accetable in the XXI century as feminine representation. Even more in the japanese animation, that has a powerfull background of great femine characters. Meliodas is also despicaple, just an overpowerd perv withouth a developed personality. The villain is just the common bad guy and the other sins, well, plain as a pizza, and, for that, a great desapointment. 


Art- 3/10

The character design is just lame, is even not crative. Is a rip off of a series of 80s anime and manga. Also the art looks like something from 20 years ago, with simple backgrounds and a excessive use of bright colors. 


Sound- 8/10

The only thing remarcable in the show, the soundtrack is very good and blends modern with classic perfectly. The ops. and endings are pretty decent too, however, are not remarcable at all. The sound efects are oldfashioned, but as the show is all oldfashioned, that is the minor problem. 


Personal Enjoyment and Overall


Nanatsu was to me the forgetable anime that televion stations positioned between memorable shows such as Digimon Adventure, Dragon Ball or Cardcaptor Sakura to mantain the kids tuned and therefore earn more money from sponsorships. Well, if it was not by the sexist ecchi. It's a lame, childish anime, oldfashined in the wrong way, with tem most simplistic plot and characters. So, why it is such a phenomenon in the anime community? Why is the most popular anime of 2014? Are people this nostalgic about the old times that even the bad nostalgic show is a sucess? I really cannot understand. But, as being born and raised in the 90's and early 2000's, Nanatsu would not be the success it is today if was launched in that time.

Very good so far, the art is reminiscent of the original Dragon Ball series but also brings a vibrant display of combat to the mix. The story flows very fluently through the episodes with very little filler. Each episode leaves you waiting for the next but the show ends a bit to abruptly and the extra 4 ova's bring little other than questions to the plot. It still leaves me excited for the second season. 
To expand on the TLDR version:
1. Story:
The story only receives a 7 for me because, albeit good, it is predictable. Although that does not stop the overall action and buildup that the show is able to produce. 


2. Art:

Nothing more to really add here then from my short form explanation. The show gave me a nostalgic feeling of being a kid waiting for the next episode of dragon ball to come on. 


3. Sound:

The sound and music did not do anything special but was good at key points of the story. Only really adding to the fight scenes but occasionally giving me chills of anticipation for a fight. 


4. Character:

Character build up and writing are executed very well. Although the same goes for the characters as the story, by being predictable, it still is thrilling to watch as the characters interact and build their character. 


5. Enjoyment:

For me, the enjoyment of this show really shines in the battles. This show is able to skip the 'building' phase that cripples some other similar shows. The characters are instantly shown as powerful, and this is able to lead to some very great fights not only at the end of the season but at the very first couple of episodes. 


6. Overall this show really encapsulates what it means to be a shonen anime. It really shines in its battles and combat scenes. 7/10

I just finished it so this review may not be impartial.
Art - 7 : overall good aniamtion, fluid, blends in the current gen. I was not really fan of the face of Meliodas, the round nose, it looks like a 90's shounen, and I couldn't think about anything else. Also some of the armors are gross AF.
Sound - 8 : gound songs, ambiance music and sounds didn't hurt my ears, so it's cool !
Character - 6 : This is were it starts to hurt. The characters are interesting ! You have a giant, a fairy king, a demon boy, an immortal, etc... But due tothe format, you don't have any clue on who are those people ! I can't even tell you who is the main character ! We know shit on King, Ban and Diane a bit (and we don't even know why she's alone). Meliodas gets no exposition, same for Gowther, and my favorite is the seven's sin, whose name is told twice in 24 episodes. And I can't even remember it ! I would love to know why is Meliodas demon (or part demon, I don't know), where does Ellie gets her powers, and who the f*ck is Gowther.\n\n
Story - 4 : Same here, the 24 episodes killed it. The end of the story is rushed, we don't get to know why is there a second demon under the castle, we don't know why Ellie can use Deus Ex Machina god-like powers, and it goes on. So many questions ! It's so frustrating, even the characters kept asking at the end "Is this really over?". Well I hope not. I need some explanations.\n\n
Enjoyment - 6 \n
Overall - 4 \n
The rating seems bad, but I actually enjoyed 90% of the anime, I was just so disappointed to get to episode 24 without knowing shit about what the hell is happening to those people I barely know. \n\n
Love you.

Nanatsu no Taizai, or The Seven Deadly Sins was a very good anime that I will probably keep in my mind for some time. The plot is simple, and develops greatly throughout the story. It kept me wanting to watch more after each episode, which allowed me to finish this anime is about two days.
Story-10
The story of Nanatsu no Taizai will always be somewhere in the back of my mind, because it was amazing. The concept of the story was a bit generic at first, but definitely develops throughout all 24 episodes. Elizabeth's reason for requesting help was very reasonable and after meeting every Sin,the plot would develop a little bit more. Small little things that were hinted at become a large part many episodes later, which was one of the best things about this anime (in my opinion of course).


Art-8

The art for this anime was very good, but due to my personal preference, I didn't enjoy it as much as others. The main characters' art was great but it seemed like the other characters were a bit neglected. They looked like they just took the build from another character, and changed the hair color or the eyes or something like that. 


Sound-10
