Overall: 3


WHY THE HYPE? WHY OH WHY?

Is it me or is the anime industry just going downhill? How many recent shows have I watched that were just plain dreadful? PLEASE Stop producing so many anime and refocus on quality! I've been catching up with animes from the end of the first decade/early 2010s this past year and most animes I've watched were either over-hyped or just dreadful being rated 8 or above here. Seriously? 

This is not bad. This sucks. This is not me thinking well... Not really my thing but I can understand why people like it. No. This is me saying I've seen LOTS of shounens which were pretty average all these "average shows" of the early 2000s were WAY better than this shit which got 8.25 on MAL at the time I'm writing these lines.

Man I don't know anymore.

having a good premises and being hooked by the first 3 episodes, the show starts out pretty well. however, after the first half of the show, it slides around. i would not recommend this to anyone who expects an anime with plot twists or interesting villains, however if they enjoy the soundtrack, character development and variety of different battles it offers, it may be worth their time.
the 7 deadly sins consists of interesting but sometimes predictable characters with a diverse cast of different personalities and backgrounds. the character designs are disgusting but the show makes up for that with the rest of its elements, containingan extremely powerful and beautiful soundtrack, interesting and different fights throughout different places and situations, and an exciting plot because of all the mysteries that the show offers throughout the time you watch it. the pacing is steady for the first half, but sometimes characters are thrown in out of nowhere, especially after the second half of the series. most of the series feels very rushed after the second half, and the pacing flies out of the window during that half. the final villain isn't particularly interesting, and had lost a lot of potential. but as stated before, the rest of the series's elements make up for that.

This is my first review here on MAL. I hope everybody here can get a good idea of what this show is about, and what you can expect from Seven Deadly Sins or Nanatsu No Taizai.
"nanatsu no taizai is another round of the mill shounen 0/10 do not recommend......BAHAHAHA yeah right."
All jokes aside.
The basic underlining of this show can be summed up to ones burden or "sin" if you will. We all have something we regret doing in our lifetime whether it is something small like eating your room mates food, or as bad cheating on a test. This is the premise of Nanatsu NoTaizai. One's sin.


To start off i'd like to say that i stumbled upon this show by accident. I found myself watching abridged episodes and, auto-play being what it is, brought me to Nanatsu No Taizai.


First let's get one of my dislikes out of the way.


Playing it safe.

This is why it get's a 9 from me. Playing it safe is also probably why it's not as popular as other shonen, i think the fact that it does this is the reason the series is held back a bit.


Plot convenience is also fairly prevalent here, although that could be summed up because of the OP nature of the main cast.


BUT!.


This anime is by no means predictable, it does a great job at surprising you with it's jacked-up action scenes and it's random(where the hell did that comes from?)scenes. But seeing as how strong the main characters are, it's really hard for the writers to work outside of this box. With everything this anime throws at you, it get's kind of dumbed-down, although with quite a few twists and turns. This is subjective as it was my own expectation that allowed this sort of thinking in the first place.


Story.

I don't really have much to say here except that this show does have a solid story and is well worth investing yourself in. It cuts right to the chase with the basic formula and setup of the world. But this is by no mean's the bottom line. You will soon find out that while it does have a pretty basic premise to start off with, it evolves into much more when backstories come into-play. The fan-service is hilarious and isn't over the top, and the story is very well rounded with some conclusions to be made in a second season(or so it's hinted at the end). This does not hinder the ending at all.


It has a good amount of(let's not fuck around)moments which in my opinion adds to the overall enjoyment. Which is why i slightly compare it to the higher rated shonen :)


Art and Design.

There's not much to say here really. It's absolutely gorgeous!. I especially love the fantasy style they went for, and to this day i haven't really seen anything similar to what they've done, in this industry alone of course.


Characters.

Every single character has a use and a good backstory, except for a couple side characters that didn't really have much screen time.


The main leading protagonist meliodas...well to put it simply, he's amazing!.


The main female protagonist, while i thought to be slightly annoying at first had some really awesome moments and doesn't beat up the main character for every little thing they do(which in my opinion, when you save somebodies life 21 times...you get it.)well...he does get beat up by Diane a lot. The main female leads development throughout the anime and toward the end was very well done. The others characters are way to likable, and are a lot deeper than your typical shonen character.


Sound. 

Sawano . The music itself is your classic medieval fantasy-esc sound, with quality skyrocketing as the anime further develops.


Enjoyment.

This anime has absolutely everything you could wish for. Comedy, parody, action, story, good character development, art and a great OST. It is by far one of my favorite shonen of all time!.


Overall

I think this anime deserves a lot more attention than it currently has, and i don't say these things lightly. In-fact i never have. Some people call this anime "generic shounen" oh boy is it anything but that. It pokes fun at itself and other generic shounen while maintaining it's own dignity, premise and story in the process. 


For a show of this quality it is a very underrated anime. i've never seen this specific anime mentioned anywhere. Not here, not facebook, nowhere in particular. I know this doesn't mean it's underrated but compared to some of the bigger titles it has little to no mention or recommendation, even though this particular anime is equivalent to if not better than a lot of the Shonen i've watched and deserves much more attention.


So in conclusion to my enjoyment of this anime, i will be supporting these developers in any way i possibly can, whether that is through buying copies or spreading the word.


9/10


Extremely enjoyable to watch.

*This review has had a quick edit! So if you've already read it give it another read!*
Nanatsu no Taizai is a very fun adventure that starts right away. We learn about the cast as we go, as if we've been shot out of a cannon. The cast, like the show, are easy to love although some cast members get more backstory then others.
This might seem to be a flaw but it reflects the outcome of the show. For example we wanted to see more of Gowther's past. It was too late into production and it's understandable that the studio couldn't afford to get another storyin. The reason I'm letting this slide is because we have Ban, King, and Diane in one story-arch.

It does check-out, and it's not a boring story in retrospect.



I have very few quarrels with this anime, on a personal level I did not like how they treated King's story regarding what ended up happening. This part of the story made me cry a lot, but I daresay, it makes you seriously hate the villain.

Which in turn, makes a good villain.


Give her a watch.

Or better yet, buy the series.

It's worth your GP.

I actually created an account just to review The Seven Deadly Sins.
I've watched my fair share of animes, and this one tops the cake (so far anyway).
I was reading some of the reviews, and some I just do not agree with and think they don't go in-depth enough, so I wanted to write my own.
****(MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS)****
The Seven Deadly Sins is great. Point blank. It has a great story line and gives you tastes of background information a little at a time of each character so you can identify with them easier. It is a tear-jerker, comedy, and has a perverted take all in one.What more could you want?


I read a review where they said the characters' "markings" do not correspond with their personalities. This is, in fact, a lie.


Let's start with Meliodas. His sin is Wrath, which he portrays very well. He is the strongest of them all. He also has demon blood inside of him, and from what I can tell, he has a secret about him.


Elizabeth. She isn't part of the Seven Deadly Sins, but we do find out later that she is a goddess and she does have powers. Hence why she is very kind, helping, and soft. One of her known powers is healing.


Diane. Her sin is Envy. Her power has a strong connection with the Earth. (Hence "Green with Envy"). She is also very jealous of many things, especially when it comes to Meliodas and Elizabeth. 


Ban. His sin is Greed. He is very greedy for the taste of blood. He loves conflict. Plus, he's immortal. Another example is in a background story of his when he was trying to take from the fountain of youth.


King. His sin is Sloth. He is a fairy king. He floats around with is pillow and is even seen sleeping. He does not engage in physical contact. Instead, he just uses hand movements to control his weapons. He is very weak in physical fist fighting. Hence his sloth nature.


Gowther. His sin is Lust. In one episode, he uses his powers to make a mob of fighters "fall in love" with himself, Ban, and Meliodas. He even saves Guila from transforming into a demon with, from what she says, the power of love.


Merlin. Her sin is Gluttony. We haven't experienced much of her character in the anime yet, along with the seventh unknown sin. 


Would I recommend this anime to anyone? The question is obvious. Of course. And I've stated my reasons.

Nanatsu no Taizai (The Seven Deadly Sins) was suggested to me by one of my best friends and, I have to thank him for recommending it as this show was probably the best show I've watched since Noragami Aragoto. 
The seven deadly sins is pretty much your average shone anime but, with the storyline of getting the band back together a story arc I've always enjoyed. The story takes place in the kingdom of Britainia during medical times where an order of seven knights (the sins) have been framed for murder and, the princess of the kingdom tries to get them to help save thekingdom. We follow this princess Elisabeth and, dragon sin of wrath Meliodas on their quest to bring the others together.


The story was pretty basic and, easy to follow and, it thankfully did not have much filler. I liked the way the sins were introduced and, the each have their own unique personalities with my personal favorite being Ban the fox sin of greed who is the most charismatic and, emotionally compelling character of the show as he is totally awesome and, has the best story arc in the show and, it feature a great romance story. The story arc between King and Dianne (Sloth & Envy) was also a pretty good story arc with an amazing flashback episode. Gowther and, Merlin felt more like supporting characters as they didn't get much development this season but, still has their badass moments. Meliodas reminded me of Saitama in a way in that he was indestructible in a way and, comic relief to the max and, there was never any dull moment with him on screen. Elisabeth on the other hand is another plot device and, towards the end of the season one of the most annoying characters I've seen in recent memory. The supporting cast is great for the most part I loved the knights of Liones and, the antagonist were defiantly a surprise and, semi well established. 


The animation pretty good, nothing really stands out in terms of location design. Character design is pretty crisp and solid thanks to the wonderful staff of A1. The openings and, ending were completely forgettable in my eyes I don't even remember the names of the songs or the artists to be perfectly honest.


The action sequences of the show were absolutely fluid in motion and, phenomenal especially the final battle of the season, there defiantly are large number of lol moments as well as holy shit moments. I loved the progression of the story and, characters as it was well paced. I was blown away by the twists and, turns of the story and, there were defiantly a number of emotional moments even though some things did drag on a bit.


Overall I would say that Nanatsu no Taizai is a great way to introduce someone to anime, I feel as if it would be a great first anime for people to watch but, as I have seen many shine anime I did not enjoy the season as much as I would have liked but, it is still a really good show.

The seven deadly sins was one of those fantasy animes that really do a good job at working with elements of medieval times and other things fantasy. Seven deadly sins had some pretty decent comedy as well as serious elements to  the show that you can get into. I found myself kind of getting dragon ball vibes from the show when they use their magic, because they call out the names of their attacks a lot during battle sequences. The show also had a deep and immersing backstory to it and great artwork to keep you interested in the show. Although the show hasa lot of fanservice and doesn't really get a full explanation as to some of the things that happened during the show. All the more reason i'm excited to go and watch season 2 right after i'm done with this review. I would recommend this to anyone who likes fantasy, comedy and doesn't mind a  lot of fanservice. See you all after season 2!

Seven Deadly Sins is an anime that is difficult to pin down. This is because, like  many other anime, it offers an unpolished and yet highly enjoyable experience. The result is that it has many flaws and yet an abundance of positives. In many ways its raw and charming nature is what makes it a good anime but, the glaring mistakes cannot and should not be overlooked.
Story line (7) - It would be disingenuous to suggest that the plot is in anyway unique. Avid anime watchers will be all too familiar with this epic fantasy style plot; in which a fellowship of adventurers mustovercome world-threatening evil. Despite this, Seven Deadly Sins manages to provide a passable story line. It is not so generic that you'd describe it as banal nor is it so grand that you'd describe it as convoluted. Seven Deadly Sin's plot line sits in the comfortable middle-ground of "good".


Art (9) - Despite lacking in other areas, this anime really excels in its visual effects and artistic details. Vibrant landscapes, charred battlefields and iridescent magical effects are copious throughout. The art really triumphs with regards to the combat. Many times I found myself aghast at how brutal and yet beautiful the battle scenes were animated; often a sundry of bold colours. Facial features and movement are both also done to a very high standard.


Sound (9) - Aside from the art the other standout feature of this anime is its fantastic soundtrack. Those with a keen ear will notice that tracks are often recycled but, that they are never used inappropriately and thus always have maximum effect. The soundtrack has outstanding musical quality and makes full use of the ambiance to deliver a truly powerful audiovisual experience. The only criticism of the music is that a greater variety of tracks could potentially enhance the anime however, Seven Deadly Sin's quality over quantity style is certainly refreshing.


Character (7) - Much like the story line the character development certainly leaves something to be desired. In season one I was beguiled by the idea of seven incredibly powerful and mysterious warriors that had been banished for heinous crimes but, once the identities and personalities of the crew has been revealed the air of mystery quickly disappears. While there is character development to a degree, for certain characters it feels like they are little more than place holders. The anime shows glimpses of further development and interest at times but these opportunities need to be explored further. All-in-all the characters aren't badly written whatsoever but some are far more interesting than others.


Enjoyment (8) - Despite its flaws, such as the run-of-the-mill story line and a few lackluster characters, Seven Deadly Sins is a very enjoyable anime. It won't revolutionise the anime industry or change your whole perception of animated series but, it will most definitely evoke emotions and give you a strong sense of satisfaction. In many ways Seven Deadly Sins is on the cusp of being a 10/10 anime, if it could just iron out a few flaws. The second season for example, in my opinion, was a huge let down. It is careless mistakes like this that stop Seven Deadly Sins from pushing into the upper echelon of anime.

For the first half of 2015, The Seven Deadly Sins (the manga) was on top of the selling chart with around 10.3 million copies sold. The Seven Deadly Sins anime was the 30th best selling anime of the first half of 2015. On the Anime News Network, it is rated as Very Good.
Personnally, I think that this series is very intersesting and I love the fact that those who were once considered evil are now been asked to fight those who used to be good, it's an interesting plot. The characters are very well-thought and really different one from another, which makes the series richerand keeps us attracted to it. The animation is good and the drawing is not too complicated,which goes well with the comedic aspect of the anime. I also likes the soudtrack pretty much. The only weak point of the series, according to my opinion, is the love story that takes place in the middle of it, which weakens a little bit the action and comedic bases of the story.

I was hesitate to watch this anime because of the art. But this show is the bees knees! Do NOT let the negative reviews deter you. The one and only thing is CAN MY GALS WEAR MORE CLOTHING PLEASE. Everytime Elizabeth is about to get a new outfit I`m like thank God. And then it`s the same skimpy thing or even less. You can tell the artists really care for big boobs and no waist *rolls eyes* but anyways. The plot is so good. It did what was required. The only time I`ve ever read ahead in the manga is with attack on titan andI did the same for this. Iconic. Also just try it out, what I love about this anime is at the end of the seasons there is no cliffhangers like for example someone went missing or dying, there is none of that. So the creators/directors want you to have enough sleep for the next season. As I said before, iconic.

I dont usually write reviews for shows, but I guess my feelings on what I just watched were so strong that I just needed to write about it.
This is by far the worst anime I have seen... ever.
It's quite harsh but as a person who loves shounen, I tried super hard to find something that makes it stands out. And after comparing this with seasonal shounen like Magi and Sword Art Online(yes, even sword art online is better than this), I can't find anything at all.
Story - So the story I find to be the weakest part of the anime. Good shows take previously donestorylines and plots and uses their direction, character and world to make it interesting... but none of that is done well. The settings are so similar I can show you two episodes in completely different locations and you couldn't even tell that you were in a different arc. The conflicts are for the most part, us vs them, and for a show about sins it's rarely about inner conflicts and more about what's going on around them but... the story is basically told from the very beginning and it's no shock as to what happens next at all. And i'm not talking about how the heroes win, theres much more to that when I mean predictability. 


Art - I think the story struggles a lot because of the art direction. This is going to sound weird but, the show is too god damn bright and colurful when it shouldn't be. There are some scenes that try to get you to feel emotions but when the environment is so bright, colorful and happy, who cares if someone cries? The actual animation, fight scenes and such are at least done where it looks visually pleasing, even the 3D parts which don't strain your eyes. I wouldn't say the show stands out compared to other shounen, but at least it's above average.


Sound - There's not really a lot I want to say for sound because overall, the music fit well and there wasn't too much that I disliked, but some things just weren't my taste. A criticism I have that isn't too big is that during the mid-way pauses, sometimes Hawk would make these oink noises that were just unpleasing and annoying. But thats pretty minor.


Characters - For characters, I'm going to go over the ones I want to talk about one by one.


Ban: When it comes to characters I actually like, Ban is basically the only one. He's cool, isn't a one-dimensional character and has inner conflicts that he fights throughout the series. He's fun to watch in fights, and uses his immortality ability in a way thats fun for the viewer as well. 


Melodias: He's a very typical main protagonist for a shounen, but unlike the other tropes in the series, he's not done poorly, but I would call it average. I do think the whole broken-sword fighting was a cool aspect of his character, but everything in this series gets worse due to....


Elizabeth: This fucking character. Oh my god if MAL had a least favorites list this character would be #1 without a doubt. She is the prime example of how to make a character no one cares about into a character everybody fucking hates. For the beginning half of the series she's just crying and being well, useless despite everybody trying to help her. When she's crying I couldn't give a shit at all because it was so predictable. And her relationship with Melodias is just poorly written. She weakens every character because she tries to be something she isn't. Then we get to the conclusion of the series, and its hard to talk about it without spoiling, but this part of the story is honestly astonishing how they take this shitty character and make it worse. I'm going to talk briefly about the ending of the story, so if you want to avoid them please skip the rest of this paragraph, just know that it ruins her character. Elizabeth's plot twist fills the show with plot holes, as the idea of death is a fucking joke now. Hawk's moment specifically is treated horribly and I blame both the story and the characters for what happened with her at the end, stories should never toy whether or not a character can come back to life, and for gods sake don't fucking pull it twice in a row. 


The rest of the characters just follow tropes and cliches and don't really do anything interesting, with a few minor exceptions. They're all incredibly 1 dimensional and as I said, Ban is the only likable and 2 dimensional character. So props to having a character I like I guess?


Enjoyment: Didn't really enjoy the series at all, only watched because I was interested in seeing how it would end. In fact, it was actually getting gradually better up until the last 2-3 episodes where it just reminded me that this show was not worth a season 2, and I love how the series ends by reminding us that Elizabeth is coming back for another adventure and that Ban isn't. Telling, isn't it?


Overall: just a bad show overall, if you're interested in shounen and want to see what a bad shounen is, I reccomend this. If you want to see some good shounen, Magi is probably the better option, as the first season is 25 episodes as well, and has actually interesting characters, an interesting magic system and a much more interesting world.

If you haven't seen this anime and you want to go in spoiler-free then I have a simpler review without spoilers here:
The story was awful. Good backstories to the characters, but that was kind of it.
The visuals were pretty good. Nothing great, but still good
The music was very forgettable
I really like the characters
Spoiler-filled part:
I'll start off with the visuals:
It was pretty good. I enjoyed the style and the animation was pretty good. Nothing great, but still pretty good.
Next, characters:
This was definitely my favorite part of the show. Most of the characters had a good backstory. But there were two characters I didn't like as much.Melodias, Elizabeth, and Hawk. I'll start off with Melodias, cause he's the one I liked the most out of the three. Melodias had some parts that I liked, but it wasn't enough. He was a pervert most of the show, which made him very unlikeable. He also felt very bland. He was another shounen (I don't know if it classifies as a shounen, but whatever) main character to me. Next, Elizabeth. She didn't have any effect on the story for the longest time, she was just there to be Meliodas play doll until the end where she actually does something. And then we have Hawk. She is probably the most annoying anime character I have ever seen. She didn't have any effect on the story, other than her making Meliodas not rape Elizabeth, and she was just annoying all the time. I was happy when she died for an episode, too bad she didn't. \n\n\n
Next, the music:\n\n
Very forgettable. I don't remember any of the songs. I know I liked one of the battle songs, but I already forgot it. Not terrible, just very forgettable.\n\n\n
Next, the story:\n\n
This was the thing that I liked the least. Not that I didn't like the plot as a whole. I liked the idea, the concept. But there were so many things in the story that were weird. Like King didn't get a reaction from seeing a friend that he murdered a hundred years before, Meliodas seemed to really care that the enemy took Elizabeth he didn't show any love for Elizabeth except sexual before that, why didn't ban try to kill Meliodas as fast as possible (he was going to kill Meliodas to get Elaine back from the dead) and so many more. \n
Don't get me wrong, there were things that I liked. Like the humanity in some of the villains (but those who eventually switch side. The rest aren't presented as humans)and that Elizabeth has an effect on the story (in the end. Before that, she has no purpose than to be the subject of a joke) but it was very bad in my opinion.\n\n
So in the end, I didn't like this anime.

One of the worst anime I've ever seen yet for some bizarre reason (at the time of writing) this show (and its 2nd season) have scored 8.29+. I can't fathom that at all! Other anime (such as Darling In The Franxx - to name  but one I'm currently watching) are better on so *many* levels yet they can't even scratch an 8.0!
I'll forget the novel-sized rant I put on Reddit but the main reasons I dislike this anime so much (apart from the art style - I just don't get along with it) are as follows:
Amnesia!
It's a cheap writer's trick but if used well,it can be utterly amazing. Suffice to say 7 Deadly Sins not only doesn't use it well.. it uses it incredibly badly TWICE! And with the same character! That's just lazy and so, *so* bad!


Gowther.

Gowther is by far the most uninteresting and frustrating character. He's emotionally empty and socially inept (which are things I usually empathise with in a character as I'm terrible at social cues myself etc.. So the fact that I don't like him where I normally would in an anime, is saying something!) He does dumb things that make no sense (for plot progression I presume?) that hurt people and cause ridiculous issues! There is no way a character would ever do the things he does, even a robot would have pause and reconsider its options!


Plot holes and flashbacks.

It seems like nothing in this show was planned from the start (even though I understand that it's based off of source material too?). At later points in the show they shoe-horn in flashbacks to explain what random things they've decided to happen, happened.. Someone suddenly becomes a good guy? Flashback. Someone has a new power they've never shown before? Flashback! Someone made a promise to someone and loves them where they were deadly enemies before? Flashback!


I think at one point it was explained that someone was only a bad guy because they were being spied on the entire time or something.. I'll admit that you *do* see a raven or something in some scenes that he's in but it feels more like an animator just so happened to include the bird in the backgrounds in his scenes and they were able to quickly think up a reason for it and make it into something... "let's put this in and think of something much later in the series for it to be".


All of these flashbacks cause massive, massive plot holes and they tried to fix some of them with guess what, flashbacks!


Conclusion:

I really can't understand why this show has such a high rating.. I can only guess that it's because the manga/LN has been going on for *so* long that it has a massive fan base and they'll upvote anything to do with it.. Or I've just become jaded to this kind of show and can't appreciate them anymore?

"Nanatsu no Taizai" seemed quite promising, having characters on the cover of the anime that looked colorful and diverse, like any successful Shounen anime that aired... but after watching this season, i felt that there were a number of things that was lacking in the show. Hence, my rating of the show overall had dropped to a 6, even when i first thought that it might actually be worth a 9 or 10 with its current popularity.
Story: 6
I found myself quite interested in some of the backstories of the Sins, such as Ban and King's. They were well written imo, but the fights in theshow were quite a letdown to me. I felt that they do not actually have a very big twist, and the outcome for almost all fights are quite predictable. After going through a few battles at the beginning, I am almost certain that the protagonists’ side will always win by some means, and it always involves a new ability that would come as a surprise to the audience every time. Too many of these surprises made the show repetitive to me, and the show seemed less appealing to me as a result.


Art: 7

Although the colors used by A-1 Pictures were rich and very consistently presented throughout the world that Nanatsu no Taizai takes place in, the same cannot be said for the animations used for each characters’ unique skills in battle. Powers harnessed by each of the major characters in the show do not seem impressive enough in the aesthetic sense, and they do not actually feel truly special to any one of the characters. The attacks always seem to look the same to me, always accompanied by a flash of white light followed by a huge lump of debris being thrown about. (e.g. Gil’s lightning attacks feel almost the same with every strike, regardless of how differently he says it; the lightning animation is always the same, making the attacks and fights seem really bland and boring.) 


Sound: 8 

The music was pretty decent! OST sounded good (especially Perfect Time), and the 2nd Opening was a nice shounen tune to hype me up for the episodes. MAN WITH A MISSION does a good job.


Character: 6

When Meliodas started to hunt down his former comrades, I thought that it was going to be promising when it started off by meeting Ban and Diane. Altho Diane's lines were pretty disappointing and somewhat cheesy, Ban's backstory and lines were pretty smooth. But after seeing Gowther and Merlin, they just seemed like they were having different personalities just for the sake of being different members of the group. Although they do seem like characters with some depth, I feel like they had way more potential than this, and that their characters weren't as nicely fleshed out as someone like Ban. King was pretty decent tho. Hopefully we will see some more development in the ongoing Season 2.


Enjoyment: 4

This was pretty saddening for me. The show came strong with its first 5-6 episodes and got me hooked, but the premise of the show started to get pretty boring. The main antagonist for the season turned out to be someone that didn't get developed well in the season, with the help of only a handful of short flashbacks to get to know the dude. I found myself more interested in finding out who the next member of the Sins was and their backstories, and didn't really enjoy the rest of the season after that.


Overall: 6 

With all that negative stuff being said, I still feel that Nanatsu no Taizai wields the influence of a Shounen genre heavyweight and rightfully so, even being one of the more happening series in WSM. It just isn't an objectively good anime in my opinion, and dulls in comparison to some other Shounen shows that i happen to watch.

To begin this review, I’d like to say that if you’re looking for a show with an exceptionally deep plot line which shatters cliches and is groundbreaking in its storytelling, this anime is not for you. But if you’re fine with watching a lighted hearted, superhero-style, comfort food show which you can watch without getting anxiety over which major character is going to be killed off next, then Seven Deadly Sins is very good.
   The characters are definitely the series’s strongest point. Most of the characters, including both the Sins and the Holy Knight antagonists, are unique in both personalityand design. The interactions between the characters is usually light and comedic, but still goes a long way in developing them as people. Both the protagonist’s and antagonist’s motivations are plainly  expressed, which was very refreshing (even if the characters’ reasoning was a but silly at times). Many of the Sins are especially likeable, with Ban, King, and Gowther being the most interesting. Ban is almost used as a Deadpool-type character (because of his ability to regenerate from literally anything) and there’s a running gag where he gets punched in half or blown up and nobody really cares (including himself). 


   This isn’t to say I didn’t have a problem with any of the characters; Melodias, the Captain of the Sins, is an immortal with the appearance and intelligence of a fifteen year old. He’s also pretty much the most basic and annoying piece of shit you could write into a show. He’s overpowered as all hell, and literally pulls a new god-tier power out of his ass every episode. In addition, he is a molester and pervert, who gropes the female lead at every possible moment. This is probably meant to be funny, but the joke usually falls flat because it doesn’t really fit into anything else going on. 


   Speaking of the female lead, Elizabeth- a princess of the very stereotypical fantasy kingdom- is such a badly written character. She’s literally just a pair of giant tits who exists purely for fan service and for Melodias to molest. She does nothing, has no personality, and is a literal detriment to the team. Even Hawk, the annoying talking animal sidekick, was more interesting and useful than Elizabeth. Also, she falls in love with Melodias from the instant she meets him solely because he’s op as hell (which is a terrible, overused cliche). Even so, the show isn’t really sexist; Diane the giant is intimidating on paper (although she doesn’t really use her hyped up strength to any great effect) and there are several female Holy Knights who were fairly well fleshed out and kicked major ass. The major detriment to the characters was probably the overuse of fan-service (the female protagonists outfits and Melodias’s fondness for sticking his head up skirts) which was really unfortunate because, overall, this aspect of the show was really very strong.


 The overall story is very, very cliche fantasy, which is not inherently a bad thing if you like that sort of thing. Even so, I found the world-building to be very weak, and it almost seemed as if the writers were randomly throwing different fantasy cliches into the story as it went along. King Arthur even randomly made an appearance, and I was just like “huh?” But keeping the fantasy monster-mash in mind, the plot was paced so that along with the great characters (not you melodias), it kept me interested and entertained. 


   The soundtrack was alright, but the ending song to the first half actually caught my attention. It fit well with the overall ~aesthetic~ and along with the shot of the Sins’ wanted posters waving in the wind, it was actually kind of cool. Or maybe it wasn’t, and I’m just goofy as hell. Who knows. Anyway, the art and animation is very well done, and it’s obvious the show had quite the budget behind it. 


   Overall, I enjoyed it. It had quite a lot of flaws, but none that were so heinous I wasn’t able to overlook them and see the show for what it was. Will some people dislike this show? Certainly. Will some people despise this show? Certainly. But I enjoyed it, was entertained by it, and felt like my time was well-spent in the end. 


7/10

Given the choice, I would sooner watch a series which let me discover what its central message was rather than a show which tried at every other moment to force its message upon me. This for my money is the difference between Ah My Goddess! and Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid. It's also the difference between The Seven Deadly Sins and Fairy Tail. Sure, friendship is a wonderful thing, but we don't need to be reminded of this every 10 minutes or so (a slight exaggeration, just go with it).
The Seven Deadly Sins is one of the better shonen series currently floating around out there, withlikable characters matching those of every other shonen series, decent animation and character design. Its story doesn't relegate itself to telling a long succession of story arcs. Instead it focuses on just one season-long arc, which at times plays out more like a Fire Emblem game than your typical shonen anime. There's also a noticeable lack of plot armour here, with our heroes facing a lot of tense situations throughout.\n\n
This is probably me being presumptuous, but any Fairy Tail fan looking for a more mature approach to storytelling without losing any fun elements could do a lot worse than check this out.

It's has a great storyline, every single charper is catchy and the character design is good enough for a series with so many comedy overtones. 
The most positive point of the series is how most of the conflicts end in two or fewer chapters (with exceptions in the final part), thanks to the speed of the individual stories of each character, you can not avoid remembering their connections to the main plot .
The soundtrack is great, although at the beginning it has more catchy songs and they do not leave so many empty spaces of musical sound. But the second part of the series ismore ocher since the lack of justifications about how they get their skills.\n
Seeing this I was pleasantly surprised, does not follow the style of Shonen but takes the camaraderie of them and submits them to an adventure of the fantasy animes.

Honestly, I had very few expectations going into the anime. I knew that this had been famous for quite some time, but I've been pretty out of the anime loop until recently and my standards for Shonen anime have sadly dropped a lot. I don't have a certain style of anime that I really love( I've watched it all from yaoi to comedy to shonen), I just like a well written plot. I don't mean that it has to be super deep or very out of the ordinary, but rather something that keeps me interested. Usually, for shonen, the characters tend to be placed onthe back seat while the plot and the fighting and whatever, probably war, that is going on is a lot more emphasized than character development. In terms of this textbook formula, Nanastu no Taizai is not that different. It has the classic over-powered male character with the somewhat damsel in distress type female lead. But I will give it this-- it kept me interested. A lot of shonen have a bunch of fillers and nonsensical episodes that just show off how strong the male lead is, but Nanastu no Taizai used each episode to further the plot, even if a majority of it was fighting. The anime did also make me pretty invested in each character. Although there was a severe lack of character development, with arguably only one character having any sort of personal journey, each character did have their unique quirks and abilities and their backstories and such made them a bit more flushed out in terms of character portrayal. Another thing that Nanastu no Taizai did really well was it kept a balance. I mean this in two ways. One, it balanced out the comedy and slightly more plot heavy aspects of the show, and though shonen typically don't have massive problems with this, it becomes a real deal-breaker when the writers are trying to be funny and failing. Secondly, and much more importantly to me, Nanastu no Taizai established a few rules and actually stuck to them. This a problem I see in a lot of shonen anime. It starts off well and within some boundaries of reason, but as the show progresses, the writers start to really stretch my suspension of disbelief in an effort to make characters seem more and more powerful. That is my #1 pet peeve of shonen anime. It just becomes repetitive and really irritating when characters just have these unexplained add-ons in terms of ability. That, to me, is just a sign of sloppy writing and I usually just stop watching the anime or have to mentally prepare myself to watch the standard of the anime to drop severely. I am very happy to say Nanastu no Taizai did not have this problem.


On a separate note, I like the animation. It was, once again, not anything super special, but it was easy on the eyes and well executed. The fighting scenes looked really nice as well. Other than that, there's not much to be said about the visual aspect of it. I did like the music though. The one hype song that came up during the really intense fight scenes was really nice. 


Overall, I'd say that Nanastu no Taizai is a pretty typical shonen anime, but it is well executed and well thought out. I would recommend it to any Naruto or Fairy Tail or other classic shonen fan.

Story:
Overall this is a good show. The story is a little by the numbers though and there are quite a few beats where you'll be left scratching your head at how convoluted some things can be. Overall though its and enjoyable enough story, just very underwhelming and not really anything to write home about. If you're looking for an anime to watch and turn your brain off, this is (mostly) the show you're looking for. Plus its on netflix (which most people have) so its easy to get a hold of and binge without having to worry about subpar subs or dubs.
 I just wishthat the sins werent so heavily established as being absurdly OP. It takes a lot of tension out of most of the fights. Even at the end when they fight whats basically the devil it becomes hard to think that meliodas or the sins are going to lose. Though admittedly that issue is mostly fixed towards the end when it starts to look like the sins are capable of losing. Which happens more than you would think based off of the first few episodes. Also there are a few too many unresolved plot lines and unanswered questions for a 24 episode series for my liking. But luckily it (mostly) doesnt take away from your enjoyment while watching the show. Just while thinking about it


Art:


Its good. Lots of fun, action, and the character designs really stand out. its all pretty well animated. My only gripe with the character designs however do have to do with the minor characters. They all look very drab and basic compared to the Sins. So much so that it sort of helps with the story at some times. In particular, the main villain(s). They just look so basic and uniteresting that you wont realize that their the villain until its made very obvious that they are. Which helps, but at the same point, certainly does the story no favors, as it makes the villains seem forgettable. Which I would argue isnt exactly a bad thing, if the show were shorter. With a show's arc running over 13 episodes, I would argue that the villains need to have more substance to them. But that might just be me. 


Sound:


Sounds good. Neat music, basic enough score. Moving on. 


Character:


6 out of the 8 main characters are pretty dope characters. Diane is adorable but not overly so where she becomes annoying or is made into a damsel. The princess isnt exactly going to be a feminist icon but her goals are made clear and she is very relatable overall. King has got to hit way too close to home for lots of weebs and neckbeards that will watch the show, but not in an overly cringey way, certainly not in an unhealthy way. Ban at first seems incredibly annoying but by the time you learn his backstory and his cooking skills get rid of one of the most annoying running gags in the series you'll learn to love him too. And Gowther seems like they could be a great LGBT character, though I wish they were given more backstory (more than what we got anyway) so maybe in season 2 (which just started airing at the time of my writing this review). And Merlin, while having an overly fanservicey design still has an intruging air of mystery about her to make watching her interesting. Though I certainly wish that we would get more of her (looks like we will in season 2). Even some of the minor characters, despite having mostly dull designs are incredibly well developed and fleshed out. It leaves you wanting to root for them.


But there are two massive issues with the show, and they are two of the main three characters that we follow through most of the series! bwah bwahhhhhhh. Meliodas is wayyyyy too overpowered. Like. Stupidly so. At first you think it might be fun to watch like in One Punch Man or Mob Psycho 100. But nope. Its everything that people think One Punch Man would be when they heard the pitch. The fight scenes involving him are robbed of all tension, and its just annoying. Plus he's a massive perv. Which they try to play off as cute, but despite his 12 year old body, he's still like forty or some shit. Probably way older. Just makes me hate him more. Also he keeps secrets from his best friends for little to no reason. Hes an awful leader. Ask anyone who has held a job for more than a month. Good leaders communicate. Meliodas doesnt communicate. He just asks and takes. He sucks and I hate him. 


The other massive issue with the show is the pig, Hawk. He's not cute. He's annoying AF. He constantly tries to be endearing but it jsut doesnt pay off. None of his jokes land. He's like if your 14 year old cousin's instagram account was made into an anime talking pig. It especially sucks when they try to make him into the emotional core of the show. It just takes you out of it completely and there were several parts thoughout the end of the show where my eyes rolled so far into the back of my head I could see into my skull and see the aneurism that this stupid fucking pig was giving me.


Enjoyment:


I enjoyed everything but the pig, meliodas, and the lack of stakes as a result of meliodas or my hatred for said pig. 


Overall: 


6/10

Would recommend, but only to those such as myself who also have no lives and are free to complain about pigs in a japanese cartoon on an internet forum post that nobody will ever read. Or if you want to get fucking drunk while binging an anime. (Take a drink everytime meliodas or one of the sins is stupid OP, only rule)

It was fun... until the director (can't say if author too, haven't read manga) decided to add some angst somewhere around 13th episode. From this moment anime was becoming less and less enjoyable. This whole seriousness felt pushed, fake and sometimes even cringe. Especially around romance threads - almost all of them turned cheesy, unnatural and one (I'm looking at you, Ban...) even a bit of sick. Nanatsu no Taizai's humor wasn't very subtle but at least it was, and alltogether with nice dynamics and bit of fanservice it was just matching as a simple entertainment. When anime decided to became serious, the whole funwas gone. If I want feels, I'd watch a nice written drama, not something which is by definition written as simple, flat and uncomplicated. What is nice for humor and action, won't get along well with different threads. What a pity, Nanatsu, you failed here. I'm not regreting spending time with it but I'm not gonna watch 2nd season nor read the manga.

I'd like to preface this review by saying that I rate things mostly based on my enjoyment of the series, especially regarding shounen series, and these are just my opinions. This review will be surface level, very short, and basically devoid of spoilers.
I personally really loved this series. I have been putting off watching any shounens for a while because of the typical tropes that have become so prevalent in each one with very similar and predictable plots. This anime took me by surprise, while it still had some typical shounen aspects, it felt very original. Whether it be the characters or the plot, itall felt very refreshing and I was genuinely excited for each new episode. The end of the series left me craving for more so, while I'm not usually one to read manga, I may end up actually picking up this series.


One thing that may put some people off is the ecchi tag, but I feel like that the "ecchi moments" were few and far between so they didn't take away from the series although ecchi has never really bothered me personally. I think my only real gripe with the show was Hawk. I really have grown to despise the token talking animal/creature character in these types of series but that's just me. I didn't really enjoy the endless flow of "scraps" and "pork" jokes thrown in every other episode either. 


Overall wonderful series, I would recommend to anyone looking for a fun/feel good fantasy action series with OP characters.

Seven Deadly Sins—Known for its ecchi(although it actually doesn't have much) and its overpowered main character(can't disagree), its one of the post popular shows made by A-1 Pictures. This is a tale much like Yona of the Dawn, a princess gathers a strong group to bring down the powerful enemies.Its a thrilling adventure—and nothing less.
Story(8) Like I said, it is very much like Yona of the Dawn. The story is captivating because the main point is to gather the most powerful people, which is extremely exciting. They also have to bring down their common enemy, the Holy Knights. However, this type of story isn't unique,which is why it's not a ten.


Art(9) The art has a special bubbly feeling to it. Especially the character designs of Meliodas and Elizabeth, the art doesn't seem to have a dark and serious setting. The colors are bright, and the backgrounds and castles look wonderful. Not much else to say here.


Sound(9) The first intro I really loved, a lot more than the second one. It had one of those catchy tunes that you will remember forever. The sound effected the show a lot, and the sound tracks of the battle scenes and death scenes were amazing. The part where Elaine gave the water to Ban had THE MOST EFFECT ON ME, especially with the fiery art and the ABSOLUTELY AMAZING music that played at that scene. That scene was one of the most impactful I have ever watched in anime.  The sound and music are a BIG part of this anime's feel.


Character(7) The part that's lacking in this show is the characters, and the character development. The characters all have different powers, and different strengths. Its easy to notice the difference between them, which is why many people would like the characters. However, compared to Yona of the Dawn, the character development isn't great. Sure, there are a few short flashbacks here and there, but it doesn't go in depth to each of the individual characters. This show would be much better if we knew the characters and their backstories more, especially Meliodas. The characters are also "flat characters," which means that they don't change too much throughout the show.


Enjoyment and Overall(8): This show was enjoyable, and it was fun seeing Meliodas destroy many people. The fight scenes were great, and there was even some decent comedy in there. I would have liked to see more developments between the characters and their interactions with each other. Overall, this was a very enjoyable show .

I didn’t enjoy this show, but it had some redeeming qualities. The best way I can put it is that The Seven Deadly Sins is like a strawberry smoothie with a little mucus mixed in. Ban and Gilthunder and King’s past are some of the absolute best things about this show. I enjoyed the slow development of who the big bad bosses really were and some information about Meliodas’ true origin. Fight scenes are nicely-executed as well. 
However, I was really turned off by the copious blood vomits/spit-takes (it's like the blood spews out in two forms: bite-sized nuggets and water hose pressure DX), Meliodas’gropey-grabby hands (the fanservice feels icky and too contrived; sorry not sorry), and Elizabeth’s utter uselessness (I swear her personality is “best girl”; I don’t care too much about moe chicks). The piggy character runs its mouth too much for me, but it fulfilled the animal sidekick role well enough.


Now, I love romance as I’m always reading a good shoujo, but I didn’t care for Elizabeth’s undying love for our golden boy. I actually preferred Ban’s thinly-developed love more even though I can’t stand lolicon stuff. 

The story moved too slowly in certain episodes before picking up an exciting pace toward the 20’s.  


MISC: ANIMATION, VOICE ACTING

As far as the English dub, I thought the voices were good. I think each voice fit its character well though Elizabeth’s voice is sickly sweet and her crying leaves a lot to be desired. 


The animation is very fluid and smooth, but some of the bodies look weirdly proportionate (i.e Griamore and Elizabeth).


The music is beautiful and empathy-inducing. 


OVERALL:

Is it worth watching? For me, I would’ve dropped this show much quicker if it weren’t for Ban and the interesting build-up to a satisfying end. But for something I found on Netflix, it is pretty entertaining. For all its stupid moments, there is a lot of heart, great characters, and foreshadowing. Give it a try!

I agree with the top guy's review, the plot is too generic and character development is too rushed. 
[Light spoiler ahead]
So, we got power level thing, nice. Things gonna be more exciting because there will be no stupid protagonist comeback overpowering enemy much more powerful than him in the last minute... I was wrong. 
The fight is basically only a show for overpowered characters while everyone else sit back and watch, maybe helping a bit by cleaning up useless troops.
"If we help him we are only going to be a burden for him."
Weak character exist only for diversity, until the author decide to power himup.\n\n
First you got useless meliodas that can barely defeat guila 3 vs 1, the next day he regained his power and one hit everyone, then 10 commandments come, he gained more power AGAIN in few days and suddenly become the strongest. Thats okay i guess, he is supposed to be the strongest, he lived through the holy war afterall.\n\n
But what about his 2 other comrades that also got 10x stronger overnight?? It's like the author can not think of ways for the protagonists to stand a chance against OP commandments other than sudden powercreeps. I feel like the number is bullshit and not a rational one, i dont think 20 holy knights with 4000 power level can fight against the weakest of commandments.\n\n
Emotional story is build only from romance, and memory erase. Like, everyone is fucking losing their memory, and then they started to cry. Or they got someone they loved killed in a war. The only thing that surprise me is they keep doing that over and over again when i thought they will have something else. Everything is so shallow its lame, not emotional at all.\n\n
I have no idea why I'm still reading the manga, maybe I still have that expectation for nanatsu no taizai, I like the concept very much and still waiting for the author to come up with a more interesting plot. \n\n
"Maybe things will get more interesting next chapter.."\n
- me, while quickly reading through the boring fights and conversations.

Just as note I dropped it after watching only the first episode. So maybe (this is a big maybe) it saves itself. But the first episode was just meh. 
I mean the premise has so much potential but it just doesn't go there. It was just very OK. And the dialogue is weird. It doesn't flow. That was probably what threw me off the most.  
It doesn't help that right before I watched this I watched some really good anime, so just by comparison it did not hold up. And I have a bunch other anime on my to watch list that I knowfor certain will be amazing. I just wanted to give it a shot because it is about the seven sins. \n\n
But at the end I knew I had better things to watch. I mean if you have nothing else to watch you can watch this. It's not so bad that I would beg people to not watch it. It is just that there are better things out there.

This was probably my first anime I watched that Netflix had produced so I didn't know what really to expect. The story line seemed interesting and it was. It wasn't the best, but it was pretty good. The plot went. I was surprised at the actual story of the Seven Deadly Sins - they have their own back story and it lightly touches on some parts of it - and my curiosity still lingers to this day because I am still wanting them to continue it - or at least have an ending closure.
There is a slight character development that you see in these charactersthough. Especially when they provide with the backstory of them, it really brings new light into the anime and lets you watch it with the considerations of the characters' past.


There were many things that was left open ended and it was not one of the things that are "left to the viewer's interpretation-type thing." So I'm definitely still expecting a continuation or something of that sort.


This was probably the most fan service anime I've watched - I typically try to avoid those kinds of anime if I knew it were included; but I guess I have to encounter it some time or another right?


Overall, I think it's a pretty good anime to watch in your free time.

Since I just made an account on this site I'll review the thing I'm currently watching I suppose.
It's cute I guess.
A (lot) of groping, but anime will be anime. Kinda gives me a nostalgic feeling, can't exactly put my finger on as to why though. Didn't think much of it at first but as I continue to watch it, it continues to hold my attention. Could be because of the predictable characters, but for some reason I'm into things like that. 
The art style is appealing. It's very unique for what it is. I think it was risky considering everyone would end up looking alittle too goofy with those button noses, but it actually looks cute. \n\n
The story is unique in the fact that I can't think of many other anime that have touched on the seven deadly sins. Obviously Fullmetal Alchemist is known for its brilliant incorporation of the sins in its plot, though this anime has decided to portray them in a more fun, lighthearted manner which I find is very refreshing. \n\n
Overall, breddy good.

One of the best done anime of the last years. Well developed with a good plot and very well tied up. History above average, and the main: Do not get lost. That is, it is already better than many scenarios out there.
Captivating characters, fun and with a humor in the right measure. Very enjoyable to watch, you end up delighting in some characters that mix seriousness with humor very well.
The animation is not out of this world, but not bad in almost no time. Quality.
Each character has their background well shown and executed. What makes you create an emotional attachment to each one of them.Some characters have not really had enough on-screen, the case of Merlin and a few others, but we will have a second season that will probably explore these characters.\n\n
Overall, Nanatsu in Taizai is a great anime. With many hits, very few mistakes and impressive lightness and softness. It is worth watching.

As i write this i am 18 episodes in. And that has been 18 episodes of enjoyment, except a few things. And i'm here to speak up. For myself.
SPOILERS AHEAD
Ok so the plot was Ok i guess.
Like i loved the sins, they were all awasome.
BUT
And this is a big But.
I HATED ELIZABETH (the princess).
(loved the other one, strong and independant. Reminds me of showel kbight)
But this princess Elizabeth is this useless fanservicy character made to get the plot starting it's rusty engine. 
And yeah you can say she was needed. (she really wasn't)
Freaking damsel in f#*kin distress. useless. F.exp in ep 18 the anime cutsinto her being knocked out, by a tiny blast with the same amount of fire power as a firecracker. and i hate her, i just wanna skip those bits man.\n\n
The music was great tho :D

I'll try and keep this short and sweet.
This anime was a solid 7 for me until about episode 18 where it really zooms in on character motivations and backstory. From that point on it is beautifully crafted, full throttle action. Everything leading up to those last 6-7 episodes becomes a whole lot clearer and you can really sit back and enjoy everything you've seen. 
I will admit that personally, I am someone who is bothered when anime/television programs take a while to kick in. I do not want to have sit through 8 boring episodes of viewing just for the 9th to be good, butin that regard I did not feel my time being wasted watching this. I felt compelled to continue watching this series in full despite not knowing where it was truly going until three quarters through, and when it finally got down to business it really made me take a step back and appreciate everything I had seen up until that point.\n\n
While this anime is far from perfect, it is definitely worth the watch. I have high hopes for the second season.

The concept of the Seven Deadly Sins in anime is nothing new, however Nanatsu No Taizai adds an interesting twist to it. It completely reverses the idea of the Seven Deadly Sins and uses it in interesting ways. The character's personalities do not reflect the sins they each represent, but their past does. However, most characters are forgettable and one-dimensional. None of these characters feel like they could be actual people personality wise, they're all walking talking fucking archetypes that don't develop in any way. The only decent character is Ban, who actually has different layers of his personality, an interesting background, and other goalsthan just reclaiming the kingdom. The music is fantastic and the action scenes, while not anything special, are pretty entertaining. However, without good characters to carry the series forward, it shows you all the worst of the shonen genre with not enough positives to make up for it.

Now this is an anime i pretty much binged.  To put it simply, i really really liked it. Some minor flaws of course, but still great. 
 Now, the name may put some people off, seeing as how many countless anime are based off of the (Catholic) seven deadly sins, however, i didn't find this a problem for once. Most likely because for one, the sins were the good guys AND were really interesting and had in depth backstories that i find all unique.
Now of course, like i said, there are flaws. I am NOT a fan of "ecchi".  I more orless tolerate it. The main reason being is i do not like the over-sexualisation of women. (They are not objects and are to be treated equally).  Saying that, what upset me the most, was how such a great character such as elizabeth was put into such skimpy outfits, and constantly molested by one of the MCs constantly. (people like that piss me off, in real life and out)  \n\n
*Ahem* Anyway, overall this has everything a good story needs. A great setting, great Characters, a good comic relief, a good villain, a good mystery, and so on. The only downside to this story, is that it's not over yet.  The manga continues the story, and (i haven't watched them yet but) there are a few OVAs.  I am not a big manga fan mostly because i just prefer anime to it.  (as a side note, i also liked how colorful this anime was) \n\n
Overall, i say give it a try.  I say till about episode 5 or so.

Nanatsu no Taizai was a series that I brushed off at first due to its "ecchi" tag. But thankfully, I was convinced that I should give this anime a short despite having such a genre. However, I was pleased that the ecchi elements were extremely minimal in this and its definitely not the focus of the show at all. 
Let us first start off with the mediocre parts of this anime. The plot, sadly, is extremely cliché and overused, something like your typical shonen material. The main female protagonist of the series is your seemingly typical damsel in distress, the one in need of constantsaving, to the point it gets slightly annoying. And additionally, it has considerably many deus ex machine moments. BUT the strange thing about this series, is that many of its weakest points are also its strongest if seen from another perspective. 


The pacing of the plot is done extremely well, with a more lighthearted beginning (although there were many serious moments in the first few episodes) and as the plot progresses and the story starts to unveil itself to be the complex and thrilling plot that it is. It goes beyond a one-dimensional and simplistic story, to bring to the viewers something that is both visually stunning with its wonderful fight scenes as well as emotionally resonating. This show made me shed quite a few tears and there will be FEELZ. The show tries to trick you at the start of the series, rendering you more confused as the episodes follow, only to reveal plot twists that I personally think was presented in such a beautiful way. 


Moving on, THE CHARACTERS URGHH WHERE DO I BEGIN? ;_; They are all really really precious and I honestly can't pick a favourite because they are all unique and lovable in their own ways. Each of them is tied together with a sin, but in contrast to what I thought at first, the sins do not represent their personality at all so don't be fooled into thinking that the cast is a bunch of one-dimensional unrealistic characters. I can't reveal too much about the other characters because they are slowly introduced as the episodes come along, and meeting them one by one was really such a fun experience for me. Their backstories are captivating and will have you rooting for them because you will subconsciously empathise with their pains and misery, although much has yet to be revealed but no worries a season 2 is already in its makings! 


Soundwise, both openings were pure awesomeness and set the right tone for such an awesome anime. The first ending theme will make you want to get up and dance and the sadder/slower second ending really sets the change in mood in the later half of the show. The battle themes are also really amazing. Although the story consists of subplots, everything is woven nicely together and overall it was such a joy to watch this I hope you will like it too! 



 many may pass it off as just another series to join the excessively hyped shonen realm along with other popular series.

The Seven Deadly Sins is the light beer of anime. The anime seems like FMA:B and Attack on Titan had a shitty baby. No really. The Seven Deadly Sins all have red marks on their bodies, like the ones in FMA. But unlike the Sins in FMA, these Sins aren't actually afflicted with their sins, especially Lust. (No really, when you meet Lust, you'll be just as confused as the characters in the show.) On the other end of the spectrum, it seems like Greed is a direct rip from FMA. Everything about him is the same.
There are countless times in the show where aplot line just stops. It was like the writers wanted so desperately to breathe some life into this corpse of an anime, but corporate wouldn't let them. At one point, it seems as though we are going to get introduced to a conflict within the Sins, but two episodes later: "...no hard feelings right?" and it's gone. And I was actaully looking forward to an actual character conflict like we had in FMA. It would have been easy, since this is the same show, but shittier. Actually, there are only two characters with this high level internal conflict in the show, and they aren't even main characters. (In the four episodes following the first season, which apparently shift the anime from action/adventure to romcom, they have cumulatively about fifteen lines.)


Next, there are characters whose attitude changes completely, which isn't really a plot hole, but completely unnecessary. But let's talk characters. Elizabeth, can you chill? Why are you always crying? I get the writers were going for a Winry type character, but honestly, just stop. They use her to try to force the cliche "inspiring anime monologue," to fill a few minutes in the show. "I'll keep fighting for you even if I'm dead." Dude, shut up.


One more point about plot. I don't mind if anime stick to cliches at all, but if you're fighting, don't take your eyes off the enemy. Nearly half the times where a character is "down for the count" is when they took their eyes off their opponent. Just...lazy writing in my opinion.


In addition, the whole show is predictable. If you have any sense of stroytelling, you'll be able to pick out the "twist" at the end in the first four episodes.


Here are it's redeeming qualities: epic sound track, the art is actually decent, and there are some great supporting characters who aren't squeaky ass "comic relief if you can even call it that" pigs.


If you like Sword Art Online, you'll like this.


4/10

Really enjoyed this anime! Hawk and Meliodas have got to be one of my Favourite characters. Story wise it's rather exciting, although not much actually happened in the 24 episodes - but I believe there's so much room for development of further episodes as evidenced by the manga. Going on to read the manga now and it is indeed entertaining! Love every single character and rly enjoyed the backstory of Ban, King and Diane (as explored further in the manga). Elizabeth is also extremely sweet and likeable, unlike other female MCs there solely as a romantic interest. However she's not very well developed and ratherone dimensional, but still likeable nonetheless (: looking forward to S2 already!

For an anime produced by A-1 Pictures, I was impressed. Compared to Fairy Tail and Sword Art Online, the content was a lot more mature. By mature, I'm speaking of sexual innuendo, fluidity of combat, and blood spillage. Many a time do characters die, or come close to dying, as Nanatsu no Taizai is a clash of epic powers. For an anime of its length, I was pleasantly surprised by the sheer quantity of power and strength in so many characters.
The premise: a princess searches for a group of powerful fighters known as the Seven Deadly Sins, each so named for committing a Sin inthe past. Now these guys, whenever a new one joins the team, boy you're continually stunned by his/her abilities. Their opponents? The kingdom's Holy Knights, each with his or her own unique abilities. Compared to the fighting in Fairy Tail, the combat here is much more fast-paced and visually enrapturing, so much so that I looked forward to watching more episodes just for that aspect.


That being said, this series shares some similarities with Naruto and Bleach and I won't say why but after you watch it you'll understand what I mean. They have to do with greater power within and the corrupted search for even more power.


The soundtrack was very good, openings and endings superb. Animation was pretty clear. In terms of character development, since the members of the Seven Deadly Sins don't all show up at once, not much really can happen. Some deep and dark things happened in the past, which continually haunt and shadow several of the main characters' current personalities and motivations. I'll just say that Ban is one of my favorite anime characters of all time.

If you're pondering over watching Nanatsu no taizai or not, there is one question you should ask yourselves: do I like shōnen anime? Because here's your typical one, surfing on familiar waves such as Fairy Tail and Dragon Ball, bringing its own share of epic. So, if the answer is yes, it's unlikely you won't enjoy the show.
Even without spoilers, you know what to expect of that kind of anime simply from the genre they belong to; that's the problem with stereotypes and this show is no exception. In fact, it doesn't even try to break the stall, doesn't try to run free and surpriseyou, or to amaze you in some way or another. Instead, it gives the feeling of honestly doing its job, and with enjoyment. What could be seen as a flaw leaves eventually a rather good impression. Yes, it's classic! Nevertheless, the story is very decent and the protagonists offer enough interest in every aspect of their characterization to make them more than likeable (now, I love giants). In the end, everything contributes to a very entertaining show, well-paced, which doesn't take his audience for fools and simply shares a common passion for the genre.


The art might look a bit weak or old-fashioned, but it's not a bother and, somehow, it contributes to the charming and colorful Dragon Ball side. That, and fist fights, super powers, transformations and the quest side. From Fairy Tail we got more of a general tone, with heroic fantasy, magic, mysterious pasts and motivations, friendship and dedication. So, once again, even without exploits in the direction and average animation, the job is pleasantly done.


Enough to say the best part is there will be sequels.

Enjoy!

In this world humans and non-humans (fairies, giants etc.) still live together, the kingdom of Leones is protected by the Holy Knights, powerful magic users both revered and feared by everyone. Supposedly the strongest, most fearsome of these knights, the Seven Deadly Sins, betrayed the kingdom and made enemies of all the other knights. But Princess Elizabeth didn't believe this story, and sets out to find the Sins - but when she meets the first Sin at a tavern (Melodias, the dragon sin of Wrath) he's not what she expected. But even so they set out to find the other sins and thus started theirepic adventure, filled with action, a bit of strange romance, humor and mystery. \n

I feel like this anime could have been much better. The premise is good, the character design is good, the settings is interesting. But the story flow and the decision making of the author makes this anime/series annoyingly tedious. I mean, why would you hype your protagonists to be the strongest of the knights who could dispose of dozens, but then, only show them struggle with a meager one or two half-assed not even fully-fledged knight. It's inane and unwarranted. Having the main characters struggle and lose, is I know, a part of the story. But them, being the strongest knights, to lose at eachand every turn. To be beaten by each and every minor villains. They, being the legends that they are, never did once beat an fodder villain effortlessly. It's counter-intuitive and annoying. The payback period is so long. At least show us the Sins overwhelm minor characters once or twice. I mean really, 3 of the sins against a minor character at the beginning, and they can't seem to take her on? What's up with their supposed strength. This anime/series could be so much better with a proper balance and clear distinction of strength and power. Imagine, it's the first arc and the much hyped "legendary" sins are already getting their asses handed to them. That's idiotic.
